column2: In a letter published March 7 the assistant executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People severely chastises Tom Wicker for writing a column which purports to support racism because it endorses the idea, often enunciated by black-power advocates, of the need for Negroes to organize themselves so that they can do more things for themselves and thereby reduce their dependence on whites.

TRENTON, March 14 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes declared today that the Democratic party would be "torn apart and disruptively split" if Senator Robert F. Kennedy opposed President Johnson for the Presidential nomination.

OSLO, Norway, March 14 (AP) -- John Bower became the first American ever to win a cross-country race in the Holmenkollen Ski Festival when he captured the 15-kilometer half of the Nordic combined today.

A SHORT time ago, during one of those "wastingthe-taxpayers'-money" waves that frequently wash over the Agency for International Development, mission heads in 70 nations around the world got it typically blunt message from their boss.
ALBANY, March 14 -- The Rockefeller administration, yielding to restive state employes, has agreed to raise their pay 10 per cent, with a minimum increase of $600 a year.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The United States in effect advised the leaders of South Vietnam today to curb public talk and any plans for an invasion of North Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- A Government survey of 1;124 color television sets in the Washington metropolitan area detected excessive radiation from 66 of them, the Public Health Service reported today.

Democratic State Chairman John J. Burns predicted yesterday that Senator Robert F. Kennedy would have the support of "a major portion" of the state's delegation to the national convention if he decided to seek the Presidential nomination.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 14 -- The Soviet Union has succeeded in expunging from the record of the Commission on Human Rights most of Ambassador Arthur J. Goldberg's charge that Soviet leaders are repressing free speech.

Following is the transcript of a television interview last night by Walter Cronkite with Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota. Mr. Cronkite, of the Columbia Broadcasting System, was in New York and Senator McCarthy was in Washington.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- A conflict-of-interest provision likely to be controversial highlighted a code of ethics proposed to the House today by its Committee on Standards of Official Conduct.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 14 -- Jack Nicklaus equaled his low score on the golf circuit this year when he tallied a 67 in the $115,000 Florida Citrus open today.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Senate Finance Committee refused by a 2-to-1 margin today to approve a 10 per cent income tax surcharge.

U. S. Industrial Chemicals Company, a division of National Distillers Chemical Corporation, said yesterday it was raising the price of pure ethyl alcohol by 5 cents a gallon for one to 17-drum quantities, effective April 1.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Union leaders who worked for Johnson delegates in the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday, reported today that the so-called "labor" wards outperformed the state as a whole in producing votes for President Johnson.
An unarmed, 42-man Community Patrol Corps will tour Harlem streets next week in a five-day experiment in community service and crime prevention.
NORTH NEWPORT, N. H., March 14 -- Winter leaves northern New England grudgingly.
LONDON, March 14 -- In a move to counter protectionist pressures developing from the world monetary crisis, Britain today proposed a speed-up in the tariff cuts agreed upon in the Kennedy round.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Federal Reserve Board raised its basic lending rate, the discount rate, to 5 per cent from 4 1/2 per cent today "to strengthen the international position of the dollar and to curb inflationary pressure in the domestic economy."

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Businessmen added another $850-million to their inventories during January, down substantially from a rise of $1.4-billion in December, the Commerce Department reported today.

RALEIGH, N. C., March 14 Columbia will play Davidson and North Carolina will meet St. Bonaventure tomorrow night in what appears to be the strongest eastern regional semifinal round to date in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championships.
Gold mining stocks remained strong yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI) -- The Senate was urged today to save Federal aid for the arts and humanities from becoming a casualty of the war in Vietnam.
The Civil Aeronautics Board has authorized what it said was the largest number of inclusive tour charters it has ever approved for a single company -- all of them within the United States.

French art song and German lieder are well known, genres that attract specialized recitalists. Is there such a thing as American art song? The question was answered in resoundingly positive terms last night by William Lewis, tenor, who sang at Carnegie Recital Hall.
ABADAN, Iran, March 7 -- Iran has begun extensive economic exchanges with the Soviet Union, which United States observers say are a logical outcome of geography.
The movement to draft Governor Rockefeller for the Presidential race gained impetus yesterday with the establishment of national headquarters at Annapolis, Md., and a New York State committee here.

Ten miles off Fire Island yesterday morning, an orange and white amphibious plane bearing the legend "U. S. Coast Guard Brooklyn" winged down out of the sun to within 200 feet of a sleek white fishing ship as big as some tankers.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Johnson and Secretary of State Dean Rusk honored an African Premier today whose policies symbolize the American goal for underdeveloped nations.
Harold Chamberlain Banks, the maritime union leader and ex-convict, won an extradition fight yesterday.

The New York Philharmonic is touching many bases this season in the celebration of its 125th anniversary. Last night it got around to what may have been the least-expected of all -- the first American performance of a work by the late Dimitri Mitropoulos, musical director of the Philharmonic from 1950 to 1958.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The House Republican leader, Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, said today that he would seek to modify open housing provisions of the Senate's controversial civil rights bill.

PORTLAND, Ore., March 14 -- Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon wrote Senator Robert F. Kennedy today that the New York Democrat would be helping President Johnson by entering the Presidential primary in Oregon.

DULUTH, Minn., March 14 (AP) -- Denver University put unmerciful pressure on George McPhee, the Boston College goalie, and he finally cracked early in the third period tonight when the Pioneers scored two rapid-fire goals en route to a 4-1 victory in a semi-final game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Present draft rules will cut back by 70 per cent the number of college men entering graduate school next fall, a national survey indicates.
Four women will be honored by the Jewish Theological Seminary of America Thursday at its benefactors' award luncheon at the New York Hilton.

ROCHESTER, March 14 -- Archbishop Luigi Raimondi, Vatican Apostolic delegate to the United States, today consecrated two vicars-general of the Diocese of Rochester as bishops. He was assisted by Bishop Fulton J. Sheen, under whom they will serve.
Original drama will be back on television stronger than ever next season.
The House Democratic leadership has intelligently decided to send the Senate version of the Civil Rights bill directly to the floor for final approval.

The apparent resolve of Senator Robert F. Kennedy to seek the Democratic Presidential nomination remakes the national political scene. Until now, President Johnson's renomination had seemed assured. He faced in Senator Eugene McCarthy's candidacy a moral challenge and a political embarrassment but not a mortal threat. Now, although the political realities continue strongly to favor Mr. Johnson, his renomination can no longer be taken for granted.

American Airlines, which is increasing its advertising and promotion budget by $3-million this year, will unveil a new campaign on Sunday whose theme may have the ultimate appeal -- patriotism, all done up in red, white and blue.
Spring will be a sure thing in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for Colony House's annual ball March 23.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Agency for International Development ordered new and tighter controls over foreign aid spending today in an effort to placate critics on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

About 35 Barnard and Columbia students, brandishing signs and petitions, marched in front of the Barnard College library yesterday in support of a girl who lives off campus with her boy friend and has been accused by Barnard of violating college housing regulations.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he preferred the positions taken on Vietnam by Senators Eugene J. McCarthy and Robert F. Kennedy, both Democrats, to that taken by Richard M. Nixon, who is seeking the Republican Presidential nomination.

A poll of Democratic voters in New Hampshire before the Presidential primary Tuesday showed that more than half those interviewed did not know where Senator Eugene J. McCarthy stood on the Vietnam war.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 14--Facing National League opposition for the first itime this spring, the New York iYankees found it indistinguishable from American League opposition and lost again today, 7-3. The defeat by the Atlanta Braves was New York's fourth in a row after two victories and a tie.

BRUSSELS, March 14 -- European bankers report that time is running out on some of the options the United States has in dealing with the massive move into gold by speculators and hoarders. In the European view, the United States has six choices, at least some of which are expected to be presented at an international monetary meeting in Washington on Saturday.
"Slaughter on Tenth Avenue," one of the first ballet pieces to be integrated into Broadway theater, will be recreated on April 30 at the New York State Theater.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 14 -- Midwestern Democrats are displaying a growing disenchantment with President Johnson.

In three previous appearances in the National Invitation Tournament, St. Peter's College of Jersey City was eliminated in the first round. But in those games, notably in a 103-58 loss to last year's eventual champion, Southern Illinois, the Peacocks never possessed a player with Elnardo Webster's elan.
Interest rates climbed dramatically and fixed-income securities prices fell sharply yesterday as the credit markets awaited announcements from the Treasury and the Federal Reserve.

Regarding your March 6 editorial titled "'D' Is for Delay," the additional $41 million requested relates solely to projects for which construction bids can definitely be placed in the next fiscal year. Specifically, it is desired to contract for:
The city school system is planning to open next fall its first bilingual school, where pupils will be taught in both English and Spanish.

Among the rums of the Mekong Delta community of Bentre early in February a United States major said sadly, "It became necessary to destroy the town in order to save it" from the Vietcong. This is a report on Bentre by Peter Arnett, an Associated Press correspondent.
PARIS, March 14 -- Panic buying on the Bourse today escalated gold trading here to a record volume.

Spokesmen for antiwar groups joined civil rights leaders here yesterday in demanding that Attorney General Ramsey Clark halt the Federal "persecution" of H. Rap Brown, militant chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Senate narrowly voted this evening to remove the gold backing for the dollar, thus freeing $10.4-billion in gold reserves to help meet the inter national demand for gold.
Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo yesterday disputed charges made by Mayor Lindsay that Governor Rockefeller's proposed Urban Development Corporation would violate home rule.
PRAGUE, March 14 -- Col. Gen. Vladimir Janko, a Deputy Defense Minister of Czechoslovakia, shot himself to death today.

The National Museum of Racing at Saratoga, N. Y., will benefit from "D~gas' Racing World," a loan exhibition of painting, .drawings and bronzes of aspects of the turf as shown by D6gas and other French painters from G~ricault to B0nnard, at the Wildenstein Gallery, 19 East ..64th Street, Thursday through April 28 and from a cham~pagne preview on WednesClay night.
YONKERS, March 14 -- Del Insko, adding two victories tonight to his driving double of the previous (opening) night at Yonkers Raceway, moved to within four triumphs of making 2,000 for his career.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Pentagon has decreed an end to K.P. for most servicemen.

MONTREAL, March 14 Struggling for a fluidity that never materialized, the Rangers dropped their third consecutive game tonight, losing to the Montreal Canadiens, 3-1. With the loss went virtually all hope of the Rangers finishing first in the National Hockey League's East Division.
CAMPER vehicles, once regarded as side - show freaks, are elbowing their way onto the main aisles of an increasing number of boat shows.

CAIRO, March 14 -- The United Arab Republic's chief censor said today that his decision to permit "Cleopatra" to be shown here was "because of the merits of the film -- it is good propaganda for Egypt."

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI) -- A group of Government employes said today that it expected thousands of civil servants to stage a public protest against President Johnson's war policies in Washington next month.

TERRENCE McNALLY provided a bitingly original look at some American attitudes toward the war in Vietnam last night in "Apple Pie," three one-act plays, presented on Channel 13's "New York Television Theater."

GENEVA, March 14 -- With three of the 17 participants withholding their approval, the disarmament conference completed work today on the much-amended draft of a treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons and referred it to a special session of the United Nations General Assembly.
When will the speculative binge in precious metals contracts end? Nobody knows, of course, but some brokers have been getting a little restless at the heavy volume and the spiraling prices.
The New York City Council Against Poverty's plan to insure "fair racial and ethnic representation" on community corporation boards was opposed last night by members of community antipoverty groups.

WHEN Rudel Briscoe and Walter Fountaine were looking around for a place to open their Coif Camp beauty salon three years ago, they did something rather earthshaking for Negro beauticians: They decided to go Downtown.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that Albany's discouraging silence on his plan for increased state aid to cities, and the new cutbacks in state medical aid and Federal poverty programs, had created "a very serious problem" for the forthcoming city budget.

A $200-million hotel, apartment and office development Iwill be erected on a sevenacre tract in downtown Phila!delphia by local banking and building interests. Plans for the development were announced yesterday by Mayor James H. J. Tate and the sponsors.
THERE was an air of apprehension in Wall Street, set off by the International monetary crisis, that continued long after the close of trading yesterday in New York City.

PARIS -- The common factor in recent demonstrations against Government policies in the United States, Britain, Poland, Spain, Czechoslovakia, Japan and Egypt is that they were largely made by students. This is an extraordinary phenomenon: a global trend that underscores a split between generations in many nations, regardless of the ideology they currently practice.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14 -- Wearing a sweatshirt of bright Cardinal red, Orlando Cepeda wheeled around the row of lockers in the clubhouse, singing at the top of his voice.
THE RETURN OF THE VANISHING AMERICAN. By Leslie A. Fiedler. 192 pages. Stein Day. $5.95.
A strike of 3,500 moving men here enters its third week today with increasing signs of frustration among the thousands of New Yorkers who want to move their household and office furnishings.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 14 -- United States efforts to persuade the South Vietnamese Government to release from prison a group of political figures, religious leaders and labor officials have failed.
TRENTON, March 14 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes said today he would recommend new taxes if necessary to pay for the programs embodied in his forthcoming special legislative message on urban issues.

William Steinberg and the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra have been playing Mahler in New York this season (who hasn't?), and their farewell concert at Carnegie Hall last night was devoted primarily to the colossal "Resurrection" Symphony.

IT is a great pity, I think, that what is undoubtedly Arnold Wesker's most ambitious play, "The Four Seasons," is also probably his worst. In the past this British playwright has been concerned with naturalistic drama, such as "Roots" and the rest of the Wesker trilogy and the Broadway success of some seasons back, "Chips With Everything."
Radio station WHN was condemned by the city's Commission on Human Rights yesterday for not employing any Negroes or Puerto Ricans.

The rush into gold has taken on stampede proportions. Private individuals and corporations have joined the speculators and hoarders in a massive demand for gold that reflects their fear and distrust of the present international monetary system.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 14 -- St Patrick's Day may be at hand, but San Francisco socialites have been wearing red, green and white hippie-type buttons proclaiming "Avanti Mattioli" in anticipation of tonight's elaborate masked ball.

The State Investigation Commission, whose recent disclosures of racketeering and Mafia influence at Kennedy International Airport led to proposed legislation for tighter state control of airport activities, has begun investigating underworld infiltration of other legitimate businesses.

THE United States interna-national team rallied sensationally yesterday to win a place in the quarterfinals of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship, the leading event of the American Contract League's Spring Nationals.

I find myself on many occasions in agreement with your editorial position on the Taylor Law and feel you have attempted to be fair. However, your paper is not and never will be fair until both sides are placed before the public.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI) -- President Johnson set up a 17-member Citizens Advisory Board on Youth Opportunity today to help disadvantaged young people prepare for adult responsibility. He named William O. Beach, 45 years old, a county judge in Clarksville, Tenn., as chairman.
PANAMA, Friday, March 15 -- President Marco A. Robles was impeached late last night by the National Assembly. His trial on charges of violating the constitution was set for March 24.

THE late E. E. Cummings (1894-1962) once described himself as an "author of pictures, a draughtsman of words." The "draughtsman of words" is, to say the least, well known as one of the classic modernists of 20th-century American poetry.

The Earl of Snowdon, looking tan and trim in a dark gray suit and a wide aqua and purple flowered tie, leaned back in his chair, sipped appreciatively from a glass of red wine, and said: "I would like my film to unnerve people: I'm not in the least concerned if they like it."
WARSAW, March 15 -- Warsaw University students joined in a classroom boycott as student defiance of the Communist regime entered its second week.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association has denied a labor federation charge that big drug concerns charge excessively high prices and endanger lives by selling unproved drugs.

THE gathering in the Rainbow Room last night was billed as "A Gala Evening of Musical Theater in the Gracious Presence of Her Royal Highness the Princess Margaret, Countess of Snowdon, and the Earl of Snowdon."

IT WAS an imaginative idea for the Manhattan School of Music to bring together in one evening three versions of "Medea." One was a fragment of the play by Euripides, in the Gilbert Murray translation.
OAKDALE, L. I. -- The residence of Gary Towlen, a young concert pianist, could hardly be called ordinary.

RALEIGH, N. C., March 15 -- Columbia's road to basketball glory came to a dead end tonight as a strong Davidson team, nearly beaten in regulation time, defeated the Lions, 61-59, in overtime during the second round of the National Collegiate basketball tournament.

BONN, March 15 -- Informed financial sources here said today that the Bundesbank. West Germany's central bank, might recommend at the gold pool meeting in Washington this weekend the adoption of a dual gold market as a means of solving the international financial crisis.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy has decided to become a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

Thousands of buttons carrying the words "Immigration Or Die" around a shamrock were distributed among persons planning to march in the St. Patrick's Parade, which will move up Fifth Avenue beginning at noon today.

Eugenia Hyman is a careful, thoughtful musician with a well-schooled and finely honed keyboard technique. It wasn't until the last half of her Carnegie Recital Hall concert last night, however, that the pianist was able to color her very accomplished playing with a strong personal character.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A new Federal entity specializing in legal matters with a sea flavor has been established within the Shipping Coordinating Committee with representatives from the Government and maritime industry organizations.

MONTREAL, March 15 -- Financial specialists in Canada, both official and private, are generally in favor of ending the London gold pool and letting the price of gold finds its own level in private transactions.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Senate approved last night and sent to President Johnson a far-reaching change in the Federal judicial system -- a requirement that jurors be chosen by lot and not hand-picked.
BRUSSELS, March 15 -- European bankers were generally unimpressed by the measures taken yesterday in Washington to defend the official dollar-gold price at $35 an ounce.
PORTLAND, Ore., March 15 -- Richard M. Nixon accused the Johnson Administration tonight of causing the gold stampede by mismanaging the country's economy.

WASHINGTON, Mar. 15 -- Senator Russell B. Long of Louisiana, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, predicted today that the House Ways and Means Committee would approve a general tax increase shortly.

Has this country ever sought to discover the full potentialities of music and the dance as psychological aids to reach boys and girls of economically and culturally disadvantaged background? Not simply to entertain, but to break through psychic and social barriers?
INDIO, Calif., March 15 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower voiced his support today of both the course of the war in Vietnam and of Congress's action on the gold problem.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Johnson Administration has asked New York City businessmen to provide at least 54,200 jobs over the next six months as part of its new program to cure hard-core unemployment.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 15 -- New York University, Columbia and Navy dominated the opening round of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association's 71st annual championships in Princeton's Dillon Gymnasium today.

The New York Mets announced yesterday that they would permit the New York Giants and the New York Jets to play an exhibition pro football game at Shea Stadium in the late summer of 1969. The Giants and Jets said they had not been officially notified and therefore have not yet accepted the terms drawn up by the Mets.

No concerned American can treat lightly the report of the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders. The recent vulgar remarks of George Wallace either indicate that he hasn't read the report or that he is so concerned with his own selfish interests that he has no regard for the future of our society or for the constitutional assurance of freedom and equal rights for all.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 15 -- A murder trial with politica overtones ended today when the State Security Court sentenced Adnan Sultani, a 28-year-old bank messenger, to death for the murder on May 16, 1966, of Kamel Mrowa, a newspaper publisher.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 15 -- The Reserve Officers Training Corps at Rutgers University has been attacked by the residents of nearby Piscataway Township for using blank small-arms ammunition on maneuver in a wooded area of the university campus.

CHICAGO, March 15 -- The Federal Aviation Administrator disclosed yesterday "staggering'' new air travel forecasts and warned of "more and more regulation" unless airways and airports were modernized rapidly.
HONG KONG, March 15--Peking pictured the international gold crisis today as an inevitable development of capitalist monetary structure, which, it said, was "likely to fall apart at any time."

LANSING, Mich., March 15 (AP) -- Gov. George Romney said today the New Hampshire primary "clearly shows the people now see through the Administration's continuous brainwashing" about a Vietnam solution through military escalation.

PORT LOUIS, Mauritius, March 15 -- This neat little Indian Ocean port takes its name from a Bourbon King of France. Louis XV, so it follows that its municipal flag shows golden fleurs de lys on a field of royal blue.

Not even the Thuringian peasantry of Theophile Gautier's imagination could quite raise the Long Island Civic Ballet Company's program at Cooper Union last night to full-fledged professional standards, but it helped.

DULUTH, Minn., March 15 (AP) -- North Dakota cracked through Cornell's all-American goalie, Key Dryden, and upset the Big Red, 3-1, tonight in a semi-final game in the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament.
Arthur J. Morrell is a handsome 21-year-old Negro from the South Bronx who wears a tie and a tastefully cut brown leather sports jacket, holds a high school diploma and wants to be a psychiatrist.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 16 -- The allied forces announced yesterday that they had begun the largest offensive operation of the war in an effort to capture or destroy the 8,000 to 10,000 enemy troops believed to be near Saigon.

The trading floor of the New York Mercantile Exchange was noticeably quiet yesterday after frenzied sessions during the week in platinum and palladium. Members of the exchange, best known as a center for trading potatoes, concentrated on this more plebian commodity.
THE distinctive feautres of 18th-century Maryland furniture are clearly displayed in an exhibition now at the Baltimore Museum of Art.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Governor Rockefeller will meet here Tuesday with nearly 20 Republican Senators to sample party sentiment before announcing whether he will actively seek the Presidential nomination.
A steamfitters group was ordered yesterday to appear at a public hearing to answer charges that it discriminates against Negro and Puerto Ricans in its apprentice training program.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A spokesman for an organization of antiwar business executives attributed the gold-buying rush today to world reaction to the expanded United States role in the Vietnam war.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- The chief of the Army Engineers announced today that a dam and reservoir would be built in the Red River Gorge in eastern Kentuck despite proposals that they be built elsewhere to preserve the area.

AN apple for the teacher or an apple for a child is often more acceptable if it has been combined with choice ingredients and baked into a perfect bread or cake. The following recipes are suggested to do just that.

" When I heard the split times, I was pleased. It made me run all the faster." This is how John Brady, a long-striding St. Helena senior, summed up his setting of a national all-floors record of 2 minutes 12.4 seconds for the 1,000-yard run last night.
Operating profits of the Martin Marietta Corporation fell sharply last year despite an increase in sales, it was announced here yesterday.

MANY observers rated the recent spring showings in Paris and Rome the most boring and pointlessly gag-filled in history. Yet Alexander's buyers have managed to find 50 designs worth copying for women who expect clothes to make them look fresh and appealing.
BERLIN, March 15 -- East German officials announced today that they were planning college reforms and that they had instituted a public opinion poll to study trends among the country's youth.

NEW ORLEANS, March 15 -- In an effort to "minimize chaos," correct past "bottle-necks," and maintain "constitutional" government during riots, the National Association, of District Attorneys issued today broad guidelines dealing with the administration of criminal justice.
The Glen Alden Corporation is holding negotiations to acquire all of the outstanding common stock of Schenley Industries, Inc. The deal would involve in excess of $400-million.

The City University's 7,000 faculty members overwhelmingly endorsed yesterday the charter of a proposed faculty senate that would give them greatly increased control of basic decision-making at the seven-year-old educational complex.
Former Vice President Nixon had more than a lot of primary votes on his side when he observed after the New Hampshire balloting that 1968 was no year for "absentee candidates."
MILWAUKEE, March 15 -- President Johnson's campaign chairman for the Wisconsin primary said today that he had urged Vice President Humphrey to come to Wisconsin to help.
Governor Rockefeller will ask the Legislature for a compulsory health insurance program that covers more persons and gives them vastly greater benefits than his previous proposals.
Harold (Hal) C. Banks, a maritime union leader, was released from Federal custody yesterday after the State Department denied a Canadian request that he be extradited for alleged perjury.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A device that was patented this week by a woman research chemist is being used in laboratories around the world to detect pesticides in foods. The detector invented by Mrs. Laura E. Giuffrida gave the Food and Drug Administration for the first time a direct means of discovering the presence of an important class of pesticides containing organic phosphates.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 15 -- Jack Nicklaus, still searching for a suitable driver, led at the halfway mark today in the $115,000 Florida Citrus open golf tourney as Arnold Palmer failed to qualify for the final 36 holes.
Stock prices sprang back yesterday as the market responded to moves designed to ease the international monetary crisis.
Wall Street reacted calmly yesterday to the international monetary crisis, showing scarcely a sign of emotion as a pint-sized morning selloff turned into a full-fledged afternoon rally.
PANAMA, March 15 -- President Marco A. Robles declared today that he would not recognize an attempt by the National Assembly to try him for violating the Constitution.
New York financial markets took in stride yesterday the announcements late Thursday of a temporary shutdown of the London gold market and an increase in the Federal Reserve's discount rate.

SIR ALEC GUINNESS, sitting in the empty gallery of a London theater, looked at the camera last night in the final moments of a documentary entitled "The Actor." He spoke the speech from "The Tempest" about performers melting into thin air and being the stuff of which dreams are made.
A BATH towel has tomato catchup all over it. A cow is to lean against. So is a girl with long eyelashes and a heart-shaped mouth. A giant gin bottle guards pennies. A cooky is to put hot plates on.
Terrain in the vicinity of San Francisco is reportedly being warped at a rate that some earthquake specialists consider alarming.

Music for an Austrian wedding and a French comedy made a handsome couple last night at Philharmonic. Hall, where Thomas Dunn conducted the season's final subscription concert of his Festival Orchestra.

In your March 5 editorial you state that a Charter amendment to allow the Mayor, City Council and the Borough Presidents to share in the appointment of community planning boards would be "likely to promote factionalism and drag the boards into politics."
The sixth annual Louise Waterman Wise Awards of the American Jewish Congress National Women's Division will be presented March 27 at the group's benefit luncheon in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom.
A Roman Catholic order of nuns and an agency of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations will jointly sponsor a series of two-week institutes on Judaism for Catholic educators this summer.

ATHENS, March 15 -- Premier George Papadopoulos promised today to hold a referendum for a new constitution on Sept. 1 as a first step toward a return to parliamentary democracy under King Constantine.
Price increases involving such diverse products as beer cans, graphite electrodes and palladium were announced yesterday by a number of manufacturers.
CONCORD, N. H., March 15 (UPI) -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy came within 230 votes of outpolling President Johnson in the New Hampshire Presidential primary Tuesday, official returns showed tonight.

The chief administrator of one of the city's three pilot school decentralization projects resigned yesterday with an attack on the Board of Education for allegedly undermining the experiment in community control.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Industrial production was essentially unchanged in February, but housing starts and personal income both rose.

Robert Kennedy has waited, allowing Senator McCarthy to take all the risks and to do all the dirty work. Now that Senator McCarthy has shown that Johnson's defeat is possible, Kennedy shows interest in wresting the victory from McCarthy.
Thirty-eight small children were carried to safety yesterday just before cold, muddy water spouting from a broken main poured in the windows of a school bus stalled on a sunken road in Central Park.
Bond prices scored large gains yesterday in trading activity that dealers found gratifyingly orderly in the wake of Thursday's world-shaking economic news developments.

A concert version of "Oklahoma!" will be given March 26 by the New York Philharmonic at Philharmonic Hall. The orchestra's pension fund will receive the proceeds of the evening arranged by its auxiliary board.
A strike against The Long Island Star-Journal scheduled for today is expected to result in the suspension of the newspaper.
Mayor Lindsay named a task force of top-level administration officials yesterday to assist the Board of Education in speeding up lagging school construction.

PRAGUE, March 15 -- A purge of the Czechoslovak Government began today with the dismissal of the Interior Minister and the Attorney General. At the same time, the campaign for the removal of President Antonin Novotny and other ranking Government figures gathered speed.
DETROIT, March 15 -- Larry James, a new face in the 440-yard run, and Bob Beamon, an old hand at the long jump, set world indoor track records tonight in Cobo Arena.

With different styles and different burdens, two playmakers -- Jo Jo White of Kansas and Bob Melchionni of Villanova -- guided their teams to decisive opening-round victories in the 31st National Invitation Tournament last night before 13,041 customers at Madison Square Garden.
The Board of Estimate and the City Council yesterday struck $25.9-million for building a new police headquarters from Mayor Lindsay's proposed capital budget for the coming year.

As a former student of government I read with great interest C. L. Sulzberger's column (Feb. 18) on the possibility of replacing NATO's Supreme Commander, General Lemnitzer, with a Britisher. A non-American Supreme Commander would, he argues, give the alliance a less "American" look.

The undersigned differ widely among themselves in their evaluation of our commitment in Vietnam, our military and administrative policies pursued there and the professed peace aims of our Government. But we are as one in rejecting the economic measures by which the Administration and Congress are trying to implement these policies, both as inadequate and ultimately self-defeating.

Spokesmen for both management and dissident stockholders of the Northern Pacific Railroad's merger with the Great Northern and Chicago, Burlington Quincy railroads would not comment yesterday on the results of voting at a stockholders' meeting of the Northern Pacific on Thursday in St. Paul.

THE title of the Metropolitan Museum's new exhibition. "Three Centuries of Peruvian Silver," is a misnomer, since the 17th and 18th centuries are barely represented. Essentially it is a 19th-century show.
BRASILIA, March 15--President Arthur da Costa e Silva ended his first year in office today with a pledge to make Brazil the first great nation south of the equator.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Kennecott Copper Corporation announced today it had reached a tentative agreement with 26 unions covering some of the company's properties.
VENICE, March 15 -- The Roman Catholic Church took a solemn preliminary step today toward formal recognition of Pope John XXIII as a saint.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -Corporate mergers showed the largest increase in modern industrial history in 1967, whether measured by number of mergers or number of acquisitions of sizable companies, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.

TRENTON, March 18 -- A legislative crime commission recommended today that the responsibility of the state public defender be expanded to include every indigent defendant facing a possible prison sentence.
