ST. JOHN'S, Antigua, March 19 (Reuters) -- The police opened fire today on demonstrators supporting a call by the anti-Government Antigua Workers Union for a general strike.
Complaints of crimes here rose 12.4 per cent in January over the same period last year, but arrests rose only 1.8 per cent, according to Police Department figures.

A libel and slander suit for $418,000 against the city and two retired police officers over testimony they gave as experts on the Mafia before a special Italian court convened here in 1965 was dismissed yesterday.

A record 38.7 million gross tons of merchant vessels are operating on the world's waters under the classification rules of the American Bureau of Shipping despite a decrease in the number of craft registered by the society.

NEW HAVEN, March 19 -- Backers of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy made it certain today that primary elections testing President Johnson's strength would be held next month in most of Connecticut's major towns and cities.

For several months the more extreme elements in Prime Minister Ian Smith's Rhodesia front have threatened to break away and form their own party. Now some of them have set up a Rhodesian National party to work for more drastic racial segregation, a more belligerent policy toward Zambia and a ban on further negotiations with Britain, aimed at achieving legal independence.
A total of $22-million has been pledged to the Uris Building Corporaiton by Aetna Life Casualty of Hartford for the financing of a $100-million office complex in Rockland County.

Mayor Lindsay urged 3,000 cheering Queens College students yesterday to join the "resistance movements" in the Republican and Democratic parties, and then predicted that Governor Rockefeller would lead the Republican resistance to the war in Vietnam.
Trading volume trailed off sharply yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as prices drifted down.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- Some 6,500 striking copper workers approved a contract with one company today, and prospects brightened in talks involving three other major strikebound concerns.

The S. S. Kresge Company raised its earnings 22 per cent last year and its sales 27 per cent lifting the volume above the billion-dollar mark set in 1966, the variety store chain reported yesterday from Detroit.

State and Federal authorities broadened a search yesterday for Winston Moseley, the slayer of Catherine (Kitty) Genovese. He broke away from a prison guard in Buffalo on Monday, four years to the day after he was arrested for her murder in Queens.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- A Securities and Exchange Commission hearing examiner today accused two financiers. Victor Muscat and Edward Krock, of "arrant conflict of interest" and "lack of good faith" in connection with a proposed securities transaction involving companies they control.

HOUSTON, March 19 -- Almost all major oil company spokesmen told the Texas Railroad Commission at its annual market review today that while demand for oil products in the United States would rise by 3.5 to 4 per cent this year, much of the growth should be supplied from foreign oil.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- The Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, who has been critical of United States policies in Vietnam, said today he would devote his efforts this year to keeping the Democratic party together.
Stock prices retreated in quiet trading yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- A Senate investigating panel reprimanded the Defense Department today for doing nothing to recover or avoid annual payments of $10-million to $20-million a year in port charges to countries receiving military aid grants.
Off Off Broadway is facing the worst crisis of its hectic life and many of these tiny showplaces so dear to avant-gardists may have to close.

The Harpur College music department was represented by a performance of dignity and quality at Town Hall last night when it presented a concert by the New York Woodwind Quintet and Ruth Laredo, pianist.
Gold mining shares were again active on the London Stock Exchange yesterday, closing above their lows for the day.
The New York Jets announced a new training camp site yesterday and a third knee operation for Joe Namath, their all-American Football League quarterback.

A longshoremen's work stoppage virtually paralyzed the Port of New York for a second day yesterday, and the dock workers' union said the stoppage would spread today to all ports from Portland, Me., to Norfolk, Va.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- United Press International normally requires a substantial down-payment before it sells its news service to any new newspaper whose chances for survival appear questionable, a U.P.I. vice president, Frank Tremaine, told Senate investigators today.

YONKERS, March 19 -- Del Insko, needing one victory to reach the 2,000 plateau in a harness-racing career that is in its 23d season, achieved that triumph on his sixth and final attempt tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

The use of atomic energy to provide "fingerprints" that might establish the ages and origins of paintings will be explored by the Atomic Energy Commission and the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

WARSAW, March 19 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka, the Polish Communist party leader, sought today to moderate the anti-Zionist campaign that has spread across the country in the past week with apparent official blessing.
Doug Thomas had wet sand on his face and the kind of remorse in his voice normally associated with a jockey whose horse had not run fast enough.

Two city hospitals provided more than $1-million in services for research projects, but two voluntary hospitals with which they were affiliated got the money, a state investigator testified yesterday.

Let's step into the future. The millenium has arrived. The nations of the world have agreed to accept Special Drawing Rights in the International Monetary Fund -- paper gold -- as their international monetary reserves.

Since Congress has been notoriously and deliberately obtuse on the subject of ethical standards, the reports submitted to both houses last week have to be considered progress. But the report to the House is less than ideal, and the Senate committee's "important beginning" is hopelessly inadequate.
With the basketball on the rim at the buzzer in both games, sentiment lost a double-header by narrow margins last night in the 31st National Invitation Tournament.

The same kind of cooperation by which major nations dealt last weekend with the gold crisis is needed also to maintain a liberal world trade system, William M. Roth, chief Administration trade official, asserted yesterday.

Up to this time opposition to the Vietnam war has been largely identified with the liberal left, and the grounds of opposition have been chiefly moral. It may be time for the conservative right to consider our involvement from the unsentimental viewpoint of the national interest.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Senator Thruston B. Morton of Kentucky will play a major role in directing Governor Rockefeller's campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination, possibly as national campaign manager.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- Secretary of Transportation, Alan S. Boyd, said today a full study of the auto insurance industry was necessary to bring about a modern, fair and efficient system of compensation.
The who, what, where, when and why questions of the National Hockey League playoffs were discussed here yesterday, but the central problem the the league's board of governors grappled with was "how?"
ALBANY, March 19 -- A bill that would raise the basic parimutuel tax at New York race tracks to 16 per cent was passed today by the State Senate, 56 to 1.
Howard Stein, president of the Dreyfus Fund, one of the nation's largest mutual funds, is joining the Presidential campaign of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy as a fund raiser.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 19 -- Six North Vietnamese Army defectors, two of them doctors, said today that Hanoi's intelligence agencies provided as much as 24 hours' notice of American B-52 raids in South Vietnam.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., March 19 -- Lucius Amerson, the first Negro sheriff in Alabama since the Reconstruction, said today that his department had arrested the white police chief of Notasulga and a state trooper in connection with the beating of a Negro.
OSLO, Norway, March 19 -- King Olav V gave his consent today for the marriage of his 31-year-old son, Crown Prince Harald, to a commoner.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- Representative Edwin E. Willis, chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, today urged college and high school students to boycott an international student strike April 26.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen raised many questions today about the proposed Senate code of ethics.

A joint study by the Delaware Hudson and Boston Maine railroads has shown that "substantial" savings could be achieved if the two properties were put together, management of the B. told its stockholders yesterday in the 1967 annual report.
New York City's antipoverty agencies were confronted yesterday with the necessity of making a 15 per cent cut in the Federally aided portion of their community action programs in the next six months.
A model of Rome's Trevi Fountain will be set up at the entrance of the WaldorfAstoria's Grand Ballroom on April 4 for the Ball of the Year benefiting Boys' Towns of Italy.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 19 -- A 10-year research project conducted by nine legal scholars from seven countries will reach fruition tomorrow with the publication of "Formation of Contracts: A Study of the Common Core of Legal Systems."

CAIRO -- The revolts against Moscow rule within what used to be regarded as Russia's East European sphere have all been accomplished by human willpower instead of historical determinism. In the name of Marx the most un-Marxist things have been done, and one must await the outcome of current events in Czechoslovakia and Poland to judge this rule again.
THERE is always a special joy in hearing Mozart played by a small and skilled orchestra, and so it was last night in Carnegie Hall when Anshel Brusilow conducted the Chamber Symphony of Philadelphia.
TAMPA, Fla., March 19 (UPI) -- Mayor Dick Greco warned today that the city would not tolerate a recurrence of the looting and rock throwing that erupted last night in a Negro district.
LINCOLN, Neb., March 19 -- The question of whether Governor Rockefeller's name can legally be entered in the May 14 primary here is expected to be settled soon.

A bearded Indian doctor with an immaculate white turban pushed a yellow baggage cart with four trunks along the second-floor platform of Pier 86 yesterday morning, two hours after the liner United States had docked in this strikebound port.
LISBON, March 19 -- Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar's Government has arrested and ordered the deportation of Mario Soares, a Socialist leader.

The Metropolitan Opera will open its 84th season on Monday, Sept. 16, with Cilea's "Adriana Lecouvreur," in the same production staged by Nathaniel Merrill during the 1962-63 season. Mr. Merrill will again direct the work, and the four leading singers will be the same: Renata Tebaldi, Irene Dalis, Franco Corelli and Anselmo Colzani. Morley Meredith also is in the cast, and Fausto Cleva will conduct.
A 25-year-old youth who has been in prison since May, 1961, was ordered freed yesterday, and the charges against him dismissed.

WHO -- forget about whom -- did you see and hear last night on "Who, What, Where, Why" from 10 to 11 on the network of the Columbia Broadcasting System? The answer is the visible Harry Reasoner and the off-screen essayist Andrew A. Rooney, indulging their humor and concern over "The Strange Case of the English Language."
The Xerox Corporation announced yesterday price changes, effective May 1, on some of its copiers and copier duplicators.

CHEKHOV'S last play, "The Cherry Orchard," that Janus-faced comedy looking first at this Russia and then at that, was given a new production last night at the Lyceum Theater by the APA Repertory Company.
ZURICH, Switzerland -- The Dow Chemical Company has operated a bank in Zurich for the last two years in one of the more unusual experiments on the European financial scene.

BRUSSELS, March 19 (Reuters) -- The European Common Market's Executive Commission has suggested that the United States slow down its plans to reduce tariffs under the Kennedy round to help overcome its balance-of-payments problem.

Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan plans to announce his candidacy for the United States Senate today. He will be the fourth candidate actively trying to become the Democrat opposing Senator Jacob K. Javits this fall.
GENEVA, March 19 -- Swiss bankers welcomed Britain's austerity budget tonight in the belief that it would help the country overcome its balance-of-payments problem.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Justice Department said today that efforts to brand the W.E.B. Dubois Clubs of America a Communist front group may have to be abandoned because of a new Supreme Court position on electronic eavesdropping.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 19 -- Informed sources said today that there were 55 per cent more North Vietnamose troops in South Vietnam than the total of such troops estimated after the enemy's Lunar New Year offensive.

DETROIT, March 19 -- The automobile industry has formally told the Government that it opposes speed - governing devices for automobiles. Instead the industry suggested that a system that caused the car horn to blow and lights to flash at excessive speeds might be workable.

GRENADA, Miss., March 19 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today he would summon to Washington on June 15 "a massive outpouring of hundreds of thousands of people, white and black" for a "special day of protest" in his "poor people's campaign" in the capital this spring and summer.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Johnson's hopes for quick approval of a controversial civil rights bill were dashed today by the House Rules Committee.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 19 -- United States infantrymen continued sweeping the jungles and flatlands on the fringes of Saigon today. South Vietnamese paratroopers uncovered a weapons cache near the capital.

CAIRO, March 19 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser has decided to bring into his Cabinet 14 relatively obscure civilians who have never been ministers before, Egyptian officials reported tonight, but there were indications of a hitch in his plans for the most sweeping Government reshuffle here in 15 years.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI) -- An advisory commission on veterans' programs called today for expanded benefits ranging from increased disability compensation to higher burial allowances for the nation's former servicemen.
Several representatives of large advertising agencies admitted yesterday that they had not been using sufficient numbers of Negroes and Puerto Ricans in television commercials.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Royals moved into a tie for fourth place and a possible playoff berth by defeating the Philadelphia 76ers, 131-130, in an overtime National Basketball Association game at Convention Hall tonight.

ADELAIDE, Australia, March 19 (UPI) -- Tracy Smith of the United States Army won the 3,000-meter run and Nancy Benson of Phoenix, Ariz., took the women's 400-meter event today to be named outstanding performers in a track meet between the United States and Australia.

The American General Insurance Company increased its investment in the Texas National Bank of Commerce in Houston through the purchase yesterday of more than 800,000 shares of the bank's stock. The transaction exceeds $40-million, according to B. N. Woodson, president of the Houston holding company.
The credit markets, after weeks of excitement over gold, settled down yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Johnson offered another defiant response this evening to the challengers of his Vietnam policy by insisting that "we have set our course" and "America will prevail."
ROCHESTER, March 19 -- A drive to consolidate support for the renomination of President Johnson was opened here tonight by a group of upstate Democratic county chairmen.
PRAGUE, March 18 -- Czechoslovakia's reform leadership was reported today to have blocked a trip to West Germany for President Antonin Novotny's son for fear that he might defect.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Politics might replace pot and pills, it was suggested here today, as the opiate of the hallucination generation this year as more and more young people tune out of the drug scene and turn on to campaigning.
Business leaders started programs yesterday to attack two major problems of the city's slums: substandard housing and a shortage of adequate jobs.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- A House subcommittee is asking the Federal Government to spend about $3-million next year on a program that some scientists think may offer modern civilization one of its last chances for survival.

PARIS, March 20 (Reuters)-A French naval task force is on its way to the Pacific to prepare for the first French hydrogen bomb test scheduled for this summer, the Armed Forces Ministry announced today. The task force sailed from Toulon March 12 for the nuclear test center at Mururoa and Gangatofa atolls, southeast of Tahiti.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 21 (AP)--President Nguyen Van Thieu promised today to increase the South Vietnamese armed forces by 135,000 men, to crack down on corruption, and to improve the efficiency of the Government's machinery.

The scholarship fund of the Westchesmr Day School in .naroneck, N. Y, benefit from the Crystal Ball, a dlnrer dance to be held on Sunday in the Pierre's Grand Ballroom. The even: will also celebrar the school's 20th nniversary and honor its headmaster, S. Maurice Plot:nick.

W. Clement Stone was elected yesterday chairman of the Commerce and Industry Insurance Company, New York. Mr. Stone is president of the Combined Insurance Company of America, Chicago, which recently acquired Commerce and Industry Insurance.
Special to The New York Times NUREMBERG, West Germany, March 20--West Germany's Social Democratic party pledged today to "respect and recognize" the present western frontier of Poland.
Special to The New York Times LONDON, March 20--Since mid-1962 the number of Britons leaving their country has exceeded the number of immigrants.

Special to The New York Times SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 20--The North Vietnamese Government, in its first pronouncements on the Presidential candidacy of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, has indicated coolness toward both Mr. Kennedy and Senator Eugene J. McCarthy.

Formation of a Nelson A. Rockefeller White House Club, with an estimated 17,000 members from coast to coast, was announced yesterday. The organization of boosters for the New York Republican was announced by the group's co-chairmen, Lawrence J. Byrne, an attorney at 32 Court Street, Brooklyn, and John G. Walsh.

Special to The New York Times INDIANAPOLIS, March 20--A small valley tucked in the central Indiana woodlands 35 miles west of here has become a national battleground for the Izaak Walton League and the United States Army Corps of Engineers.

Special to The New York Times STEAMBOAT SPRINGS, Colo., March 20 -- This quiet cattleranching community, which was named a century ago by three exploring French trappers who heard the chugging at a local spring and decided it sounded like a steamboat's, becomes the collegiate capital of skiing tomorrow.

Ever since Mademoiselle Magazine was born back in the Depression, its August College Issue has been a big ad grabber. For a while there, in fact, it was the only issue of a fashion book to pull in $l-million dollars in ads.

The National Alliance of Businessmen has asked private employers in this area to provide 18,500 adult job opportunities for the hard-core unemployed and 35,700 summer jobs for disadvantaged youths. It seeks what Mayor Lindsay has rightly called "a major and very important commitment."
HOUSTON, March 20 (UPI) --A 43-year-old Pennsylvania real estate and insurance salesman underwent surgery today that employed Dr. Michael E. DeBakey's left ventricular bypass heart pump.
The Tri-State Transportation Commission authorized yesterday the establishment of three experimental bus service on Long Island. The service is scheduled to start some time next month.
EAGLE PASS, Tex., March 20 (AP)--Gov. John B. Connally Jr. of Texas will dedicate the new international bridge linking Eagle Pass and Piedras Negras on April 5.
PARIS, March 20 (UPI) -- Nine American deserters and draft dodgers opposed to United States involvement in Vietnam were granted residence and work permits by French authorities today.
THE GENTLE BONAPARTE. A Biography of Joseph. Napoleon's Elder Brother. By Owen Connelly. 335 pages. Macmillan. $6.95.
There was no brake on the motel industry's expansion in 1967, a survey by a leading realty company shows.

Special to The New York Times ALBANY, March 20 -- Governor Rockefeller today named Mrs. Ada Fisher Jones, a Negro teacher and civic worker, as his assistant appointments officer. Mrs. Jones, whose annual salary will be $16,500, will help select appointees for state jobs that do not fall under the civil service system.

The American Electric Power Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday new highs in net income for the 12 months ended Feb. 29. The report placed net income at a new high of $95,414,000, equal to $2.02 a share. This was 7.3 per cent higher than the $88,957,000, or $1.92 a share, on fewer shares in the like 1967 period.

MOSCOW, March 20 (AP)-Olga Kosiceva of Czechoslovakia won her third event, the 800-meter free-style, today, as the five-day swimming meet sponsored by the Soviet youth newspaper. Komsololskaya Pravda, ended at Minsk.
JERUSALEM, March 20-Israel's Defense Minister, Maj. Gen. Moshe Dayan, nearly lost his life today when he was burled by sand for a few minutes in a cave-in at an archeological site near Tel Aviv.

NEW HAVEN, March 20 (UPI)--The Yale Law School Alumni Association today named associate United States Supreme Court Justice Potter Stewart for its Citation of Merit, its highest award. The presentation will be made by Chief Justice Earl Warren April 27. Justice Stewart was graduated in 1937 from Yale College and in 1941 from the law school.

Special to The New York Times LISBON, March 20 -- The wife of the democratic opposition leader Mario Soares sent a last-minute appeal to Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar today to save her husband from banishment. The Government arrested the 43 - year - old lawyer yesterday and ordered him to be deported to Sao Tomee, in the Gulf of Guinea. off Africa.

DOVER, Del., March 20 (AP)--Students at Delaware State College boycotted classes today in support of a list of proposals drawn up by officers of the student government. The orderly boycott was effective, halting all classes.

A pharmacist who formerly controlled a pharmacy in the financial district was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on income tax evasion charges. The pharmacist, Louis Rifkin, 57 years old, of 926 East 16th Street, Brooklyn, formerly controlled Vim Chemists 134 Inc., at 2 Broadway. He was charged with evading $25,000 in income taxes for 1961 through 1963.
MONTREAL, March 20 (AP) --A series of small fires in mattresses stored in the stairwells of the 21-story Queen Elizabeth Hotel today forced the evacuation of 250 guests. There were no injuries.

Steadying trends were again in evidence in the foreign-exchange market in New York yesterday. Returning confidence in the British pound, apparent abroad as well, carried the currency up to its best level in the last couple of weeks. It closed at $2.4072, compared with Tuesday's $2.4060, 12 points higher on the day.

Random House, Inc., a subsidiary of the Radio Corporation of America, announced here yesterday the election of C. R. Groux as administrative vice president and Morris Berkowitz as financial vice president.
The National Catholic Office for Motion Pictures has placed its "Class C" or "Condemned" rating on "Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush," the British film now showing at the Baronet Theater.
ROXBURY, Vt. -- In 1966 Vermont became the last state in the union to permit the hunting of antlerless deer with firearms.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)--The Department of the Interior disclosed today it was considering replacing its present system of allocating oil import licenses by a system of auctioning them in competitive bidding.

Special to The New York Times RIO DE JANEIRO, March 20--A 20-year scandal of murder, rape and robbery, of Brazil's Indians has been uncovered by an investigating commission of the Ministry of the Interior.
Special to The New York Times ALBANY, March 20--Assembly Democrats today beat back Republican efforts to introduce a bill outlawing school integration through the busing of pupils.

BIRD'S Opening--1 P-KB4-is a Dutch Defense with a move in hand and, as such, yields an initiative in conjunction with its natural defensive qualities. But it grants White only a scant hold on the center. Even so, its general pattern appeals to the adventurous, and it leads to an eccentric equality.
Special to The New York Times SAN FRANCISCO, March 20 --A 1 per cent payroll tax on commuters was proposed to the Board of Supervisors today by Mayor Joseph L. Alioto.

The three-judge Federal Statutory Court that ordered the Legislature last year to redraw the lines of the state's Congressional districts accepted yesterday the controversial plan offered it by the Legislature.
Special to The New York Times ROSELLE, N. J., March 20--Flames, at times leaping 50 feet in the air, today destroyed a vacant mansion, a 61-year-old landmark, at 127 East Fifth Avenue.

Congestion, imbalanced operations, uneconomic practices and unjustified competitive pressures plague the Port of New York, Representative John M. Murphy said last night. He urged prompt action to cure these problems.

CHICAGO, March 20 (AP)-Everett McKinley Dirksen, Senator, orator and recording artist, has added film actor to his list of occupations. Wilding Studios, Chicago, announced that the Senate minority leader had agreed to appear in a feature film, "The Monitors."
Special to The New York Times PORTLAND, Ore., March 20 --"Get Morse" is a battle cry heard among Oregonians every six years since Wayne Morse was elected to the Senate as a Republican in 1944.

Special to The New York Times ALBANY, March 20--Republican leaders in Albany, Washington and New York City were concluding tonight that Governor Rockefeller had decided upon something less than an all-out campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination.

Special to The New York Times HARRISBURG, Pa., March 20 --The Pennsylvania Democratic chairman, Thomas Z. Minehart, said today he would ask Senator Joseph S. Clark this weekend to reconsider his conditional position and declare full support of President Johnson for re-election.
Lively, imaginative television programing aimed at millions of preschool youngsters will be tested in an $8-million series scheduled to go on the air in the fall of 1969.
The conviction and murder sentence of a 24-year-old state prisoner were set aside yesterday in Federal Court on the grounds that a coerced confession was used against him at his trial in 1959.

Special to The New York Times UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 20--Roger Hilsman, a former senior official in the State Department, has proposed that the United States de-escallate the military side of the war in Vietnam, "de-Americanize" the struggle and work for a broader-based and more reformist and responsive government in Saigon.

DALLAS, March 20 (UPI)--The Dallas Chaparrals insured at least a tie for second place in the Western Division of the American Basketball Association tonight with a 109-97 victory over the New Jersey Americans.
The New York Knickerbockers eliminated Cincinnati from a National Basketball Association playoff berth last night by defeating the Royals, 108-106, at Madison Square Garden.
THE Chillino girls figure that being a big family has made the crucial difference. Otherwise they might never have been able to open their own shop.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (Reuters)--The Treasury said today it completed gold transfers to meet losses to the now-defunct London gold pool with a massive, new shipment of $750-million worth of gold in the last week.

LOS ANGELES, March 20 (AP) -- Dyan Cannon testified today, in her divorce suit against Cary Grant, the actor, that he used the hallucinatory drug LSD for 10 years, frequently went into "yelling and screaming fits" and beat her.
TAKE the nation's leading commercial bankers, sprinkle with tart comments on their earnings statements and they'll boil over without the application of heat.
The London Stock Exchange responded with a broad advance yesterday to the proposed new British budget.
Several large advertisers yesterday laid at least part of the blame for the infrequent use of Negroes and Puerto Ricans in TV commercials on their advertising agencies.
Special to The New York Times BRUSSELS, March 20--The price of gold continued to slip today in the newly established free market as dealers spoke of a squeeze on the speculators.
The Marine Midland Grace Trust Company of New York announced yesterday the election of Harold W. Rasmussen as executive vice president.

From the press, from the churches, from many private organizations and individuals the reaction to the report of the National Commission on Civil Disorders has been overwhelmingly favorable. The report spoke to the conscience of white Americans on the failings of a racist society, and there are many signs that they are freshly aware of those failings.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., March 20 (AP)--The New York State Bridge Authority announced today the election of Benjamin Slutsky of Ellenville as the authority chairman. Mr. Slutsky replaces the late Dr. John Edwards of Hudson, who headed the authority for eight years until his death March 6. Mr. Slutsky had been vice chairman for the same period.

The Exposition Rotunda of Madison Square Garden Center will be opened today by Deputy Mayor Robert W. Sweet, Preston Robert Tisch, chairman of the New York Visitors and Convention Bureau, and Irving Mitchell Felt, chairman and president of Madison Square Garden Center, Inc. The ceremonies will precede the noon opening of Autorama-Cyclerama, an exhibition of 150 rare vehicles, including custom, antique and classic cars, motorcycles and hot rods. The exhibition continues through Sunday.

Special to The New York Times MOSCOW, March 20--Prof. Yevsei G. Liberman, the Kharkov University exponent of economic reform, called today for a scrapping of the "full capacity" theory that is basic to much of Soviet planning and management.

The Rangers announced yesterday that playoff tickets would go on sale Monday at Madison Square Garden at 10 A. M. They will be sold on a first-come, first-served basis in strips of four games, with each purchaser allowed only two sets.

Special to The New York Times MOSCOW, March 20 -- Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the Soviet poet, was reprimanded today by a literary critic for a recent poem in which he compared himself to an Alaskan blue fox "born in captivity" but unwilling to flee his cage.

LONDON, March 20 (AP) -- An onslaught from left-wingers, trade unions and industry endangered Prime Minister Wilson's Government and its austerity program today despite a sharp rise on the London stock market.
Colt Industries, Inc., makers of machinery, industrial equipment, firearms and sporting goods, last year increased net earnings to $12,016,004 from $7,928,909 in 1966, the report disclosed yesterday.

PRAGUE, March 20 (UPI)-Maj. Gen. Josef Cepicky of the Czechoslovak Army said tonight that General Sejna "could divulge only incomplete information on Warsaw Pact military affairs if he had any knowledge in this respect at all."

The four-hour stoppage that shut down ports from Maine to Virginia yesterday was a characteristically brazen abuse of power by the International Longshoremen's Association. It supplemented the threeday paralysis of the Port of New York, which has now been halted by a court order.

Special to The New York Times BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 20 --Kurds and Iraqi leaders are dissatisfied with their 20month-old compromise peace, but neither the restless Kurds of the northern provinces nor the Iraqi Government can see any advantage in resuming the fighting that halted in July, 1966.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI)--Because of a lack of money, unemployment checks for former Federal Government employes and former G.I's have been delayed, officials said today.

Stephanie Sills, who became an Off Broadway producer with "America Hurrah," now in its second year, is planning to make her Broadway debut with "Lovers and Other Strangers" in September. Renee Taylor and her husband, Joseph Bologna, wrote the comedy. Charles Grodin will direct it.

Members of an experimental Community Patrol Corps took to the streets of Harlem yesterday and within a few hours they had broken up a fight between two teen-aged girls and prevented a possible stabbing.

A labor-relations professor at Cornell University has been named coordinating director of the Institute of Collective Bargaining and Group Relations here. The appointment of Dr. Matthew A. Kelly was announced yesterday by Cornell and the American Foundation on Automation and Employment, which formed the institute.
The decline in platinum and silver futures prices continued yesterday, but the rate slowed substantially.
An increase in Long Island Rail Road fares, effective tomorrow, was "reluctantly" authorized yesterday by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

PRAGUE, March 20 (AP) -Gen. Jan Sejna, the Czechoslovak political officer who defected to the United States, carried with him an "encyclopedic knowledge" of Sovietbloc military affairs, a Czechoslovak staff officer acknowledged today.

Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan yesterday appointed Ronald R. Evans, a teacher in city schools for seven years, as acting principal of the controversial Intermediate School 201 in East Harlem.
Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, March 20--The House Interior Committee closed its doors to the public today as it began final consideration of the $1.3-billion central Arizona water bill.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 20 (UPI) -- Wise Exchange charged from eighth place in the stretch today and won the $20,000 added Fountain of Youth Stakes by three-quarters of a length at Gulfstream Park.
WASHINGTON, March 20--Howard University, a predominantly Negro institution, was closed today after several hundred students took control of the administration building and refused to leave.
The stock market dawdled in quiet, indecisive trading yesterday before tipping slightly downward late in the session.

Allison Danzig, who retired last month after 45 years as a New York Times sports writer, will be honored by Madison Square Garden and the United States Lawn Tennis Association. Danzig will be introduced to the Garden crowd on March 29 during the semi-final round of the Garden's Challenge Trophy tennis tournament.
The nation's electrical power production rose 7.1 per cent in the week ended March 16 from the level in the corresponding 1967 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.
Andrew S. Roscoe, chairman and president of the Equitable Federal Savings Loan Association, was named yesterday as chairman of the New York Small Business Advisory Council.

Special to The New York Times YONKERS, March 20-Three horses, one from each division of the Adios Pacing Festival eliminations to be staged tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway, were withdrawn today. Vicar Hanover from the Adios Butler, Sun Lord from the Adios Harry and Robin Dundee from the Adios Boy were scratched.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, March 20--United States officials refused to comment officially today on President de Gaulle's statement. Privately, they said the statement merely showed that the French President had not changed his mind. They would have been surprised had he said anything else, they added.

Robert V. Roosa, former under secretary of the Treasury for monetary affairs, suggested yesterday that the British Government might attempt to float a massive, long-term loan in the international money market to help rehabilitate the pound.

WASHINGTON, March 20-Senator Eugene McCarthy may be the biggest thing that has happened to American youth since marijuana. In New Hampshire, as we all know, they flocked to his standard from campuses all over the country, did some real work--many of them for the first time in their lives, perhaps--and even consented to wash and cut their hair to help the cause.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI)--Gov. John J. McKeithen of Louisiana, expressed fear today that Senator Robert F. Kennedy's decision to challenge President Johnson might result in the breakup of the Democratic party.
Special to The New York Times BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 20 --Marshal Andrei A. Grechko, the Soviet Defense Minister, arrived in Baghdad today for five-days visit.

ST. LOUIS, March 20 (AP)--The assets and business of the Peabody Coal Company of St. Louis will be purchased by the Kennecott Copper Corporation on March 29, it was announced today by both companies. A Kennecott official said Peabody would become a wholly owned subsidiary, retaining its name and management.
Americus Liberator, 57, a former Nebraska cowboy, is seeking Republican Presidential nomination in his state's primary on May 14.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI)--The House passed today and sent to the Senate authority for the Government to set controls over builders of color television sets and other devices that might give off harmful doses of radiation.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 20 (UPI)--What started as a discussion of a simple resolution supporting President Johnson and the United States war effort in Vietnam turned into a mass oratorical attack on Senator Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)--A Philadelphia judge and two businessmen were indicted today on conspiracy and mail fraud charges in an alleged scheme involving possibly $1-million in worthless checks and money orders, the Justice Department said.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 20 (AP)--Secretary Freeman said today that the "long knives" of opponents were out to cut up the Administration's multi-billion-dollar farm aid programs.
Andreas Papandreou, former Greek Cabinet Minister who is in exile, presented yesterday a 25-year-old Greek who he said had left his job as a security officer of the ruling junta and defected.

Completion of the draft nonproliferation treaty at the seventeen-nation Geneva disarmament conference and its transmittal to the United Nations now virtually assures acceptance of the long-sought worldwide pact to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.

A 17-year-old girl suspected of having contagious spinal meningitis, a disease that is often fatal if not treated, returned to Beth Israel Hospital for tests yesterday after having been sought by the police and health authorities.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI)--Treasury officials, ignoring Congressional pressure, have ruled that industrial revenue bonds will not be tax-exempt.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, March 20-House Republican leaders, under heavy pressure from liberals and moderates within their own ranks, edged a step closer today toward acceptance of the Senate's civil rights bill.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 97.0 on Tuesday from 96.9 on Monday.
The House of Fragrance, a division of Genesco, Inc., is in the process of being sold to the Sterling Drug Company, where it will be absorbed into the Lehn Fink Products division.

In the tiny lofts on 46th and 47th Streets, behind the thick locked doors with the peep-holes that permit cautious inspection of anyone, seeking entry, the men who make gold jewelry lace a new, puzzling, financially hazardous problem.

Special to The New York Times WARSAW, March 20 -- Students in Cracow pointedly ignored today an appeal by the Communist leader, Wladyslaw Gomulka, for an immediate return to classes. They staged a sit-in at Jagiellonian University.

The Metropolitan Opera Club will hold its annual "Ball in the Opera House" on March 30 after a performance of Verdi's "Un Ballo in Maschera." Proceeds from the evening will be turned over to the Metropolitan Opera Association.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Representative H. R. Gross, Republican of Iowa, told the House today that the use of a special Air Force plane to fly Vice President Humphrey's tuxedo to Scranton, Pa., did not jibe with the Johnson Administration's plea for austerity.

Special to The New York Times ALBANY, March 20--Governor Rockefeller is preparing amendments to his recent $6-billion-plus urban development plan, but they fall far short of meeting Mayor Lindsay's sharp objections about the plan's "invasion" of localities' home rule rights.

Four armed men, wearing stocking masks, white butcher aprons and white gloves, held up the Finast Suermarket at 694 Burke Avenue, the Bronx, at 8 A.M. yesterday and escaped with $5,000 after forcing the manager to open the safe.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI)--President Johnson said tonight that a "quick peace, an easy peace" in Vietnam was not necessarily a just and honorable peace.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 20 (UPI)--Gay Brewer, who tore this course apart last year with 26-under-par golf, sets out tomorrow to become the first pro to win the same tournament three years in a row since Arnold Palmer did it five years ago at Phoenix.

Thirteen hundred critically ill patients who should not be moved were transferred last year from other hospitals to Bellevue and Kings County Hospitals, the State Investigation Commission was told yesterday.
The election of John T. Burns as president of the Vickers division of the Sperry Rand Corporation was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Postmaster General Lawrence F. O'Brien said today that he had no plans to resign from President Johnson's Cabinet to direct the Presidential campaign of Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

The management of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation was castigated by a stockholder at the annual meeting here yesterday for the high salaries its members receive even though the company is in liquidation.

Special to The New York Times ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20--The hungriest baseball player in Florida this spring is Ed Charles or the New York Mets. He is 35 years old and has been a professional ballplayer half his life. He has a family and a new house in Kansas City--but no contract.
CHICAGO, March 20 (UPI)--Agriculture Secretary Orville L. Freeman announced today that milk price supports would be set at 90 per cent of parity for the marketing year starting April 1.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 20 (UPI)--The recently appointed director of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Department of Arkansas led a raid tonight on the Top of the Rock Club in the Tower Buliding here.

Special to The New York Times UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 20--The Government of the United Arab Republic declared today that it was ready to implement the Security Council resolution intended to promote a durable peace in the Middle East.
The City Planning Commission approved yesterday the construction of a large apartment development, a high school and a small park on the site of the old Ruppert Brewery in Yorkville.

In California, several of the nation's largest savings associations, which earlier in the year had been reported to be cutting their interest rates on home mortgages, said yesterday they were now increasing their loan charges. Where 6 3/4 per cent had been reported as the minimum rate in some California cities, it was said, 6.9 per cent was now the lowest charge being quoted.
LONG BEACH, Calif., March 20 (AP)--Governor Rockefeller of New York is the strongest Presidential candidate the Republicans could nominate in California, the Opinion Research Poll reported today.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., March 20 -- The all-Republican City Council here appointed Theodore W. Maurer of Poughkeepsie as city manager his salary will be $26,000 a year.
JERUSALEM, Thursday, March 21--An Israeli Army spokesman announced today that armed forces had crossed the Jordan River during the night to attack terrorist bases in Jordan.

Special to The New York Times BOSTON, March 20--A group of Negro businessmen, headed by Thomas E. Sanders, a forward on the Boston Celtics basketball team, received a Federal commitment of nearly $1-million today to undertake a housing rehabilitation project.

Special to The New York Times TOKYO, March 20--How are you going to keep them down on the farm after they've seen Tokyo? Or Osaka or Nagoya or Nagasaki or any of Japan's throbbing, brightly lighted cities?
SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 20 (UPI) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, in a filmed address, said today that the ideal Presidential candidate had "unimpeachable integrity."
Special to The New York Times SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 21--Enemy troops shelled the Tansonnhut Air Base on the edge of Saigon early this morning.

LANSING, Mich., March 20 (UPI)--With Gov. George Romney out of the Presidential race, 19 of Michigan's 20 Republican State Senators have thrown their support to former Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
Special to The New York Times MADRID, March 20--The Spanish-British talks on Gibraltar this week ended with no progress.

This fall and again in 1970, New Yorkers will choose their Congressmen on the basis of district lines that are somewhat better than those used in the last three elections, but still far short of what they should be. That is the net result of yesterday's decision by a three-judge Federal court.
A Broadway play will give a special performance Sunday night for the Actors Fund of America. After deductions the 85-year-old charity is expected to be $4,000 to the good.

The New York McCarthy for President headquarters reported yesterday that it had received $30,000 in campaign contributions on Tuesday, the highest total yet for a single day. A spokesman said that 3,500 letters of support had also been received the same day.

MONACO, March 20 (UPI)-Jacques-Yves Cousteau, the oceanographer, has announced plans for a three-year research program in the Mediterranean Sea. Twenty nations will sponsor the ocean exploration under the auspices of several United Nations agencies.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, March 20--Government officials said tonight that technical studies have been done recently within the Government on the impact of a withdrawal of Chinese Nationalist troops from the islands of Quemoy and Matsu, off Communist China.

WASHINGTON, March 20-American politics is showing itself this year to be something new and different. The underlying realities of human nature that govern our politics, and all others, are the same, but they are being appealed to, exploited and controlled in different ways.

AMMAN, Jordan, Thursday, March 21 (Reuters) -- Israeli forces lost four tanks in a battle after they crossed the cease-fire line into Jordanian territory this morning, a Jordanian military spokesman said.

The head of the nation's largest bank specializing in "wholesale banking" for major corporations said yesterday that the question of an increase in the prime or minimum interest rate on business loans is "on the back burner" at the moment.

Willie Sutton -- whose bank robberies and jailbreaks had made him a legendary figure to an earlier generation -- began a legal action yesterday in the Queens courts that he hoped would get him out of jail and keep him out.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 20--Former President Harry S. Truman, showing flashes of his famous "give 'em hell Harry" campaign form, came out strongly in favor of President Johnson today and predicted he would easily win re election this fall.

A three-day work stoppage by longshoremen, which has cost the New York port's economy about $3-million a day, will be ended today as a result of a stay order issued late yesterday afternoon in State Supreme Court.
Interest rates on high-grade utility and railroad securities moved up yesterday, reaching the highest levels since the bond market established a peak in yields three months ago.
Nicolai Gedda sang his first Nemorino of the season in Donizetti's "L'Elisir d'Amore" at the Metropolitan Opera last night, and from a vocal standpoint he was as steady and reliable as ever.

MEXICO CITY, March 20 (AP) -- Mickey Mantle's first home run of the spring started the New York Yankees to a 9-1 exhibition baseball victory tonight over the Mexico City Red Devils of the Mexican League.
St. Peter's suffered its first setback in the National Invitation Tournament yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 20 (UPI)--The proposed nontitle fight between the world bantamweight champion, Lionel Rose of Australia, and the Italian European champion, Salvatore Burruni, on April 5, has been postponed until April 19, officials said today.
A computer that detects its own malfunctions and repairs itself is expected to go into experimental operation this fall at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory at Pasadena, Calif.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., March 20 (UPI) -- The United Automobile Workers went on strike today at the Kelvinator appliance division of the American Motors Corporation. It appeared that the walkout would have no immediate effect on car production of the nation's smallest major auto producer.
Special to The New York Times CAIRO, March 20--The Government confirmed today that Vice Premier Zakariya Mohieddine, the principal rightist figure in the regime, had resigned.

Joe Namath, the New York Jets' quarterback, underwent surgery yesterday at the Hospital For Special Surgery to repair a torn tendon below his left kneecap. It was the third operation for Namath, the first of the left knee.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 20 (Reuters) -- The opposition leader, Oginga Odinga, was prevented from flying to London tonight on his way to the United States. His passport was withheld by the authorities. He was to deliver a lecture on revolution as it affects newly independent African states at Boston University.
A trucking operator, whose body was found in the trunk of his car in a Brooklyn parking lot Tuesday night, was described yesterday by law-enforcement officials as a police informant.

Special to The New York Times ALBANY, March 20--President Johnson's campaign to defeat Senator Robert F. Kennedy in New York opened unofficially today with a sharply worded telegram from the President's chief political agent in the state to the 62 county chairmen.
Trading continued light on the American Stock Exchange yesterday and prices turned mixed.

Governor Rockefeller, in what appeared to be an attack on President Johnson, deplored yesterday the fact that the report of the President's Commission on Civil Disorders had been greeted with "a strange silence" in some quarters.

E. Foley Vaughan of the Yale Club, the top-seeded player, won the Metropolitan Class C squash racquets championship yesterday by defeating Al Copeland of the University Club, 15-8, 17-16, 15-9, at the Yale Club.
Repertory programs for two visitng foreign troupes at the Lincoln Center Festival '68 were announced yesterday by Schuyler Chapin, the center's programing vice president.
Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, March 20--An experimental vaccine against rubella, sometimes called German measles, may soon get its first test against an epidemic.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI)--Airman 1st Cl. Patrick J. Nugent, son-in-law of President Johnson, reported for active duty today with the 113th Tactical Fighter Wing at nearby Andrews Air Force Base.

SKULL VALLEY, Utah, March 20 (AP) -- A toxicologist from the National Animal Disease Center at Ames, Iowa, arrived in Utah today to help other scientists seeking to find what is killing thousands of sheep in western Utah's semidesert Skull Valley.

Special to The New York Times ROME, March 20--The Roman Catholic Church and the World Council of Churches, which represents most of the rest of Christianity, issued a common statement today appealing for peace and "honorable negotiations" in the civil war in Nigeria.

MONTREAL, March 20 (UPI) --Bobby Rousseau scored his 14th and 15th goals of the season tonight and led the Montreal Canadiens to a 3-2 victory over Toronto, eliminating the Maple Leafs from the National Hockey League playoffs.

QUANTICO, Va., March 20 (AP) -- Searchers found today four more bodies of enlisted men who drowned in the Potomac River when their canoe upset during a canoeing physical training exercise March 6. This leaves three still missing.
HOLLYWOOD, March 20 (UPI)--Charles Chaplin Jr., 42year-old son of the comedian, collapsed and died today in his grandmother's home.
HUBLI, India, March 20 (Reuters)--The death toll from a collision between a speeding express and a stationary train Monday night rose to 52 tonight as rescue workers cut through the wreckage.

A middle-aged woman, clutching a large black purse tightly to her bosom, tiptoed nervously into a stock broker's office in mid-Manhattan the other day and timidly inquired if she could see the manager.
The demand for protection from electronic eavesdropping by both governmental agencies and private individuals has led to a boom in the bugging business, a surveillance specialist said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)--The Senate Interior Committee approved today a bill to control Lake Michigan's alewives-a fish that has died by the millions in recent summers, clogging beaches and causing an objectionable odor. It would provide $5-million in Federal funds, to be matched by contributions from interested Great Lakes states, to develop longrange alewife control programs.
BOSTON, March 20 (AP) --That man you'll see standing behind home plate during the American League baseball season in blue blazer and gray slacks belongs in the ball park.
Special to The New York Times GUATEMALA, March 20 -The Most Rev. Mario Casariego, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Guatamala, was released unharmed today by a group that had kidnapped him last Saturday.
Special to The New York Times BONN, March 20--A West German actor who once played an East German villain in an American movie has migrated to East Germany.

The 106th General Hospital at Kishine Barracks in Japan is receiving an increasing number of wounded from Vietnam. Their conditions are so serious that they cannot be evacuated to the United States. The military issues invitations to the next of kin to visit these men, and it is the Red Cross who meets the families and prepares them for what they will encounter, as well as lending all possible support during the visit.

Special to The New York Times MINNEAPOLIS, March 20-The National Farmers Union convention, which ended here tonight, provided a stark look into the Johnson Administration's election-year troubles in the Farm Belt.

Special to The New York Times EVANSTON, Ill., March 20 --Three major United States railroad presidents predicted today that their lines' income picture would improve in 1968 despite a variety of obstacles, including labor costs and equipment replacements.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, March 20-Senator Thruston B. Morton, who is expected to manage Governor Rockefeller's Presidential campaign, said today he would strongly urge the New York Governor to challenge Richard M. Nixon in the Nebraska primary.

Special to The New York Times DETROIT, March 20--Michigan's Supreme Court, one of the few courts in the nation with an even number of justices, will be constitutionally reduced at the end of the present session from eight to seven members for the first time since 1905.
THE Spring Nationals at the Americana hotel here last week proved attractive to a number of experienced players who normally prefer the rubber bridge table to the duplicate game.
Mrs. Lillian Brennan, retiring after a 40-year career with The Jockey Club, will be honored by that supervisory group at a dinner at Toots Shor's Restaurant on March 29.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had dropped its plan to acquire the Cerro Corporation because of opposition from the Justice Department.

Special to The New York Times UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 20 -- Sweden, Denmark, Finland, Norway and Austria reported to the United Nations today on practical steps they had taken to provide peace-keeping forces to the United Nations on short notice.

Special to The New York Times ATLANTIC CITY, March 20 --The United Steelworkers of America, facing critical contract negotiations in the basic steel and aluminum industries, decided today to levy a special dues assessment to build a $25million strike and defense fund.
BOSTON, March 20 (AP)--The Detroit Pistons gained the final playoff spot in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division tonight by defeating the Boston Celtics, 125-116.

The Chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, Rabbi Herschel Shacter, said yesterday that the Jewish community of Poland was too small to have caused the wave of unrest gripping that country.

Bronx won the senior championship and Queens the junior title in the finals of the Columbia Broadcasting System-Parks Department playground basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden yesterday. Six hundred teams with 7,000 players participated.

The Southern Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday operating revenues of $531, 945,004 for 12 months ended Feb. 29. This compared with $492,306,725 a year earlier. Net income rose to $75,255,560, equal to $1.59 a share, from $69,709,944, or $1.47, a share, on fewer shares, in the like 1967 period. The Southern Company is a utility holding company with operating subsidiaries providing electricity in parts of Alabama, Florida, Georgia and Mississippi.
Today's young marketing men, be they account guys at the agency or brand managers at the client, are a well-educated group -- ambitious and impatient. They are out for the big jobs and the big money.

Special to The New York Times GENEVA, March 20--An outstanding feature of the industrial growth recorded by the Communist countries of Eastern Europe last year was a large expansion in the output of consumer goods, according to the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Service says Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, owes $15, 547.59 for 1963 income taxes resulting from a dispute over charitable deductions, United States Tax Court papers showed today. Mr. Brundage filed suit against the tax agency, rebutting the accusation.

DETROIT, March 20 (AP)--The Detroit police, who staged a "sick call" strike last summer for higher pay, were rewarded today with the nation's highest pay scale for policemen--a maximum of $10,300 a year--effective July 1.

Giovanni Martinelli, looking like a Roman proconsul with his shaggy white head, described the event as "historic." It was the first time, he joked, that one Italian tenor (himself) had introduced another. The other, who subsequently stepped out on Carnegie Hall's stage in his first New York concert, was Franco Corelli, smiling that inimitable pearly smile and looking like Dean Martin 30 pounds ago.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 20 (UPI)--Flynn Robinson scored 29 points to lead the Chicago Bulls to a 121-112 victory tonight over the San Diego Rockets in the closing game of the National Basketball Association season.

Gordon Anderson of Central High School in Ontario defeated Craig Benson of Lawrence Park School, also in Ontario, in the final of the Racquet Tennis Club's interscholastic squash racquet invitation tournament yesterday. The scores were 15-12, 15-11, 6-15, 17-15.

The city's Air Pollution Control Department, responding to what it calls a "great clamor" for the resumption of an air pollution index, has all but decided not to issue a single index, but instead, separate readings for each of the major pollutants.

Special to The New York Times BONN, March 20--West Germany's modest space program reached a milestone today as scientists ignited the third stage of a European satellite launcher in a successful ground test at Lampoldshausen, near Heilbronn.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (Reuters) -- Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Roy Jenkins, will visit Washington next month for talks with Treasury Secretary Henry Fowler, it was announced here today. The Treasury Department said the two officials would meet April 4 and 5.
CINCINNATI, March 20 (AP) --Ted Bakatselos and Don Wray of Detroit rolled a 1,296 series today and took first place in the regular doubles division of the American Bowling Congress tournament.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, March 20-The United States was reliably reported today to have agreed to revive previously canceled plans to provide Jordan with high-performance F-104 jet fighters as part of a new arms agreement.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., March 20 (UPI)--Andre Boudrias' fivefoot tip-in with just 58 seconds remaining earned the Minnesota North Stars a 3-3 tie with the Los Angeles Kings tonight in a Western Division National Hockey League match.

A legal clash involving the rights of the press and the right of an individual to privacy has resulted in the award of $20,000 to a salesman by a Federal Court jury in a suit against The National Enquirer.
ST. JOHN'S, Antigua, March 20 (UPI)--Rival labor groups that have been engaged in a bitter power struggle on this Caribbean resort island announced settlement of their political differences today.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- About 250,000 hotel rooms across the United States are being offered to foreign visitors at rates 10 to 50 per cent below normal, the Presidential commission on travel announced today.
A Brooklyn woman who was married 10 days ago was one of four $l00,000 winners selected yesterday in the monthly drawing of the New York State lottery.

Special to The New York Times BELOIT, Wis., March 20-Senator Eugene J. McCarthy campaigned in southeastern Wisconsin today before enthusiastic crowds of college students, but there were small signs that he was beginning to lose support to Senator Robert F. Kennedy in other states.

Special to The New York Times VENICE, Italy, March 16 -- Venice, slowly sinking into the Adriatic Sea it once ruled, will seek advice from the Dutch, the world's greatest experts on living below sea level, on how to keep one of the most beautiful cities on earth going for the next thousand years or two.
About 45 antipoverty projects in four boroughs have been notified that they are being cut off from Government funds as of March 31 because of Federal cutbacks.

LAGOS, Nigeria, March 20 (AP)--Federal troops have encircled the Niger River port of Onitsha, the second largest city in the secessionist Eastern Region, and have launched a sea invasion to clear the shipping channel to Calabar, reliable sources reported today.

Special to The New York Times MOSCOW, March 20--Visit by a Czechoslovak general and Deputy Premier in charge of economic planning were interpreted here today by Western observers as missions to assure Moscow that a wave of liberal changes in Prague would not disrupt Czechoslovak military and economic cooperation with the Soviet bloc.
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose by 529,140 shares in the month ended March 15 from the total reported a month ago, the exchange announced yesterday.

Joe Garagiola and Red Barber, never harmonious when colleagues on the New York Yankees' broadcasting crew, will not have a reunion on television next Tuesday as originally planned by the National Broadcasting Company.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, March 20 --Gen. David M. Shoup, former Marine commandant, estimated today in a renewed attack on the Administration's Vietnam policy that up to 800,000 American troops would be required just to defend South Vietnamese population centers against Communist attack.

WICHITA, Kan., March 20 (UPI) -- Harry B. Brown Jr., vice president and secretary of the Wichita Eagle and the Beacon Publishing Company, Inc., was convicted yesterday on six counts of Federal income tax violation. The Federal District Court jury deliberated five hours.
PITTSBURGH, March 20 (UPI) --Wayne Hicks scored a goal and set up another to pace the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 4-2 victory, over the St. Louis Blues tonight.
BOWIE, Md., March 20 (UPI)--Last Cry led from start to finish and ran away to a sixlength triumph over Doctor Will in his first outing of the year today in the feature $6,500 allowance race at Bowie.
Codorniz, a consistent performer over the last two seasons, enabled Bobby Ussery to ride his first stakes winner of the local season at Aqueduct yesterday.

MADRID, March 20 (Reuters) --A court today sentenced nine men found guilty of setting up a Communist cell in a Madrid suburb to prison terms ranging from one to 13 years. The leader, Luis Perez, received the longest sentence.

Special to The New York Times BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, March 20--In one of the incongruous encounters that have taken place in the last turbulent weeks, Gen. Bohumir Lomsky, the widely disliked Minister of Defense, was confronted by a private in the anteroom of Alexander Dubcek, the new Communist party leader.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the three and 12 months ended Feb. 29.

Special to The New York Times HARRISBURG, Pa., March 20 -- Gov. Raymond P. Shafer named two Republicans and one Democrat today as the members of Pennsylvania's first Horse Racing Commission. The body was created by the Legislature last December to legalize thoroughbred racing with pari-mutuel betting at four tracks.
TOKYO, March 20 (AP)-North Korea's Olympic Committee said today it would not compete in the Olympics in Mexico City unless the International Committee bans South Africa from the Olympics.

BALTIMORE, March 20 (AP) --Led by Wally Jones and Chet Walker, the Philadelphia 76ers scored 42 points in the third period and whipped the Baltimore Bullets, 137-119, in a regular-season final game of the National Basketball Association tonight.
Mrs. Richard J. Hughes, wife of New Jersey's Governor, will be the co-hostess of "The Mike Douglas Show" on Channel 2 next week. The program is seen weekdays from 4:30 to 6 P. M.

Special to The New York Times CHICAGO, March 20 -- Despite the frenzied, almost warlike screaming of 18,000 fans in Chicago Stadium tonight, the Rangers scored a 5-3 victory over the Black Hawks, took complete possession of second place and guaranteed themselves a playoff berth for the second consecutive season.

The purchase price quoted for gold was lowered by $1.25 an ounce, to $38.25 an ounce, by the Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation yesterday. Last Tuesday, the important refiner of precious metals began posting a daily price at which it can obtain "sufficient supplies" of gold from producers, who no longer are required to turn in their metal to the Treasury.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 20 (AP)--Doctors reported today that Gov. Lurleen B. Wallace apparently still had traces of an abdominal infection for which she underwent surgery eight days ago. They said Mrs. Wallace, 41 years old, still had a low-grade fever, "indicating that some abdominal infection remains."

Special to The New York Times SAN FRANCISCO, March 20 --Richard M. Nixon maintained and extended his lead among California Republicans in The California Poll released today by Mervin D. Field, its owner.
Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan announced yesterday that he would seek the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate as a peace candidate.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, March 20--Senator Robert F. Kennedy charged today that President Johnson's housing legislation was riddled with defects and urged Congressional consideration of his own plan, which includes tax incentives to private builders.

The American Children's Theater will offer the American Ballet Theater in the production of "Peter and the Wolf," starring Cyril Ritchard as narrator, in a week of matinees of the Beacon Theater, Broadway at 74th Street starting April 13.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)--The following men from the New York area were identified by the Defense Department today as having been killed in Vietnam:
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)--The Federal Government announced today a $10-million program designed to attack starvation and malnutrition among the nation's poor.
LIMA, Peru, March 20 (Reuters) --Brig. Gen. Francisco Morales Bermudez today became Finance Minister and the fifth military man in President Fernando Belaunde Terry's Cabinet.

Special to The New York Times PARIS, March 20--President de Gaulle declared today that France "reserved her liberty of action" with respect to all current attempts at keeping the present monetary system of reserve currencies alive and staying off basic changes.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -Adam Clayton Powell will return to Washington for the first time since he was excludued from his seat in the House when he stops over here next month on a series of lectures.
OKLAHOMA CITY, March 20 (AP)--The State Senate approved today, 45 to 0, a resolution supporting the war in Vietnam.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, March 20 -- New orders received by durable goods manufacturers rose somewhat in February following a sharp drop the month before, but failed by a significant margin to regain their December level.

FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla., March 20 (AP)--Two pilots from Elgin Air Force base were killed when their F-4 Phantom 2 attack bomber crashed on a test range 25 miles northeast of here on a test mission last night. The victims were Maj. Charles M. Dray, 36 years old, of Tampa, commander of the aircraft, and First Lieut. Charles V. Townsend of Guthrie, Okla.

Special to The New York Times BETHLEHEM, Conn.--"I didn't start cooking, really, until quite late in life," Mrs. Victor Allan, who is still not "quite late in life," said. "But the kitchen is a wonderful place to escape work, don't you think?"

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 20 (Reuters)--A hawk at the Saigon Zoo which was wounded inthe throat by a bullet during the Lunan New Year offensive has made a complete recovery. Vu Ngoc Tan, the zoo's director, said today.
Mayor Lindsay bent down and lifted a discarded easy chair into a new white sanitation truck in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn yesterday.
-- The Lukens Steel Company announced yesterday in Coatesville, Pa., the election of Hal A. Kroeger as a director. Mr. Kroeger is co-founder of the A. H. Kroeger Organization, industrial consultants.
Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, a sponsor of several self-help projects for Negroes in New York and Los Angeles, was accused yesterday of failing to file Federal income tax returns for 1961, 1962, and 1963.
OTTAWA, March 20 (Canadian Press)--The Government today offered $175-million or new bonds in two issues at prices giving investors 7.03 and 7.3 per cent on their money.

Special to The New York Times WHITE PLAINS, March 20--Reversing an earlier endorsement of President Johnson for re-election, executive committeemen of the Westchester County Democratic Committee, voted tonight in favor of Senator Robert F. Kennedy for their party's Presidential nomination.

Merger discussions are being held between the Occidental Petroleum Corporation and the Hooker Chemical Corporation, both companies disclosed yesterday. Terms have not yet been reached but the transaction could run into $400-million.
Governor Rockefeller's news conference, scheduled for 2 P.M. today at the New York Hilton Hotel, will be carried live on television and radio.

BOSTON, March 20 (UPI) --F. Lee Bailey, counsel for the National Association of Harness Drivers, said today that drivers in New York State would boycott tracks if a bill in the Legislature was passed in its present form.

John J. Cummings Jr. was elected president yesterday of the Industrial National Bank of Rhode Island. Formerly executive vice president, Mr. Cummings succeeds John Simmen, who was named chairman of the board of directors and the executive committee. Mr. Simmen continues as chief executive officer.
The Alleghany Corporation, the holding company, announced yesterday that its net assets per common share stood at $15.61 on Dec. 31, 1967, up from $12.34 a year earlier

Associate Justice Hugo L. Black of the United States Supreme Court defended here last night his recent judicial opinions and said that he had not changed his basic constitutional philosophy.

SALEM, Ore., March 20 (UPI) --Harold E. Stassen has failed to get the 1,000 signatures necessary to qualify for the state's Republican Presidential primary of May 28. He had announced plans to qualify by petition after the Secretary of State declined to put him on the ballot.
The Citizens for Democratic Congressmen Against Johnson announced yesterday that it had endorsed a number of Democartic candidates for Congress.

Channel 11 will televise three half-hour programs with stars of the Grand Music Hall of Israel, which ends its run at the Palace Theater on March 31. The programs will be carried on April 7, 8 and 9 at 10:30 P.M. The hosts will be Geula Gill, Mimi Benzell and Jan Peerce.

Glore Forgan, Wm. R. Staats, Inc., a member of the New York Stock Exchange, has elected James H. Lynch Jr., 37 years old, vice president and secretary and Arnold N. Spur, 33, vice president in charge of New York institutional sales.

PENN STATE is the only Eastern team to have won the National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling team title. The Nittany Lions did it in 1953 when the championships were held on their campus.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)--President Johnson, describing the threat to the dollar as "immediate and serious," appealed again to Congress today for prompt passage of a 10 per cent income tax surcharge.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 20 (AP)--Half of the schools in the Saigon area are back in operation after being closed by the Vietcong's offensive against cities a month and a half ago, United States officials said today. They said all schools in the area would resume operations no later than April 1.

William Wolfe, director of international marketing, was named president of Hamilton International. Henry Huguenin, director of Swiss operations, was appointed managing director of Vantage International.
Patches of fog extended along the Atlantic coastline from Boston to northern Maryland yesterday, slowing highway traffic in some places and interrupting a number of airline schedules.

A 104-room hotel and convention hall will be erected in Commack, L. I., by Rowes Properties of Suffolk, Inc., headed by Vincent Powell. Construction costs are estimated at $5-million.

There was nothing much new, nothing much original, very little that was interesting.

One of several thousand black combat veterans now returning to the urban ghetto, Cato doesn't see anything extraordinary in what he did.

AMERICAN serial music, academic branch, subdivision Chicago, took over at the New Image of Sound concerts on Friday at Hunter College. But "new image" was a misnomer in this case. Nearly all the music was an unlovely, determined exegesis of the theories that have been held dear by the serialists for the last 10 years. There was nothing much new, nothing much original, very little that was interesting.
