AMMAN, Jordan, March 24 -- The eastern side of the Jordan Valley, across the river from Israeli guns and patrols, is becoming a no man's land. A wave of departures has followed strikes aimed, according to Israeli statements, against the fedayeen, or commandos, resisting Israeli occupation of the west bank.
" The Continuing Avant-Garde" is the name of a new contemporary music series. The first of four concerts to be given this year was heard last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

Like many of today's important and "difficult" elder avant-garde composers, Stefan Wolpe is better known through his choice of teachers (Busoni, Webern and Scherchen) and his position as an influential instructor than through actual performances of his music. This omission has been rectified somewhat of late.
NEW CITY, N. Y., March 24 -- Growth, spectacular and disrupting, is stamped over most of the muddy face of Rockland County.
THE 1968 edition of the Passover Directory lists nearly 800 certified kosherfor-Passover products including a large number of convenience foods that are available for the first time this year.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -Basic agreements have been reached covering the entire copper portion of the dispute in the metals industry, company spokesmen announced today.

Harvard University will put a four-story building under Harvard Yard. The University of Chicago is covering up Stagg Field with an $18-million building. Princeton also will be tearing up its campus. All to store books.

The Association of Producing Artists (A.P.A.)-Phoenix, which yesterday attacked the League of New York Theaters for having been excluded as a candidate in the 16 categories for Tony awards, will receive a special citation for its contribution at the ceremonies scheduled for April 21.
Service companies are expanding their operations on Wall Street as part of the battle to control the growing volume of paperwork in brokerage house back offices.

BOSTON, March 24 (UPI) -- The Boston Celtics fought off a late rally by the Detroit Pistons today to score a 123-116 victory in the opener of their National Basketball Association playoffs series. The Eastern Division teams meet again in Detroit tomorrow night in the second game of the four-of-seven series.

An examination of star photographs dating back to 1897 has indicated that the star British astronomers believe may be the source of recently discovered radio pulses is probably more than 100 light years away. This would mean that the radio emissions themselves take more than 100 years to reach the earth.

" Ya-we-ya-hi-ya." With this chant, the beating of a drum, the shuffling and stomping of moccasined feet and the shrill jangling of bells, the auditorium of the McBurney Y.M.C.A. was transformed into an American Indian Powwow last weekend.

The American Basketball Association playoffs started in Minnesota yesterday between the Kentucky Colonels and the Minnesota Muskies and the New Jersey Americans were looking in from the outside following a comedy of errors.

The State Public Service Commission is expected to make a final decision in about three weeks on a $32-million-a-year electric rate increase it granted to Consolidated Edison on a tentative basis in November of 1966.
ALBANY, March 24 -- Negotiations among legislative leaders on how to pass Governor Rockefeller's proposed budget of more than $5-billion for fiscal 1968-69 are still inconclusive.

Paul Paray was guest conductor for the American Symphony Orchestra's concert in Cornegie Hall yesterday afternoon. While the program was evenly divided between staple items from the French and German repertories, Mr. Paray's interpretations betrayed a Gallic tendency to prefer sound to structure.

When Dr. Frank W. Notestein headed the Population Division of the United Nations from 1946 to 1948, he remembers, "We walked softly, like a cat on a wet pavement." Population control was politically touchy in the underdeveloped nations where it was most needed, where peasant thought was supposed to hold that the biggest family was the best family.
PITTSBURGH, March 24 (UPI) -- Mike McMahon's 14th goal of the season lifted the Minnesota North Stars into a 4-4 tie with the Pittsburgh Penguins this afternoon.

DANANG, South Vietnam, March 24 (Agence France-Presse) -- Under a new system to be started in a few days, United States Marine pacification teams will move from village to village, spending about two weeks in each one, trying to teach the inhabitants how to defend themselves.

The refusal of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller to wage an active campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination is only the latest surprise in what has become an astonishingly unpredictable political year. Since future political events depend not only on the efforts of the rival personalities but also on the unforeseeable course of the war in Vietnam and of racial tensions in this country, it is not likely to be the last surprise.
BONN, March 24 -- Alexander Dubcek: Communist hero or Communist heretic?

A program in which the city has brought dropout slum youngsters up to high school graduation levels in four to six months is facing a shutdown March 31 because of an inability to get new Federal funds.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., March 23 -- Oklahoma State's Cowboys won the 38th annual National Collegiate wrestling championships tonight in Penn State's Recreation Hall with 81 points. A record crowd of 7,900, including 700 standees, watched as the Cowboys captured their 26th title in the tournament's history.
PRAGUE, March 24 -- The communique issued by the leaders of Eastern Europe after their meeting in Dresden yesterday has made the few Czechoslovaks who know about it uneasy.
Eddy Arnold, the country and pop crooner, filled Carnegie Hall Saturday night with an audience evoking nostalgia for his long and distinguished recording career.
Four years ago the granddaughter of Sholem Aleichem, the Yiddish humorist, wrote a best-selling and often comic account of a young teacher's experiences in a big-city high school.

The State Commission for Human Rights has ordered the seniority board of the New York Shipping Association and the International Longshoremen's Association to grant the top seniority status to a Negro longshoreman who has had a dispute with the board for the last 10 years.
W. Thomas Rice, president and chief executive officer of the Seaboard Coast Line Railroad, is feeling the impact of that slogan one sees in garages and the like around the country:

PANAMA, March 24 -- The 30 Opposition deputies of the National Assembly, meeting as a court of justice, convicted President Marco A. Robles today of violations of the constitution and voted to remove him from office.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -A Federal District Court here will hear testimony tomorrow in a suit trying to force the Agriculture Department to give the poor enough food to keep them alive.
W. Averell Harriman, Ambassador at Large, was named honorary chairman yesterday of the Johnson Committee, the New York group supporting the President's nomination.
SEBRING, Fla., March 24 (AP) -- The Porsches won another major auto race yesterday and their drivers rubbed it in by saying they could have led all the way at a record speed.

A COMBINATION -- often a series of staggering blows before the knockout -- is the heart of chess. And a combination was the climax of the Nimzovich Defense between Yugoslavia's Mato Damjanovic and Grandmaster Nicholas Rossolimo of New York in the recent international at Malaga, Spain.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes said yesterday that he expected to have an electronic traffic control system in operation in Queens before the end of the year.
One of the strongest international fields ever assembled for an indoor amateur tennis tournament will open competition today at Madison Square Garden for the Garden Challenge Trophy.

Disaffection with new shipping rates for Government-sponsored cargoes by American tramp and bulk ship operators has prompted the Maritime Administration to schedule a public hearing within 60 days on these controversial rates.

LINDENHURST, Ill., March 24 -- About 200 antiwar and black power leaders decided today to seek to form a coalition for an election-year organizing drive to strengthen existing peace, draft resistance and community organizations in the slums and to start new ones.
Sensitive, discerning musicianship was the order of the afternoon yesterday at Philharmonic Hall, as Guiomar Novaes gave her only New York recital of the season.

To believe, as your March 14 editorial ["McCarthy's Appeal to Youth"] asserts, that many college students "delivered the most effective response possible to the nihilism and defeatism of their contemporaries of the New Left" is to belittle the achievements and contributions the New Left has made to politics in the past several years.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 24 -- Losing last year's American League pennant on the final day of the season has made the Detroit Tigers a better and more complete team this spring.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- A major controversy over "the public's right to know" about the Administration's presentation of the President's request for foreign aid is emerging in the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
MOUND BAYOU, Miss -- The baby was too weak to cry.

A gang of burglars, working with precision and elaborate equipment that included a police radio, monitored an alarm broadcast while they were robbing a Queens bank yesterday and escaped with thousands of dollars only moments before the police arrived.

MILWAUKEE, March 24 -- The blonde coed, equipped with an armload of literature and a nervous smile, pressed the doorbell of the small frame house in a working-class neighborhood in West Milwaukee. When a young mother opened the door the college girl started her spiel:

JERUSALEM, March 24 -- Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said today that the attack Thursday against Karemeh in Jordan was part of a campaign, perhaps a long one, that would continue until Israel came to a decision with the Arabs.
On Feb. 28, the Republican moderates hope for the Presidency, Gov. George Romney of Michigan, pulled out of the race. The next day began the three-week not-quite-candidacy of Governor Rockefeller.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 24 -- Even a fatigued and apparently bored Jean-Claude Killy remained the king of them all.
It was bargain night Sunday at Carnegie Hall, with a sizable crowd taking advantage of the generous dollar-a-ticket policy to enjoy a concert by the New York Chamber Ensemble.
The North Atlantic Westbound Freight Association has charged a Federal Maritime Commission hearing examiner with attempting to establish ocean freight rates illegally.
The State has moved to spur savings bank investments in slum clearance projects, Frank Wille, New York State Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday.

For years Times Square has been a kind of urban urchin, dirty and bedraggled, keeping bad company. Periodic rescue efforts have been resisted with a sooty, sleazy stubbornness. The area's peculiar assets -- a lively emphasis on continuous, varied, small-scale, fine-grained human activities and a constantly moving kaleidoscope of moving light and color -- have overshadowed its liabilities.

In a $1-million leasing agreement, the American Enka Corporation has leased the entire 14th floor of 530 Fifth Avenue, the 26-story office building that occupies the west block-front of the avenue between 44th and 45th Streets.

LONDON, March 24 -- How the British Broadcasting Corporation foiled an attempt by Sir Anthony Eden as Prime Minister to impose Government control of broadcasting on the eve of the Suez invasion of 1956 is told in a book to be published tomorrow.

LOS ANGELES, March 24 -- James Francis Cardinal McIntyre, while personally remaining silent, is stepping up his indirect criticism of the Immaculate Heart Order of nuns for their controversial innovations in practices and policies.
ROSALYN DREXLER is the queen of the underground drama. Her plays are not only produced by the Judson Poets Theater, they are printed in hard cover by Random House just like Robert Anderson's.

Although the fifth annual Latin Jazz Festival attracted only a sparse audience to Town Hall last night, it still managed to build up a festive atmosphere. The combination of four enthusiastic Latin bands -- Pete Rodriguez, Willie Bobo, Joe Cuba and Ray Baretto -- and an audience that wanted to be part of the rhythm overcame whatever emptiness there was in the hall.
With many interest rates just a step below the peaks reached late last fall, the money and capital markets face a difficult week.
The American Civil Liberties Union proposed yesterday that legislatures abolish all laws imposing criminal penalties for abortions performed by licensed physicians, no matter what the reason.
The Lindsay administration, finally acknowledging Albany's unwillingness to grant its request for much greater state aid next year, has begun to slice its spending plans.
FISHGUARD, Wales, March 24 -- An Irish airliner carrying 61 persons plunged into the sea off southwest Wales today.
UNITED NATION, N. Y., March 24 -- Following is the text of the resolution on the Middle East adopted unanimously today by the Security Council:
" EVERY time I brought furniture in from Spain and Mexico, I had problems. So I did something very simple. I just brought the carpenters here."

LOS ANGELES, March 24 -- Adolph Rupp, the Kentucky basketball coach, considered by many to be a wise old man, picked Houston over the University of California, Los Angeles, in the National Collegiate basketball championship. Rupp said U.C.L.A. was too "complacent."

Newsweek magazine, on the basis of its own check of National Convention delegate strength, has concluded that Senator Robert H. Kennedy has made "astonishing progress" in his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
The day after Jane White auditioned for the role of the wicked queen in "Once Upon a Mattress" in 1959, she got a call from a member of the production staff, who was a little embarrassed.
The Metropolitan Museum of Arts plans a Rembrandt exhibition next year and will show on that occasion that some of its paintings thas were attributed to that master are not really by him.

This morning in Britain motorists on their way to work heard a phenomenon of the world of radio: the 1,000th "Letter From America" by Alistair Cooke, the droll journalist and commentator who is perhaps most familiar to United States audiences as the host of the civilized "Omnibus" television series, and the author of "The Vintage Mencken."
MIAMI, March 24 -- Things were bad enough when the New York Mets were making only two runs a game. But today they made only two hits in a game and were throttled by the Baltimore Orioles, 3-0.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- A sharp division has developed within the Federal Maritime Commission as to the extent to which alleged rate discrimination against the Port of New York should be investigated.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., March 25 (UPI) -- Jerry West's 3-point play with 1 minute 3 seconds remaining and Archie Clark's two free throws with 11 seconds left to play gave the Los Angeles Lakers a 111-106 victory tonight over the Chicago Bulls.
DEBRUCE, N.Y., March 25 -- In mid-afternoon under dark skies and driving snow, lights glowed over a pool at the Satskill Fish Hatchery.

ALBANY, March 25 (AP) -- The Republican State Committee is scheduled to go on record Wednesday in favor of designating Governor Rockefeller as New York's favorite-son candidate for the G.O.P. Presidential nomination.
COLLEGE basketball rules may undergo a major change today or tomorrow for the second straight year. The rules committee is meeting in Los Angeles and it may reverse its stand of a year ago.
WARSAW, March 25--The Government dismissed six Warsaw University professors tonight.
The post-budget buying boom continued yesterday on the London Stock Exchange and prices moved up to new 1968 highs.
PENSACOLA, Fla., March 25 (AP) -- George Archer scored birdies on the last three holes today to finish with a 65 and win the Pensacola open golf tournament by one stroke with a 268 total.

ALBANY, March 25 -- The Assembly passed without debate today a bill that would block New York City's plans for an elaborate $70-million sewage-disposal plant and ornamental fountain on the Hudson River shore between 137th and 145th Streets.
YONKERS, March 25 -- Pocomoonshine, a 7-year-old New York-bred pacer, fared well in today's draw for post positions for the $25,000 Adios Pacing Festival final Thursday night at Yonkers Raceway.

SENATOR JACOB K. JAVITS, Republican of New York, told an audience at Alexander's International Haute Couture fashion show yesterday that he deplored those "symptoms of narrow nationalism" that cause Americans to dump French wines into the gutters and stop buying French clothes.
For the third time in eight days, Mayor Lindsay addressed a student group yesterday, telling them that tension in American cities is related to "the insane military escalation in Vietnam."
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Treasury bill rate fell at today's auction from last week's levels, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

Two uniformed guards who earned $80 a week protecting the tenants of a luxurious East Side housing complex were arrested yesterday and charged with having looted the apartments of thousands of dollars in jewels and furs over the last two years.

Robert J. Kelleher, the president of the United States Lawn Tennis Federation, believes that open tennis, "on a limited basis," will be approved by the International Lawn Tennis Federation at its special meeting on Saturday in Paris.

The International Longshoremen's Association won victories in two courts yesterday and was freed to continue today its eight-day-old work stop-page against all dry-cargo shipping in the Port of New York without any legal restraint.

Spring brings fresh strawberries, but it also brings out the "little cheaters." Summer is the popular season for malteds, but some drink stands in the Times Square area use a trick measuring spoon that short-changes the customer on the malt.
" The role of the agency is to reveal the authentic, legitimate virtues of candidates," said Fred Papert yesterday during a luncheon talk on political advertising--a very timely topic.
DETROIT, March 25 -- Upgrade. Dazzle the buyer with more luxurious, more gimmicky cars that will tempt him into spending more than he planned.

PITTSBURGH, March 25 (AP) -- Connie Hawkins scored 38 points tonight to pace the Pittsburgh Pipers to a 146-127 victory over the Indiana Pacers in the opener of a three-of-five-game playoff series in the Eastern Division of the American Basketball Association.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25 -- Gil Hodges promised last week that the Mets would begin playing baseball this week the way it should be played. For seven innings tonight against his former Washington club, they did. The Mets didn't score any runs but neither did the Senators.
A drive to halt Liberal party consideration of a possible endorsement for Senator Jacob K. Javits is being pressed by Louis Stulberg, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.
SAN DIEGO, March 25 -- A nationwide survey has found that cigarette smoking among teen-agers has "declined appreciably" from the levels reported over the last several years.
At about 6:45 last evening, a freelance writer named Marcia Herscovitz whirled into the Museum of Modern Art through a revolving door and held up a placard. "Bourgeoisie Zoo," it read.

Animals looking for homes will be shown along with the Andrew Woods collection of spring into summer clothes on Thursday at a fashion show luncheon of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.
Neighbors of an elderly physician beaten to death in a Brooklyn tenement were urged yesterday to "eliminate the breeding source of problems that brought him to his untimely end."
The Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday the development of a water-desalination process which, it said, could produce fresh water at a third or a half of the costs of existing systems.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- George Meany retorted today to "some loud-mouthed critics on our own side who say we are not doing too well." The retort, in substance, was a list of achievements.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 25 -- The verbal war over Sabah (North Borneo) and the Corregidor camp incident escalated further today when Malaysia implicitly rejected a Filipino contention that the Corregidor incident was an internal matter and that "Malaysian misapprehension" could best be eliminated through bilateral talks.

The city's Investigation Commissioner, Arnold G. Fraiman, said yesterday that he was investigating whether a "malicious'' and racially motivated campaign was going on to discredit Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery, a Negro.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 25 -- Two American pilots went on trial today for manslaughter through negligence in the Feb. 16 crash of a Civil Air Transport jetliner in which 22 people were killed. Both pilots have denied they were negligent.

BERLIN, March 25--Communist sources in East Berlin said today that they believed the Soviet and East German leaderships had suggested extending a substantial credit to Czechoslovakia to help her economy.

" He win six races in a row," was the expression heard all around Aqueduct yesterday. The person in question was Jorge Velasquez, the Panamanian jockey, who led the nation's riders last year with a total of 438 victories.

DETROIT, March 25 (UPI) -- Lee Hills, publisher, of The Detroit Free Press, said today "whipsaw strike atctics" led the newspaper to suspend publication Nov. 17, the day after The Detroit News was shut down by a strike.

European bankers and investment managers are predicting another run on the dollar and another gold crisis within three months, Pierre Rinfret, consulting economist, revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Supreme Court deadlocked today in two cases as Justice Thurgood Marshall abstained from a case involving the Federal Government and a civil rights appeal to avoid an appearance of conflict with his previous legal activities.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Ralph Nader, the consumer protection and automobile safety crusader, charged today that thousands of American coal miners faced unnecessary risks because the United States Bureau of Mines was "the captive" of the coal industry in drafting mine safety regulations.
Moody's Investors Service, Inc., announced yesterday that it would continue to rate municipal bonds without charge.
LONDON, March 25 -- The Government moved today to try to reduce noise on the nation's streets and highways by setting up roadside meters for spot checks.

The International Development Association, a cash-poor affiliate of the World Bank, that specializes in low-cost loans to developing countries, announced yesterday that Sweden planned to make a contribution of $21.36-million to the association's resources.
In a dusty excavation under the Statue of Liberty, construction men have started work on the final phase of the planned American Museum of Immigration.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 25 -- A former official on Gen. William C. Westmoreland's staff who has worked for the United States mission for more than a year is leaving South Vietnam to protest "failures'' of tile American effort here.

JERUSALEM, March 25 -- The resolution on fighting in the Middle East adopted by the United Nations Security Council last night was being interpreted by some Israelis today as a virtual invitation to increased terrorism.
Concern that provocateurs may take over hippie groups, seek "confrontations" with the law and thus upset the city's brittle calm was voiced at a City Hall meeting yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, March 25 -- Five plans for reapportionment of the legislative branch of the Westchester County government were agreed upon today by the county's supervisors for submission at a public hearing April 8.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- George W. Ball, former Under Secretary of State and now an international banker, has proposed that the United States redirect its foreign policy toward the achievement of a new world balance of power.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- High civil service officials are being asked, in some cases with more pressure than usual even in an election year, to contribute sizable sums to a Democratic party dinner here early next month.

WASHINGTON, March 25--Proclaiming that he had won the enactment of programs of social justice greater than any " in all the history of America," President Johnson said today that he was " not going to sit by and let them be torn down in a partisan political election year."
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Communications Workels of America authorized today a national strike of the Bell Telephone System on April 12.
Top - level management changes were initiated yesterday by the National Biscuit Company, the National Lead Company and the Gulf Oil Corporation.
GENEVA, March 25 -- Switzerland today imposed an embargo, backed by a fine or a jail sentence of up to five years, on the export of the half billion silver coins now in circulation.

HARTFORD, March 25 -- Sterling T. Tooker, president of the Travelers Corporation, told 500 stockholders at the annual meeting here today that he expected the insurance concern's mutual fund to begin operations early in June.
The American people are opposed to sending 100,000 more troops to Vietnam by a margin of 52 to 31 per cent, according to a poll taken by Louis Harris.
Sunday's bank burglar, in which the burglars used a transistorized police radio to monitor an alarm broadcast, points up a problem of concern to the police.
LOS ANGELES, March 25 -- A pocket guide to the biggest state in the Union:

THE new president of the New York Stock Exchange placed a large but barely visible fence around one of Wall Street's most precious preserves yesterday. Robert W. Haack placed limits on the amount of otherwise undisclosed information financial analysts can get from corporations listed on the Big Board.

Activity quickened yesterday in foreign-exchange trading of the British pound and the Canadian dollar in New York. For immediate delivery, both currencies closed firmer in relation to the United States dollar than on Friday.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Senator George A. Smathers of Florida, cosponsor of legislation that would couple a 10 per cent tax surcharge with a mandatory $6-billion cut in Federal spending, told the Senate today that he believed the Administration would support his plan if the spending cutback were somewhat smaller.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 25 -- Zoilo Versalles, uncommonly tense and explicit, played with a deck of cards and talked about the night he was traded from the Minnesota Twins to the Los Angeles Dodgers.
Manhattan Community College will experiment this fall with admissions policies designed to bring more residents of Manhattan, and thus more Negroes and Puerto Ricans, into the two-year institution.

VIENNA, March 25 (AP) -- An authoritative source said today that Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty had changed his mind about maintaining his self-imposed exile in the United States Embassy in Budapest and wanted to go to Rome.
PANAMA, March 25 -- The most-discussed man in Panama today is one of the least visible of the republic's principal figures.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI) -- The Army conceded for the first time today that its nerve gas might have killed 6,000 sheep in Utah.
Two Roman Catholic groups are planning to produce a dramatized film biography of Pope John XXIII.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 25 -- Already beset by a shortage of front-line pitchers, the Yankees gave a convincing demonstration of another problem in a Grapefruit League game today: lack of hitting.

The exit of Australia's probable Davis Cup defenders, a snarled schedule, a controversial surface, illegal adjoining courts, a yellow-shifted competitor and a $30 theft combined yesterday to feature the opening of the Garden Challenge Trophy amateur tennis tournament.

" KISS ME, KATE" was revived again on television last night in a disappointingly heavy-handed special over the network of the American Broadcasting Company. The adaptation of the Broadway musical, with the score by the late Cole Porter and the book by Sam and Bella Spewack, was staged and played with barely a trace of sophisticated style or freshness of expression.
ALBANY, March 25 -- The Assembly gave final legislative approval tonight to a bill that would raise the basic parimutuel tax at New York race tracks to 16 per cent -- a 1 per cent increase.

Cotton futures tumbled yesterday following a Government report. Selling came after the Department of Agriculture surprised traders by setting a lower-than-expected premium for the high quality, 1 1/16 inch cotton compared with the middling one inch cotton, under the loan program.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- The chairman of a Congressional investigating committee proposed today that tax-exempt foundations donate their receipts to the Government during the Vietnam crisis.

TO BE runners-up in an important event four years in a row probably sets some kind of record. Fortunate or unfortunate, according to the point of view, were Bill Hoffman and Roy and Jane Hill, all of White Plains, Alan Dworetzky of Tarrytown, N. Y., and Seymour Schwartz of Yonkers.

ROME, March 25 -- Gian Carlo Menotti, founder of the 11-year-old Festival of the Two Worlds at Spoleto, has turned over artistic direction and general management of the festival to Massimo Bogianchino, former head of the Rome Opera.
The nation's railroads presented their case yesterday for the second increase in freight rates in seven months. The latest rise was granted last August.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy's bid for the Presidential nomination picked up home-state endorsements yesterday from two State Senators and four county chairmen, amid increasingly bitter Democratic factional strife.
Investors slowed their trading pace even more markedly yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
LOS ANGELES, March 25 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy stood on a street corner in the heart of Watts today and looked out at a sea of black faces.
Mutual funds have piled up liquid reserves of $3.4-billion, their biggest cash position in history, according to data released yesterday by the Investment Company Institute.
PRAGUE, March 25 -- The reformist leaders of Czechoslovakia know that the freedom they have given to expressions of dissenting views may create a tide that will be difficult to dam.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Wilbur J. Cohen, whom President Johnson has nominated as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, disagreed today with the conclusion of a Presidential commission that white racism was a principal cause of riots.

AMMAN, Jordan, March 25 -- The thorny problem of the Jordanian Government's relations with Palestinian fighters against Israeli occupation forces west of the Jordan River was discussed today by King Hussein at a large meeting.
WASHINGTON -- There is one Presidential adviser who has done his level best to change Lyndon B. Johnson's image. His sartorial image, that is.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted a liberalized rule today exempting the foreign financial subsidiaries of American corporations from regulations that hampered their raising of funds abroad to finance the foreign business operations of the parent company.
A drama by Graham Greene, "Carving a Statue," will be presented next month at the Gramercy Arts Theater, 138 East 27th Street. Margaret Webster will direct the play, which Londoners saw ,in 1964.

Those eccentrics who go to the opera believing it a form of theater and wanting to believe in what is happening onstage (may their tribe continue to increase), looked forward hopefully to last night's "Madama Butterfly" at the Metropolitan Opera.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- Spokesmen for a loose coalition of New Left and antiwar groups said today demonstrators at the Democratic national convention here in August would be peaceful rather than disruptive.
BRUSSELS, March 25 -- The United States got from European Economic Community ministers tonight a gesture of support, to help the trade segment of the American balance of payments.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 25 -- The Government announced today major changes in the rules under which it would allow new oil exploration rights. Ruben Sader Perez, director general of the state-owned Corporacion Venezolana de Petroleo, said that in future all oil agreements would be service contracts instead of concession agreements as in the past.
The six month profit of the Jim Walter Corporation more than doubled that of the corresponding period last year, J. M. Walter, chairman, announced yesterday.
To the Editor: Chauncey G. Parker's March 14 letter reflects the paranoia responsible for the grotesque foreign policies of the United States.

MADISON, Wis., March 25 -- From early morning until nearly midnight, Senator Eugene J. McCarthy put on a widely contrasting campaign today and got a vastly different response as he opened his final drive to beat President Johnson in the Wisconsin primary on April 2.

It is a disgrace that, in this richest nation in the world, babies are dying of hunger and children are growing up sick and stunted. The conditions among impoverished Negro families in the Mississippi Delta, documented for the thousandth time in a story in this newspaper yesterday, area challenge to the conscience of every Government official from President Johnson down, every member of Congress and every private citizen.

To the Editor: Your March 18 editorial on the copper strike commends President Johnson and his "Cabinet-level mediators . . . for their perseverance," lamenting the failure of collective bargaining, and castigating both unions and companies for their unresponsive attitude.
RICHMOND March 25 -- Virginia's only Negro Sheriff was found dead in his automobile in nearby Charles City County this afternoon, apparently the victim of suicide.
BERKELEY, Calif., March 25 -- Most American church members are prejudiced, racially and religiously, two sociologists of the University of California reported today on the Berkeley campus.
MANILA, March 25 -- The Civil Affairs Office of the Philippine Army, under which secret special forces camps were operated, was abolished today.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Administration was praised by farmers today, a development that some Federal agricultural officials found hard to believe although they thought they knew the reason.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Federal District Judge George L. Hart Jr. rejected today a demand by poor Alabama Negroes that would have forced Agriculture Secretary Orville L. Freeman to give out more free food to families that doctors had testified were "starving."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 25 -- The diplomatic consensus at the United Nations today was that the latest Security Council resolution on the Middle East is unlikely to curb Arab guerrilla activity or to deter Israeli reprisals.
Stock prices continued to decline yesterday as the market went through its slowest trading session in almost seven months.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 25 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan, who has repeatedly said he is "not a candidate," left little doubt today of his dissatisfaction at Richard M. Nixon's being left with the inside track for the Republican nomination for President.

THE generation gap in furnishings is being bridged in all major design areas at a quickened pace these days. The scaling-down of adult furniture for tots has been credited to the population explosion, to the youthful attitude of designers and to the fact that much of the new modern furniture is childish to start with.

PANAMA, March 25 -- President Marco A. Robles was in effective command of Panama today despite the attempt yesterday by the National Assembly to put his First Vice President, Max Delvalle, in his place.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 26 -- United States and South Vietnamese troops killed 243 Vietcong yesterday in a day-long clash 28 miles northwest of Saigon.

Several dresses of the 1930's, the original midi-length styles, will be shown alongside a collection of modern midis on April 6 at the 11th annual luncheon and fashion show of the National Tay-Sachs and Allied Diseases Association.
The New York Stock Exchange has voiced strong objections to a proposed rule by the Securities and Exchange Commission that would restrict sharply the practice of customer-directed "give-ups."

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- "We hold these truths to be self-evident," wrote Thomas Jefferson in 1776, in the Declaration of American Independence, "that all men are created equal; that they are endowed by their creator with certain unalienable rights, and that among these are life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness."

ROCKVILLE, Md., March 27 -- A state court raised the possibility today that officials of the Democratic party in Maryland who are strongly pro-Johnson might be forced to hold a Presidential primary for a statewide delegate election.

The recent deterioration in the Middle East situation -- reviving the old cycle of Arab terrorist attacks, military reprisal by Israel and justified but futile Security Council censure -- stems from the belief of both adversaries that time is on their side. It is a dangerous miscalculation.

Momentary intrusions by a fluttering pigeon, a portable radio and a ringing telephone punctuated the advance last night of Lieut. Arthur Ashe and Clark Graebner to the semi-finals of the Madison Square Garden Challenge Trophy amateur tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Senate voted today to restrict the importation of woolen and man-made fabrics Thus it threw into greater question than before the fate of the pending tax bill, to which the amendment restricting textile imports was attached.
LONDON, March 27 -- Desmond Donnelly, a persistent critic of Prime Minister Wilson, was expelled from the Labor party today. He has been a Labor Member of Parliament since 1950.
SALT LAKE CITY, March 27 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy will enter the Indiana Presidential primary May 7 in an effort to show an early surge of strength in his race for the White House.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 27 -- General Suharto, the army officer who has headed the Indonesian Government for the last two years, was granted the title of President tonight by the 828-member Consultative Assembly.

ALBANY, March 27 -- Governor Rockefeller expressed "very deep concern" today that the "drastic reductions" the Legislature is contemplating in his proposed $5.5-billion budget would have a damaging effect on his urban programs to curb crime, help the poor and assist the mentally ill.

THE sixth annual Midwest Open Team Chess Festival at the Ohio State University chess club of Columbus was a stunning victory for the four-man Toledo team, which won all its matches and amassed 18 game points out of 20. The individual Toledo players on boards one, two, three and four also finished with the highest scores on each board.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 27 (AP) -- Gov. Lurleen B. Wallace's condition took a turn for the worse today following her recent cancer surgery. Her doctors reported finding a possible "blood clot to the lung."

TIME was when Tennessee Williams wrote plays, but nowadays he seems to prefer to write characters. The most mysterious aspect of "The Seven Descents of Myrtle," his play that opened at the Ethel Barrymore Theater last night, is the title.

ALBANY, March 27 -- Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz declared today that persons now receiving treatment under the state's Medicaid program must continue to get this care after the program is cut back next Monday.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Gen. Creighton W. Abrams left for Vietnam tonight saying the enemy "has the capability to conduct offensive operations whenever he feels the time is right."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 28 -- Air Force jets moved through gray and overcast skies yesterday to pound a vital North Vietnamese railroad yard 18 miles from the border of Communist China.
A high official of the Hotel and Restaurant Workers Union was arrested yesterday and charged with three counts of first-degree perjury involving suspected misuse of the union's funds.

Rosemary Casals of San Francisco, Mrs. Ann Haydon Jones of England and Francoise Durr of France will join Mrs. Billie Jean King as the four women professionals in the National Tennis League that begins competition April 7 in Los Angeles.

'Billie Jean King, her husband is a law student, isn't that cute, and she's the fastest, reflexes-wise, in the world, she really hustles on the court.'"
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- A key Commerce Department official said today that the 1968 outlook for the United States trade balance was anything but promising.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 27 (AP) -- The Atlanta Braves announced today that preliminary medical reports had indicated that Rico Carty, their left fielder, has tuberculosis.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 27 -- A gift of $2-million to Harvard University from Mrs. William A. M. Burden of New York City and her sons, William A. M. Burden and Shirley C. Burden, was announced today.
The city disclosed plans yesterday to apply for the first time a full-scale urban renewal that will be keyed to the preservation and restoration of landmarks.
A series of seminars to inform Negro and Puerto Rican realty men about developments in the real estate business will begin next week.
A new, higher producer price for copper was established yesterday as the United States industry was moving back into production after an eight-month long strike.
Stock prices continued to advance yesterday as the pace of trading quickened.
New York is probably the first city in the United States with a "truth in advertising" law.
FRANKFORT, Ky., March 27 (UPI) -- Gov. Louie B. Nunn tonight allowed the first statewide open housing law in the South to become law without his signature.
BONN, March 27 -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger proposed today that the West German and Polish governments "exchange thoughts" on a future solution to the Oder-Neisse border issue.
The Board of Education's proposed reorganization plan has been criticized by the board's own advisory committee on decentralization.
WASHINGTON, March 277 (AP) -- Military spending dropped in February by 10.6 per cent to jjust under $6.2-billion, the Treasury reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The leadership of B'nai B'rith Women called today for a "more vigorous effort" to get peace negotiations started in Vietnam.

WAUSAU, Wis., March 27 -- Richard M. Nixon began his courtship of the nation's Republican Governors today -- an effort he hopes will provide him with broad support in the party and a fresh stream of ideas on domestic problems.

Three thousand cartons of dinner services, tea services and other chinaware, all destined for pre-Easter sales in department stores, are locked under the hatches of the Iga Haru at Pier 6, Brooklyn, below the Brooklyn Heights Promenade.
ALBANY, March 27 -- The Assembly voted today to restore the death penalty for the murder of firemen.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The Justice Department moved today to block the proposed merger of the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company and the Caterpillar Tractor Company, the nation's leading manufacturer of earth-moving equipment.

ALBANY, March 27 -- The New York Republican organization today took a step that many of its members hoped would lead to a move to draft Governor Rockefeller as the party's national candidate for President. The 300-member state committee designated Mr. Rockefeller as New York's favorite son candidate for the Presidency and pledged him the support of the state's 92 delegates in the forthcoming Republican Convention.

Congress has been urged by five maritine lador and management groups to close a "loophole" in existing law for carrying military cargoes by United States-flag merchant ships.

The State Public Service Commission ruled yesterday that a $32-million-a-year electric rate increase it had tentatively approved for Consolidated Edison in 1966 was fair and reasonable and should remain in effect.

LORAIN, Ohio, March 27 (AP) -- A California bank executive who drowned March 8 sent the bomb that killed a Government physicist in Ohio Feb. 24 "in an unnecessary attempt to remove the supposed rival in an extramarital affair," Lorain County Coroner Paul J. Kopsch said today.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today to authorize court-approved wiretapping and eavesdropping in criminal investigations despite Administration pleas to limit bugging to national security cases.

NEW DELHI, March 27 -- The Shiv Sena, a movement that Indian leaders have denounced as fascist, nearly dislodged the once-indomitable Congress party from power in Bombay yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The United Steelworkers Union announced today ratification of contract agreements with the Kennecott Copper Corporation and the Anaconda Company involving 20,000 workers.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Hudson Institute, Inc., operating under research contracts toealing $600,000, submitted reports to the Office of Civil Defense that were considered less useful than expected or required major revision, the General Accounting Office said yesterday.

LONDON, March 27 -- The Judicial Committee of the Privy Council agreed today to hear an appeal from a Rhodesian court decision upholding the legal powers of the white rebels' regime there.

MADRID, March 27 -- Parliament ended official subsides today for the University of Navarre in a showdown between Opus Dei, an influential Roman Catholic association of priests and laymen, and the Falange, Spain's only legal political movement.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27 -- The New York Mets, who can count their blessings on the fingers of one hand, finally found something that counted today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 28 -- Governor Rockefeller and United Nations Secretary General Thant exchanged views today on Vietnam and a number of other problems at a luncheon given in the Governor's honor by Mr. Thant.
Eight milk-plant inspectors for the Health Department were arrested yesterday on charges of perjury before a grand jury investigating "systematic payoffs" by the milk industry.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The United States Government, which has just completed, plans for a sweeping reduction in its civilian staffs overseas, is already preparing to trim its largest embassies still further.
State Senator Whitney North Seymour Jr. announced yesterday his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Representative in the 17th (Silk Stocking) Congressional District on Manhattan's East Side.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 28 -- Mike Andrews trotted down the line to first with a base on balls and instantly grew embarrassed. This was at the end of a game between the Boston Red Sox and the Angels at Anaheim early last season, the initial appearance of the Fenway Millionaires in California.
MADRID, March 28 -- The Government tonight ordered violence-torn University of Madrid closed indefinitely following the year's worst clash between students and the police.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Administration said today that the wage and price patterns of the copper strike settlements were higher than desirable from the standpoint of economic stability.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 28 -- The Yankees won the baseball championship of Greater New York today by defeating the Mets, 5-1, on a sunny little field 1,100 miles from Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Senate, undoing an action it took only two days ago, voted today to terminate the tax-exempt status of industrial development bonds, effective next Jan. 1.

DETROIT, March 29 -- Jonathan Moore, foreign policy adviser to Gov. George Romney in his campaign for the Republican Presidential nominanation, will begin work Monday on Governor Rockefeller's personal staff, according to sources here.

Charges against a police sergeant accused of failing to respond to a radio call and of failing to maintain proper supervision of his men were dismissed yesterday by Deputy Police Commissioner Aloysius Melia after a hearing in Police Headquarters.

It is only natural that Prof. Edward Dew, in his March 21 letter, is unhappy that the Czechoslovak general Jan Sejna was granted refuge in this country. General Sejna was a notorious Czech Stalinist who escaped from his country when a Communist regime more liberal and acceptable to our democratic thinking came to power.
TRACKED down in his Catskills hideaway, Harty Tightline was as irascible as ever.

CAIRO -- Ever since the 1955 arms deal with Egypt, Soviet policy here has been skillful and persistent. When the U.S.A. refused Nasser weapons he wanted to modernize his forces and cajole his officers, Russia moved in.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A group of Republican Senators and Representatives proposed today a manpower law that would put into effect some recommendations of the President's National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 28 (AP) -- Florida Republican leaders overrode Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr.'s bid for control of the delegation to the Republican National Convention today and the state's Democrats headed into an intraparty battle to determine their slate.
Karine Georgian, a 23-year-old Soviet cellist who won the Tchaikovsky International Competition in 1966, has been touring the United States for the first time.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A high Defense Department official warned Congress today that any drastic curtailment of military aid abroad "could threaten the very foundation we have built to sustain the collective security system" of the non-Communist world.

Lawrence Durrell, the British author who is earnestly analyzed in literature courses all over the United States, is in this country for the first time at the age of 56 -- and his favorite subject for discourse is Disneyland.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 29 -- The United States command announced today that an Air Force F-111 fighter bomber had vanished yesterday on a combat mission, the first of the planes to be lost in Vietnam. The North Vietnamese said in a broadcast later that they had shot it down.

PANAMA, Friday, March 29 -- Two men were reported to have been killed and almost 20 injured in rioting that broke out in the heart of the city last night. It was the the most serious disturbance that has occurred in the continuing effort to unseat President Marco A. Robles.

THOUGHTS of summer evidently were in the minds of five young interior designers on Bloomingdale's decorating staff when they went to work on the 11 model rooms that are now ready for viewing on the store's fifth floor.

Three more sources of mysterious radio pulsation emanating from space were described yesterday by Dr. Anthony Hewish, leader of the group at Cambridge University in England that recently discovered them.

New Yorkers would feel more comfortable about the decision of the State Public Service Commission upholding higher electric rates if they had any reason to consider the commission a real champion of the public interest.

The Dodge index of nationwide construction-contract value declined in February for the fourth consecutive month, mainly because of a cutback in public spending, the F. W. Dodge Company, construction research division of McGraw-Hill, Inc., reported yesterday.

PARIS, March 28 - The prosecutor for the state security court today accused Maurice Picard, a highly-placed civil servant, of surreptitious communication with agents of foreign powers "of a nature to harm the military or diplomatic situation of France or its essential economic interests."
BONN, March 28 -- Paul Lucke, the Minister of Interior in the West German coalition Government, resigned from the Cabinet today for the second time in four days.
BOSTON, March 28 -- The highest National Hockey League finish for the Rangers in 10 years was almost assured tonight as the New Yorkers barely lasted to turn back the Boston Bruins by 5-4.

MOSCOW, March 28 -- The Soviet Union grieved today as it prepared a state funeral in Red Square for Col. Yuri A. Gagarin, the world's first astronaut, and a fellow pilot who died yesterday in a plane crash.

It is cheering to discover that our Government, even in these troubled times on the international scene, can still confuse well-and ill-wishers abroad in the most delightful way. What are they to think of the new quarterly called Dialogue, prepared under the guidance of the United States Information Agency in Washington, which is being distributed by air and surface mail to readers in all parts of the world?
MOSCOW, March 28 -- The Soviet Union denied today that it was attempting to restrain democratic reforms under way in Czechoslovakia.

WASHINGTON, March 28--Government reports from Saigon indicate that the psychological blows of the enemy's Lunar New Year offensive were worse than the physical disruption to the program of pacifying the South Vietnamese countryside.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that Madison Square Garden executives had not given him all the figures needed in his investigation of the Garden's opening night show.
The Federal National Mortgage Association's participation certificates advanced and then fell back in price yesterday on a large volume of small orders for the high-yielding Government securities.
WASHINGTON, March 28--The Senate voted tonight to refuse to sell gold to any nation that is more than 90 days in arrears on any debt to the United States.

ROSSLAND, British Columbia, March 28 -- There was no joy in this rocky Kootenay region of western Canada tonight for Nancy Greene, performing before a hometown crowd on mile high Red Mountain, had crashed out of the du Maurier International World Cup slalom.

Hospital Commissioner Joseph V. Terenzio testified yesterday that he was powerless to correct many of the abuses reported in the municipal hospitals, including some abuses not connected with shortages of funds, equipment or personnel.

New York's foreign-exchange market yesterday "churned constantly in all directions at the same time," as one dealer described the confusion on the eve of today's meeting of Western finance ministers in Stockholm.
Robert S. McNamara, the former Secretary of Defense who now heads the World Bank, was elected yesterday to the board of trustees of the Ford Foundation.

IF the New York Knickerbockers had been able to hold a 2-point lead for six more seconds in Philadelphia last Wednesday night, or a 1-point lead for the same length of time at the end of the first overtime period, the 76ers would have been backed to the wall in defense of their National Basketball Association title.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of New York State's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said today that "great frustrations" had been encountered in attempting to improve commuter service on the New Haven Railroad.

Longshoremen began tackling a 500,O00-ton backlog of general cargo in the Port of New York yesterday after leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association instructed them to end an 11-day strike.

STOCKHOLM, March 28 -- Michel Debre, Finance Minister of France, adopted a hard opposition stance today upon his arrival in Stockholm for a major international monetary conference to approve a new reserve asset to supplement gold and dollars.

MOSCOW, March 28 -- On Moscow's broad Kalinin Prospect, amid the noise and bustle of construction work on surrounding office and residential towers, a small white church stands as a serene monument to Russia's rich heritage of religious architecture.
PRAGUE, March 28 -- The Central Committee of the Czechoslovak Communist party today named Gen. Ludvik Svoboda as its candidate for the presidency of Czechoslovakia.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Spring has come to Washington ahead of time and it is recklessly beautiful. There are two yellow clouds of forsythia on the White House lawn, and a lovely white flowering tree standing like a bride at the northwest gate, and a scattering of pink magnolia blossoms by the Treasury fence, and the rose garden is fresh and green outside the President's window.

" THE RABBLE," another of those home-grown adventure dramas of the bygone warlord Orient, opened with the usual quota of grunts and groans yesterday at the 55th Street Playhouse. Made in Japan, this florid earsplitter has been dubbed into Chinese.

ALBANY, March 28 -- Governor Rockefeller, who prides himself on being a consummate negotiator and persuader, is having unusual trouble this year persuading the Legislature to do a lot of things he considers important.

HANOVER, N. H., March 28 -- Don Schollander, who had won four swimming gold medals in the 1964 Olympic Games but had never taken an event in the National Collegiate championships, surged from behind as the Yale anchorman to help his team set an American record in the 800-yard free-style relay tonight.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., March 28 -- Nassau County Republicans selected candidates for Congress, the Legislature and local offices at their annual convention in the Garden City, Hotel tonight.

After all, even if one is Beveridge Webster, and a major artist of 30 years' standing, it must give one the debut shakes all over Ito play for the first time in joint recital with one's own son.

BUFFALO, March 28 -- Protesting the transfer of a white priest from a parish in a rundown Negro neighborhood to a white suburb and alleged "racism" by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Buffalo, a group of demonstrators plan to march upon diocesan headquarters Saturday.
The family of a plumber and steamfitter, who was laid off from his job last week, won a quarter of a million dollars yesterday in the New York State lottery:

YONKERS, March 28 -- It was so difficult to pinpoint the winner of tonight's $25,000 Adios Pacing Festival Final at Yonkers Raceway that management should have offered a prize to any of the 19,187 customers who called the precise one, two, three finish of the one-mile race.

QUEBEC, March 28 (AP) -- Doug Favell's fourth shutout of season led Philadelphia to the a 2-0 National Hockey League victory over the St. Louis Blues tonight. The triumph moved the Flyers into sole possession of first place in the West Division.
MILWAUKEE, March 28 -- The key to the Wisconsin primary, for both its two Democratic contestants and one Republican survivor, is the cross-over vote.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., March 28 (AP) -- Secretary of Transportation Alan S. Boyd said today that America had the "best transportation network in the world," but its people pay two prices -- "one in cash and the other in noise, polluted air, accidents and delays."
ALBANY, March 28 -- The Assembly voted today to restore some of the funds cut from the state's Medicaid program two weeks ago.
WHEN the National Boat Show changes dates, other shows adjust to keep in step with the leader of the parade.

LOS ANGELES, March 28 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan made light today of implications from the camp of Richard M. Nixon that the Governor was not doing all he could to discourage support for the Republican Presidential nomination.

Frederic C. (Bucky) Dumaine's resignation, effective last Wednesday, was announced yesterday by the Delaware Hudson Company. Mr. Dumaine is the company's largest single stockholder, with more than 12 per cent of the shares.

NEW DELHI, March 28 -- Promises by the developed countries that they would try to give more aid on easier terms were embodied today in the final resolutions adopted by the second United Nations Conference on Trade and Development.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee, in a climax to a long controversy, voted today to kill Pentagon plans to build a Navy version of the F-111 supersonic fighter-bomber.
DENVER, March 28 -- As Senator Robert F. Kennedy was speaking to 14,000 persons today in Denver's cavernous City Auditorium, a round-faced teenage girl stood up and shouted, "Sock it to 'em, Bobby."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 28 -- Doug Sanders, dressed from shirt to shoes in what he called "Snowflake white," scored a 65 and set a course record today in gaining the first-round lead in the $100,000 Greater Jacksonville open golf tourney.

UPPSALA, Sweden, March 26 -- In the student politics of Uppsala University, the Radical Democratic party is only two years old. Last year it watched dismayed as the conservatives, known as the University Students of Uppsala, captured two-thirds of the student council seats.

Two large Illinois utilities -- the Illinois Public Service Company and the Illinois Power Company -- announced jointly yesterday plans for a $220-million merger. Allen Van Wyck, chairman of Illinois Power of Decatur, and Marshall S. Luthringer, president of Central Illinois of Springfield, said that Illinois Power would exchange 0.65 share of common for each share of Central Illinois common shares.

WARSAW, March 28 -- Warsaw University students today defied new warnings from the Polish Government and met to demand the reinstatement of six dismissed humanities professors, according to informed sources.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -Vice President Humphrey suggested today to American Negro athletes that a boycott of the Olympic Games was not in their best interest.

While Betsey Johnson, the designer, disembarked from a balloon-trimmed Ford in front of the Parke-Bernet Galleries for a Paraphernalia fashion show, Mrs. John F. Kennedy strolled quietly up the other side of Madison Avenue with Mike Nichols, the director.
Prices of Government bonds, responding to developments outside the market, rallied twice yesterday, finishing with a moderate gain.
Wall Street was guessing yesterday afternoon that P. Lorillard Co. had resumed its courtship of Schenley Industries, Inc., a leading producer and distributor of distilled liquor.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 29 -- The United States Ambassador, Ellsworth Bunker, has urged President Johnson to give a pivotal role in the reorganization of the American military command here to Lieut. Gen. Bruce Palmer Jr., deputy commander of the United States Army in Vietnam.

ALBANY, March 29 -- The State Board of Regents today announced its general approval of a proposal to grant public funds to private colleges and universities.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -President Johnson offered Federal help today to states and cities that need it to control urban rioting. He vowed that "mindless violence" would "never be tolerated in America."
LONDON, March 29 -Edward Heath, the leader of the Opposition, called on the Labor Government today to resign following the overwhelming Labor defeats in four byelections.

ROME, March 29 -- Pope Paul VI abolished today hereditary papal court titles and functions, relics of the Middle Ages and Renaissance and enlisted the aid of expert lay consultants in the service of the Vatican state.
Eleven men were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury in unrelated cases on charges of violating the Military Selective Service Act of 1967.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -The Department of Agriculture has started to set up machinery for direct distribution by the Federal Government of free food to poor families in Alabama.

AMMAN, Jordan, March 29 -The Israeli Air Force attacked Jordanian front lines today near of Sea of Galilee in the most serious border conflict since the incursion by Israeli forces last week in the Jordan Valley, the Jordanian authorities announced today.

E. R. Squibb Sons announced yesterday that its sprawling pharmaceutical plant in Brooklyn would be closed down in mid-1969 to consolidate all Squibb manufacturing operations in the United States in New Brunswick, N. J.
Unbeaten Dewan and Iron Ruler, two of the better eligibles for the Kentucky Derby on May 4, head a field of 3year-olds in the two major events on today's thoroughbred racing schedule.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- Fires broke out in four big department stores in quick succession today, driving thousands of Easter shoppers into the streets of the Loop and raising speculation of an arson conspiracy.
A round-the-clock cancer information service for physicians and dentists will be offered beginning Monday by the Roswell Park Memorial Institute.
PARIS, March 29 -- The United States Senate appeared here today to be completing the job of rallying French opinion behind General de Gaulle in the dispute over the dollar.
THE end of merger plans of the Caterpillar Tractor Company and the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company came in the face of implacable resistance by the Justice Department.
Prices moved ahead yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in somewhat expanded trading activity.
The Annenberg Center for Communication Arts and Sciences, to be built at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, has been given $500,000 from the Harold and Doris Zellerbach Fund.

The volume of help-wanted advertising rose in February to 193 per cent of the 1957 to 1959 average, up 9 points from the January figure and 2 points above the level of February 1967, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.
Orders for 144 trijet airbuses from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for a total of $2.16-billion were announced here yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 29 -- Secretary General Thant reported today to the United Nations that it was urgent to get world action on regulating use of the sea-bottom's largely unexplored riches to avoid a scramble among the nations.

LONDON, March 29 -- In preparation for their New York season, which starts on April 23 at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Royal Ballet at Covent Garden tonight gave for the first time a new version of Frederick Ashton's "Birthday Offering."

A Czechoslovak chemist has synthesized a hormonelike substance that imparts contagious sterility to bugs. Specialists in the United States believe such substances, effective only against specific insects, may revolutionize pest control.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A process for the heat treatment of coal, invented under a contract with the Department of the Interior, is expected to bring better utilization of the country's bituminous deposits. A patent was granted this week to three engineers at the chemical research and development center of the FMC Corporation in Princeton, N. J.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI) -- The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, rejected today the idea of a "two-China" policy applying to mainland China and Taiwan.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 29 -- Proposed amendments in Kenya's Constitution were published in the official gazette today. Diplomatic circles in Nairobi regard the amendments as an indication that President Jomo Kenyatta plans to retire soon. He is 75 years old.

A fire at Belmont Park early Friday morning caused damages estimated at $10,000 but there is expected to be no delay in the opening of the new racing complex. The first program is scheduled there for May 20, and will be headed by the $50,000 Carter Handicap, for 3-yearolds and upward at a distance of seven furlongs.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -The United States has held a new round of direct contacts with North Vietnamese representatives. The talks culminated in the return today of three captured North Vietnamese sailors.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday vetoed $27-million in school projects that had been added to his proposed capital budget by the City Council and the Board of Estimate.

Responding to the report of the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders, the National Council of Churches has announced a program to attack root problems of racial injustice and the growing urban crisis.

ROSSLAND, British Columbia, March 29 -- In a one-day stand reminiscent of the postseason barnstorming days of Babe Ruth and other baseball immortals, Jean-Claude Killy, the sultan of the skiers, dropped down on this quiet mountain community today, impressed the populace and took off for points east.
The London Stock Exchange moved ahead yesterday, but the trading pace and price gains narrowed from those registered earlier in the week.

DETROIT, March 29 -- Columbia University, led by the strong performance of Jeffrey Kestler with the foil today continued to lead the field of 40 colleges competing in the 24th annual National Collegiate fencing championships at Wayne State University.

Cream, a virtuoso English rock trio, appeared at two sold-out concerts at Hunter College last night, spreading blues, blare and excitement.
Customs authorities yesterday completed a week-long experiment to streamline entrance formalities for foreign visitors arriving here by sea and air.
MILWAUKEE, March 29 (AP) -- The peace candidate's reception at Manitowoc wasn't much, but it was an improvement on what happened at Green Bay.
MILWAUKEE, March 29 -Senator Eugene J McCarthy will tour Milwaukee's Negro slum tomorrow by foot and by automobile.
PARIS, March 29 -- The International Lawn Tennis Federation will decide tomorrow whether it recognizes open tennis.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Senate, by a one-vote margin, beat back an attempt today to attach import restrictions on dairy products to the pending tax bill, a step that would probably have opened the way to a host of other protectionist amendments.

Two Metropolitan Opera contracts, three invitations to join the Metropolitan Opera Studio and 11 study prizes of $2,000 each were awarded yesterday to winners in the semifinals of the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions.

IN THE academic ranking of the class of 1936 of the United States Military Academy at West Point, William C. Westmoreland -- now the United States military commander in Vietnam -- stood 112th among 276 graduates.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department reported today that farm product prices increased onethird of one per cent during the month ended March 15.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -The country's four major automobile manufacturers insisted today that it was impossible to put meaningful price tags on safety devices required by Federal law.

ALBANY, March 29 -- The State Health Commissioner ruled today that patients now scheduled for treatment under the state's Medicaid program may receive it even after the program is cut back on Monday.

A woman bingo player in Brooklyn was shot and killed yesterday as she returned to her table after getting a cup of coffee. The police said the shot had been fired accidentally by a porter.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., March 29 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy took his quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination to the Southwest today and told two impoverished minorities -- American Indians and Spanish-Americans -- that they were being short-changed in education, jobs, health care and the draft.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to block increases in truck freight rates to take effect April 1 in 23 states.

Silver prices dropped sharply in futures trading yesterday after a firm opening. Traders apparently took their cue from lower price quotations by Handy Harman, silver dealers and fabricators, and virtually unchanged prices at this week's Government silver auction.

PRAGUE, March 29 (AP) -About 1,000 students marched through downtown Prague and stopped outside Communist party headquarters last night. They shouted for the head man to come down. It was midnight, but Alexander Dubcek, the First Secretary, came.

THE auto insurance industry is training some of its agents as watchdogs against excessive charges for repairs by garages and body and fender shops.

WASHINGTON -- Back in the early days of the Kennedy Administration, Abba Schwartz, a Washington lawyer newly installed as director of the State Department's Bureau of Security and Consular Affairs, began tilting against the seaming sacrosanct passport controls and travel restrictions that had been inherited from chillier days of the cold war.

DETROIT, March 30 -- New York Ranger fans could finally shout "We're No. 2" tonight after the Blue Shirts assured themselves of a second-place finish in the East Division of the National Hockey League by coolly and methodically beating the Detroit Red Wings, 3-1, before 14,314 fans at the Olympia Stadium.
Thousands of automobile lovers thronged through the Coliseum yesterday for the opening of the 12th International Automobile Show.

James Prigoff of the City Athletic Club, who has dominated the national squash tennis scene since 1960, advanced to the semi-final round of the National Squash Tennis Association championship yesterday at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

JERICHO, L. I., March 30 -- Ann Snyder, a tall 16-year-old high-school junior from Syosset, L. I., scored a triple today at the Jericho School of Horsemanship horse show. She won the junior working hunter and horsemanship championships and captured the United States Equesrtian Team Equitation Class.

PRAGUE, March 30 -- Gen. Ludvik Svoboda became President of Czechoslovakia today while his discredited predecessor, Antonin Novotny, applauded.
RICHMOND, March 30 -- Vice President Humphrey said here tonight that extremists would not be permitted to govern the United States.

The New York Rangers wind up their most successful season this afternoon when they face the Montreal Canadiens at Madison Square Garden. Game time is 2:05, and the contest will be carried nationally, live and in color on the CBS-TV network.

Also, and still "of course," you could cull a pretty good catalogue of perversions from the more than 300 works.

ILLUSTRATIONS of United States stamps in color in newspapers, magazines and philatelic journals may soon be permitted. On March 13 a subcommittee of the House Committee on Judiciary, after hearings in Washington, approved a bill by Rep. Thaddeus J. Dulski, Democrat of Buffalo, which would permit color illustrations of cancelled stamps in their original size, and un-cancelled stamps in more than one and one-half or less than three-fourths their normal size.

BUFFALO, March 30 -- About 400 Negroes and whites marched today on the residence of the Roman Catholic Bishop of Buffalo to protest alleged segregation in this diocese.

CAIRO, March 30 -- The Government of President Gamal Abdel Nasser has enlisted a squadron of daredevil Polish aviators to mount an attack on what the President's chief spokesman terms "perhaps the greatest evil this country faces" -- orange striped and ruddy cotton worms.
GANG WAR and Grey Ghost, two mounts who could spell success for Batsy Gerson this year, make their seasonal debuts today at the Holiday Farms show in River Vale, N. J.

CELBRIDGE, Ireland -- The grandest Georgian house in Ireland, a superlative with good, solid endorsement and no discernible opposition, stands huge and imposing in this County Kildare village 12 miles west of Dublin. The grandeur is not at its peak right now, but help is on the way.

MOYNIHAN, Chairman of the Advisory Committee on Traffic Safety in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, once told a group of business executives that during the auto safety controversy two years ago the industry leaders only listened to advice that they paid for and by so doing were led over the brink.
The fickle finger of fashion is pointing at shoes these days and bringing considerable attention to the offerings of manufacturers and merchants.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. -- April is festival time here, with events celebrating the Easter season filling the month. The celebrations will start next weekend with two functions, the St. Augustine Arts and Crafts Festival and the Inter-American Music Festival.

BIG PINE KEY, Fla. -- Boat-camping at the two state parks in the Keys is one of Florida's biggest bargains for budget-conscious families. A daily campsite fee of $2.50 buys a boatload of fun at the Bahia Honda facility or at John Pennekamp Coral Reef State Park in Key Largo, 55 miles south of Miami.

The Women's Swimming Association of New York will observe its 50th birthday six months late tomorrow night with a dinner at the Seventh Regiment Armory, 66th Street and Park Avenue. Many of the swimmers who through their Olympic, national and regional championships made America's first swimming club for women famous will be there, some with husbands and children.
Today marks the end of Red Cross Month, the once-a-year period when the Red Cross focuses attention on the vital need for contributions to support its many programs.

LOS ANGELES -- By now, the average driver of a new car is saying, audibly or to himself: "I paid $50 extra on my 1968 model for smog - control equipment, but the air doesn't seem much better. When do we get rid of smog?"

NEANDERTHAL man, who disappeared about 50,000 years ago after perhaps 75,000 years of existence, could have been our ancestor. On this theme Leonard Wibberley has written an excellent book. Tightly woven, presented in deceptively simple, stark tones, it shows a way of life stripped to bare essentials: a full belly, warmth, and a roof to shut out cold, wind and rain.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A study of the natural, scenic, recreational and historical resources of the Virgin Islands led to a recommendation today that a decision on the use of a mangrove lagoon area for a new jet airport on St. Thomas be withheld pending a full assessment of the conservation values involved.

He says that after Teaneck eliminated "racial imbalance" in its elementary schools the Negro "ghetto is broken up by whites buying back into it."

A re-creation of the Bronte family by the Walking Shadow Players will be staged on Thursday at 7:30 P.M. at the Donnell Library Center of the New York Public Library, 20 West 53d Street. Directed by David Craven, "An Evening with the Brontes" is based on Norma Crandall's biography, "Emily Bronte," and incorporates writings of both Emily and Charlotte.

The Negro then, amalgamation to the contrary notwithstanding, was not and never had been an American.

Although it is hardly the most accessible country, even in this age of jet travel, Greenland has become a rather popular destination for tourists visiting Iceland.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Antibiotics used to treat a wide range of human ailments including pneumonia, typhoid and typhus fever show promise of curing at least one serious disease affecting vegetables.

AMMAN -- When Israeli armor struck across the Jordan River at Arab civilian commando camps week before last it was the regular Jordanian Army that fought the real battle against the Israelis. Again, last week, when an artillery duel flared along the river and Israeli jets went into action, it was the Jordanian regulars who did the fighting. Yet it is the raggle-taggle commandos who have reaped the glory.

THE day after Lincoln's Birthday none of the leaders in the Atlanta headquarters of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference had read President Johnson's speech, at the Lincoln Memorial, likening himself to the Civil War President. Johnson had said that, like Lincoln, he, too, was "sad and steady."

ACAPULCO, Mexico -- The rich nomads who have given Acapulco what glamour it has achieved in recent years are neither hermits nor homebodies. Yet aside from an occasional shopping spree, they aren't out on the town giving the masses of tourists something to talk about.
DETROIT -- Evolution, not revolution, is Detroit's formula for success. Most of the changes on the 1968 autos are evolutionary: the new models are a little longer, engines a little more powerful.
