A LARGE number of excellent roses were grown by the early colonists. Many are classics in the rose world today and have historical associations which date to the Greeks and Romans. SAIGON, South Vietnam -- At a pool several weeks ago in a Bangkok hotel, a young American official on a brief holiday from Vietnam turned from the pretty girls splashing in the water to another Vietnam visitor. "I think I'm going back to the states," the official said. "I think I've just about had it in Vietnam."

ALBANY, March 30 -- The majority Republicans in the State Senate rammed a hastily drafted budget package through early today after an all-night session and went home to wait for the next bargaining move from the Democratic-controlled Assembly.

STOCKHOLM, March 30 -- Nine Western nations ignored objections by France today and went ahead without her to reform the world monetary system. The program would eventually create new reserve assets, popularly called paper gold.

Ambassadors of foreign powers thought pleasant relationships with mistresses as important as relationships with those who wore the crown and with their foreign secretaries. Some mistresses were much talked about and their influence was considerable.

OTTAWA, March 30 -- Twenty-five hundred delegates will meet in Ottawa's new Civic Center Thursday to choose a successor to Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson as Liberal party leader. The first ballot is scheduled for next Saturday afternoon.
DETROIT, March 30 -- Black separatists, who hope to form an all-Negro nation in five Southern states, voted today to affirm "the principle that we are not citizens of the United States."

TAKE 1: Uta Hagen, actress, appearing onstage for the first time in six years in Eva LeGallienne's APA revival of "The Cherry Orchard," Reclining on a chaise longue that has seen happier days, smoking a sad brown cigarette, laughing a throaty croak in a voice somewhere south of Marjorie Main's, and draping her beige chiffon gown about her legs with one last ounce of aristocratic dignity before the ax falls on Madame Ranevskaya's cherry trees.
MOSCOW, March 30 -- The head of the writers' organization here demanded today that Moscow writers who were party members improve ideological supervision over their work.

Capt. Howard B. Levy, the Brooklyn Army physician who was sentenced to three years at hard labor last June for refusing to train medical aidmen for Vietnam, is in "disciplinary segregation" at Fort Leavenworth, Kan., the Army said yesterday.

SINCE 1936, A. J. (Stub) Farlow has ridden his bucking bronco, Deadman, on the license plates carried by Wyoming cars. Deadman was a famous rodeo horse, and Farlow, a rodeo star, during World War I.

A WEST COAST businessman was recently transferred to his concern's East Coast headquarters. When he applied for a license for his car, which had been shipped east, he was informed that it would first have to pass safety inspection.

New York's listener-supported radio station, WBAI, will move to new quarters in lower Manhattan at the end of the year and begin stereo broadcasts, its station manager, Frank Millspaugh Jr. announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- There was a knock on the door and a slim dark figure opened it, came in and closed it quietly behind him. It was Richard Nixon.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, March 31 (AP) -- President Nguyen Van Thieu announced today that South Vietnam would order a general mobilization this fall if the Vietcong continued their attacks. HONG KONG, March 30 -- During seven months of Communist-inspired rioting here last year only 51 persons lost their lives. The police were highly praised for their well-disciplined handling of the disturbances.

Artur Rubinstein, who had recorded all the Nocturnes for RCA Victor in mono in the nineteen-fifties, has now recorded the set anew in stereo and, well, he's done it again.

Elly Ney, reportedly a descendant of Marshal Michel Ney, commander of Napoleon's Old Guard, was known in Europe as "the female Paderewski." She made her American debut at Carnegie Hall in October, 1921.

SAIGON, April 1 -- High American military officials hinted this morning that the F-111A fighter - bombers might be grounded until an investigation was completed of the loss of two of the planes in a week.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 -- The Philadelphia 76ers, showing why they are champions of the National Basketball Association, routed the New York Knickerbockers today, 123-105, and took a 3-2 lead in the four-of-seven-game opening-round playoff series.

THE UNITED STATES international team defeated a strong New York foursome Friday night in a short exhibition match at Darien, Conn. The organization by the Darien Community Association was of high quality and included the best closed circuit television representation of the players in action ever provided on such an occasion.
JERICHO, L. I., March 31 -The word was Dutch at the Jericho School of Horsemanship horse show today and Harry deLeyer spelled it out loud and clear.

MILWAUKEE, March 31 -- "I suppose the low point of that debate in 1949 on medical care," Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said yesterday at a luncheon of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, "was when the undertakers testified against it on the grounds that it would disturb the traditional doctor-patient relationship."

New York's musical intelligentsia turned out last night at Carnegie Recital Hall for what was designated on the program as "Roger Sessions's Birthday Concert." ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31 -- For the third time in a week and the sixth time in 23 games, the New York Mets played nine innings today without scoring a run.

The University of Southern California retired as undefeated champions of the "G.E. College Bowl" by winning for the fifth successive time yesterday over the National Broadcasting Company's television network. The four-member U.S.C. team defeated a Dartmouth College quartet 290 to 220, becoming the second team to retire undefeated this season.

CAIRO, March 31 -- Can a policeman's daughter from a placid Cairo suburb find happiness as the featured belly dancer at the world-famous Shepheard's Hotel? Yes. indeed, said Zizi Mustafa, not even breathing hard after she finished her act at the Nileside hotel the other night and the applause died away.

His voice is low and husky, a smoker's voice, and he uses it to give nuances to cliches.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The 10 per cent tax surcharge, coupled with a mandatory cut of $6-billion in Government spending and strict controls on hiring Government employes, passed the Senate today by a vote of 53 to 35.
ALBANY, Wednesday, April 3 -- The Republican and Democratic blocs defied Governor Rockefeller this morning to press for passage in the Assembly of their unorthodox plan to balance the state's budget.
In technical rallies, silver futures tried to rise yesterday but the buying flurry petered out and prices edged down by the close.

ONE day long before Zambia was free, Kenneth D. Kaunda was in London for a constitutional conference, where he sat across from his arch political foe, Sir Roy Welensky, Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland.
DETROIT, April 2 -- Consumers are not in a big buying mood, according to the University of Michigan's quarterly report on consumer attitudes and inclinations to buy.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 2 -- Texas Democratic leaders opened a favorite son Presidential drive today for Gov. John B. Connally Jr. There was a broad hint that it might be a holding action for Vice President Humphrey.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 3 -- Navy warplanes, on the second day after President Johnson's order curtailing air action over North Vietnam, have made bombing attacks on a railroad siding about 220 miles north of the demilitarized zone.

A dispute in the waterfront industry on the proposed adding of 600 longshoremen to the port's cargo-handling force was argued yesterday before five judges of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.
JERUSALEM, April 2 -- More than 1,000 businessmen and trade experts, half of them from abroad, are meeting here for a four-day conference that may set a new course for Israeli industry.

PETULA CLARK, England's high priestess of the beat, received last night one of the accolades of American show business: an hour-long television special of her own. Hollywood and the National Broadcasting Company may have rushed her progress.

The Senate has complied with President Johnson's plea for responsible fiscal policy to sustain prosperity and to safeguard the dollar. Mills of the House Ways and Means Committee, who has adamantly opposed raising taxes until the White House agrees to make sizable reductions in its spending.
Four days after disclosing initial sales totaling $2.16-billion for its "airbus" jet transport, the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation added a new customer yesterday, Delta Air Lines.
LUSAKA, Zambia -- Zambia's black leaders see themselves menaced by the white-ruled regimes to the south, east and west.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Reacting to a wide wave of criticism of its peace moves, the Johnson Administration identified the 20th Parallel in North Vietnam today as the line north of which it had halted all air and naval bombardment.
The men's wear industry's new emphasis on fashion is spurring controversy these days and stirring some sharp conflicts of opinion within the trade.

LANSING, Mich., April 2 -- Gov. George Romney called Senators Robert F. Kennedy and Eugene J. McCarthy "pipers of peace at any price" today. Their proposals for peace in South Vietnam, he said, amount to "surrender to the enemy."

WASHINGTON, April 2 -Federal officials told Congressional investigators today that procedures were being strengthened to curtail the resale to consumers of unsafe or unwholesome food and drugs that had been rejected by Federal purchasing agents.
The appointment of Frank E. McKinney as Ambassador to Spain represents an atavistic foreign policy, not a progressive one. It appears to be more of a political appointment than a diplomatic one.
The Conservative party State Committee designated James L. Buckley, a brother of William F. Buckley Jr., by acclamation last night as its candidate for the United States Senate.

SAPPORO, Japan, April 2 (UPI) -- Paul Fuji, the world junior welterweight champion, improved his stature in the fight world by scoring a quick knockout over the former world champion, Roberto Cruz of the Philippines, in a nontitle bout tonight.
The securities industry has joined the 10 member banks of the New York Clearing House Association to launch the first massive, broad-scale effort to solve mutual operating problems.
THE plea that conglomerate companies should be permitted to keep their divisional results to themselves does not impress Prof. Abraham J. Briloff.
Milton Esterow, a reporter in the cultural news department of The New York Times, was named yesterday by the Society of Silurians as the winner of its annual award for the best feature story.

Charles V. Lazarus, president of the American Retail Federation, yesterday warned a convention of discounters here that action and legislation aimed at protecting consumers would increase and that retailing must thereby improve its "weak and insignificant relationship" with government.

Americans of Italian Descent, Inc., a two-year-old group headed by entertainer Frank Sinatra, said yesterday that it had halted its campaign of opposing ethnic slurs and, in its place, has adopted a more positive program.

Last Sunday, The Peoria (Ill.) Journal Star ran a page-size, H-shaped ad with feature stories filling in the space above and below the cross bar. Next Sunday an ad shaped like an exclamation point will be surrounded by features.
The Elgin National Watch Company yesterday announced the resignation of Jerome W. Robbins as president and a director. There was no immediate explanation of the move.

The stock market extended Monday's boisterous rally yesterday as prices rose in irregular fashion in heavy trading.

First-quarter earnings reports from the nation's major banks started to pour in yesterday. They made pleasant reading for bank shareholders.

The organizers of an investment group are seeking to raise $2,583,000 from other investors to complete the purchase of the 21-story office building at 501 Fifth Avenue, on the southeast corner of the avenue at 42d Street.

The State Investigation Commission sharply criticized the city yesterday, saying that long-standing faults in its hospital system could be corrected despite red tape and chronic shortages of funds, personnel and equipment.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- A Japanese gift of 3,800 young cherry trees will be used as part of new plans for the beautification of Washington's Central Mall, Ambassador Takeso Shimoda said today at the opening of the 1968 National Cherry Blossom Festival.

The Columbia Broadcasting System and the New York Rangers met head-on in an unscheduled contest of wills yesterday, and the network came out on top.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Four National Guard and Army Reserve brigades that are under priority consideration by the Defense Department for mobilization suffer from substantial shortages of weapons and transportation and communications equipment, informed sources said today.

Permit me to point out that rioting and acts of violence, such as are now being witnessed, seem to be the order of the day. Isn't it strange that even during the great depression of the Thirties, those without jobs, and thousands in the breadlines, did not riot?
Mayor Lindsay has requested an extra month in which to work out the city s budget crisis.
It is getting tougher to recruit creative people for industrial advertising agencies, according to William A. Cather. He should know, he's in the business.

ONE way to enter the esoteric field of professional dog show superintending is to have the desire and the cash at a time that a going organization is for sale while the aspirant is immobilized by a strike. That's the way Theodore N. Bloomberg of Youngstown, Ohio, became head of the Bow Dog Show Organization of Detroit.
LANDING ZONE STUD, South Vietnam, April 3 -American units advancing along Route 9 are convinced that an enemy counter-attack is in the offing.

ARECIBO, P. R. -- In a controlroom atmosphere more like that of science fiction than sober reality, scientists manning the world's largest dish antenna here are enlarging human knowledge of the strange, newly discovered radio signals from space.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Administration is eager to talk to North Vietnam about Hanoi's latest peace proposals, but it is frankly suspicious that it is merely being invited to talk about ending the war on the enemy's terms.
Man o' War should "gallop" in Saturday's computerized Race of the Century, his 84-year-old trainer predicted yesterday.
Art purchasers paid $3,044,500 for 95 paintings and sculptures last night in an auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries. It was a record outlay for a sale of this type.
Prices moved up sharply in lively early trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The pace slowed in later trading and a number of issues closed below their highs for the day.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 3 -The New York Mets flew west today after their least successful spring training season in Florida. They won only six games, lost 18, tied one hit only six home runs and left few footprints on the sands of baseball.
WESTBURY, L.I., April 3--The Westbury Junior High School reopened today and classes at the high school were expected to resume tomorrow as racial tensions eased in the school district.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 4 -North Vietnam's expression of readiness to meet with United States representatives to discuss the complete cessation of bombing raids is viewed by Japanese political analysts as a setback for Peking.
Peggy Gale Fleming, an elfin teen-ager from Colorado Springs who won the only gold medal achieved by United States athletes at the Winter Olympics, will lace her figure skates for money hereafter.
PALO ALTO, Calif., April 3 -- The Municipal Council of East Palo Alto, a community with a Negro majority, has voted to hold a public hearing on a proposal to change its name to Nairobi.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange soared to a record of 19.29 million shares yesterday as investors bid up prices amid renewed prospects for peace in Vietnam.
PARIS, April 3 -- Leftist "student power" advocates have scored their first victory in a drive to mix politics and teaching on French university campuses.
To Mrs. Russell Eisenberg of Milwaukee, Hanoi s response yesterday to President Johnson's peace offer brought "goose bumps."
ALBANY, April 3 -- The Assembly rejected today, after five hours of emotional debate, an attempt to reform the state's 85-year-old abortion law.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 3 -- Secretary General Thant said today that he hoped that talks between North Vietnam and the United States would "constitute a positive first step toward ending the tragic conflict in Vietnam."

A MONTAGE of a dove covered the Christmas cards sent last year by Dr. Frederick Seitz, the physicist elected yesterday to the presidency of Rockefeller University. "It was an enormous card and it represented his artistic flair," a longtime associate said yester day.
THERE was no particular excitement along Wall Street yesterday morning an hour before trading began. Traders were still basking in the afterglow of two profitable days.
WORCESTER, Mass., April 3 -- "We're going to change about 80 labels in our collection of 321 European paintings," said Daniel Catton Rich, director of the Worcester Art Museum.
Frictions between the United States and France must not be allowed to endanger the economic and political bonds of the two nations, a leading French business spokesman declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Charles L. Schultze, former director of the Bureau of the Budget, has been named chairman of the council advising the Administration on the Medicare program, it was announced today by Wilbur J. Cohen, Secretary-designate of Health, Education and Welfare.
Senator Jacob K. Javits came under attack from a Liberal and a Conservative yesterday as the Senate race in New York took more definite shape.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -With a nearly unanimous voice, Republicans and Democrats and hawks and doves in Congress gave support today to acceptance of Hanoi's call for discussion of a cessation of the bombing.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 3 -- Aides of Gov. Ronald Reagan reacted quickly today with a formal contradiction of widely distributed information that he was thinking of retiring from politics.
The Ford Foundation plans to spend $20-million to $25 million in the coming year on expanding and diversifying noncommercial television and radio.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- A joint Senate-House conference committee went to work promptly today in an attempt to work out a compromise on tax legislation. But it reported no progress after a 2 1/2-hour session and adjourned until Friday.
LONDON, April 3 -- The Government announced today details of tougher policies to hold increases in wages, salaries and dividends to 3.5 per cent a year.
PRAGUE, April 3--Gen. Bohumir Lomsky, the Czechoslovak Defense Minister, offered his resignation today at a plenary meeting of the Central Committee of the Communist party.
WHITE PLAINS, April 3 -All 11 public schools here were closed today after the third demonstration in a week for greater recognition of Negroes.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 3 -- A Nobel Prize-winning chemist has reported that a fifth state of matter may have been attained in recent experiments.

Angel Cordero, the humming rider from Puerto Rico, swung into the proper rhythm of things at Aqueduct yesterday. He thrilled the crowd of 28,945 spectators by recording "two and a half" victories. In three consecutive races he won all by himself on a 4-to-1 shot, participated in a dead heat on a 7 to 1 chance, then took the feature of the day, the $27,750 Prioress, on Lloyd Miller's Dark Mirage, at $14 for $2.

MOSCOW, April 3 -- After a delay of several hours, the Soviet press agency Tass transmitted tonight without comment excerpts from the North Vietnamese Government's statement on its willingness to meet with United States' representatives to discuss a complete cessation of bombing.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- The United States Track and Field Federation asked the Justice Department today for an antitrust investigation of the Amateur Athletic Union and threatened to go to court next week to try to break the A.A.U.'s control over track competition.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- North Vietnam, though shifting its tactical position to agree to meet with American representatives, showed no change today in its basic terms for a peaceful settlement of the war in Vietnam.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 3 -- A major offensive aimed at relieving the isolated Marine fortress at Khesanh has been opened by American and South Vietnamese troops, the military command said tonight.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 3 -- Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said today that South Vietnamese would never accept a coalition government with the Vietcong as a condition for peace.
PARIS, April 3 -- President de Gaulle saluted President Johnson today for "an act of reason and political courage" in limiting the bombing of North Vietnam.
The men who move most of the household and office furniture in New York, Long Island, and part of Westchester voted yesterday to end a strike against 300 employers that began March 1.

Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, cautioned yesterday that wildly racist threats by Negro extremists were being used to justify riot-control measures that were tantamount to warfare.

The Most Rev. Terence J. Cooke was installed as the seventh Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York yesterday in a historic pageant attended by the President of the United States and highlighted by prayers for the success of his peace efforts in Vietnam.
Disorders broke out in scattered parts of the nation last night after the slaying of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The National Guard was called out or alerted in several cities.

TOKYO, April 4 -- The spokesman of the Foreign Ministry said today that a reappraisal of Japan's policy toward Communist China, which adheres closely to that of the United States, might follow a settlement in Vietnam.

GREENSBORO, N. C., April 4 -- Billy Casper rejoined the pro tour today by equaling a nine-hole record and scoring a 65. The former United States Open champion was six under par to share the first-round lead of the $137,500 Greater Greensboro open with Julius Boros.

Wall Street sources said yesterday that the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange have taken the first steps toward new rules that would require their member organizations to submit regular monthly reports on "fail" transactions.

A crowded picket line called attention yesterday to what the Board of Education calls "one of the most overcrowded elementary schools in New York City." It is Public School 92 in the Bronx, at Clinton Avenue and 179th Street, in the East Tremont section.
President Johnson, known as a man who enjoys the unexpected, paid a four-and-a-half hour visit to New York yesterday that was marked by one surprise after another.
Dismay, shame, anger and foreboding marked the nation's reaction last night to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s murder.

" TUNC" is Lawrence Durrell's first novel since "Clea (1960), the final volume of his lush Levantine tetralogy, "The Alexandria Quartet." The central character of "Tunc" is a giant electronic computer, or memory bank, named Abel. When Abel is completed, it will not only store all information about everybody's past, but will be able to deduce everybody's destiny as well.

A former waterfront construction inspector for the Department of Marine and Aviation was charged with perjury yesterday as a grand jury continued its investigation of alleged Mafia penetration into city agencies and private businesses.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) -- The Civil Service Commission said today that most Federal employes were free to sign a petition protesting United States policy in Vietnam that Government workers have submitted to the White House.

" Inside Bedford-Stuyvesant," a half-hour program of neighborhood news, interview and entertainment television, produced by and for Negroes, will have its premiere Monday at 7 A.M. on WNEW-TV (Channel 5).
Higher prices were announced yesterday for some appliances and specialty steels, while lower rates were introduced for brass strip products.

A noisily delighted group of expatriate New York Ranger hockey fans gathered in Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum last night to cheer the Rangers in their 3-1 Stanley Cup triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks.
MANILA, April 4 -- President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines said today that the nations of Asia were "simply not organized to take advantage of our potential wealth."
Following is the text of Archbishop Terence J. Cooke's sermon:

ITHACA, N. Y., April 4 -- About 60 Negro students at Cornell University staged a seven-hour siege of the Economics Department office today and held the department chairman captive in a protest against asserted racist remarks in class by another professor.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4 -- South Vietnamese paratroopers clashed with a Vietcong squad two miles north of Saigon's Tansonnhut Airport for more than seven hours this morning, killing 12 of the enemy. A spokesman said that one Government paratrooper had been killed.

An energetic, talented and winning ensemble of young instrumentalists from Italy gave a concert at Town Hall last night for the benefit of the Casa Italiana of Columbia University. The 19 players were members of the Orchestra San Pietro of Naples and, theoretically at least, they were familiar here:
EASTERN anglers are responding to the eternal tug of spring.
JERUSALEM, April 4 -- A curtain of silence and fear has descended on the west-bank town of Ramallah after a shooting incident last week involving Israeli soldiers and three young Arabs.
PARIS, April 4 -- When President Johnson announced Sunday a reduction in the scope of the bombing of North Vietnam, the Hanoi regime was preparing for the opposite.
Several of the big variety and department-store and mail-order chains reported sharp gains in dollar volume yesterday for March over the 1967 period.

The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company has leased 30,000 square feet of space in the 42-story skyscraper going up on the site of the old Metropolitan Opera House, and will consolidate three of its garment-center branch offices there.
PHOENIX, Ariz., April 4 -- Wes Westrum, coaching at first base for the San Francisco Giants, watched in disbelief today as the New York Mets made their debut in the desert.

LONDON, April 4 -- The free-market price for gold dropped closer to the official monetary price of $35 an ounce today in continued favorable reaction to improved prospects of peace in Vietnam. Sterling was firm.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) -- A top lieutenant of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said tonight that the "poor people's crusade" in the nation's capital planned for later this month by Dr. King definitely would be held.

A recent letter [issue March 27] expressed bewilderment at the profusion of independent administrative districts in the city. Thousands of students who have applied for full-time freshman admission at senior and community colleges of the City University this fall will find it more difficult to gain acceptance at the schools they want to attend.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was the 14th American, the 3d Negro, and the youngest man to win the Nobel Peace Prize.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 4 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy, moved almost to tears by the death of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., told a street corner rally of Negroes tonight that they must strive for love, wisdom, understanding and compassion toward all men.

Groundskeepers and other maintenance personnel voted yesterday afternoon to strike Yankee Stadium and Shea Stadium, a move that could prevent the Yankees and the Mets from opening their home baseball seasons on schedule.
MEMPHIS, April 4 (AP) -- A Federal judge was told today that the Negro community was so worked up that another mass demonstration here next week could "be worse than Watts or worse than Detroit."
CLEVELAND, April 4 -- The Congress of Racial Equality proposed today a program aimed to make Negroes the owners of factories and stores.

Shadowed by the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., a concert was held at Carnegie Hall last night for the benefit of the library fund of Tougaloo College, a Negro institution in Mississippi.
The St. Nicholas Society will hold its 18th annual Paas Festival Ball on Aprii 19 in the Grand Ballroom at the Waldorf-Astoria.
Louis Wolfson, the financier, and his aide, Elkin H. Gerbert, yesterday asked the United States Court of Appeals here to set aside their stock fraud conviction.

WASHINGTON, Friday, April 5 -- Scattered but persistent looting and vandalism, led for a time by Stokely Carmichael, erupted in the nation's capital last night an hour after the death of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
The 83,000-ton superliner Queen Elizabeth, the largest commercial vessel in the world, has been sold by the Cunard Line to a group of businessmen in Philadelphia.
In Albany, Ga., in 1962, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was preaching in a small church after shots were fired into nearby houses.

DON'T look now but just back of you a new baseball season is tiptoeing into the starting gate with uncharacteristic lack of fanfare. At least it is uncharacteristic for New Yorkers, spoiled for generations by the dominating roles once assumed in days of old by Yankees, Giants and Dodgers. No longer can our village anticipate at least half or maybe an entire World Series played within its environs.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The United States began today the process of working out arrangements for the site and level of the direct talks with North Vietnam to which both Governments have agreed.

TRENTON, April 4 (UPI) -- The penetration of air freight operations by organized crime at New York and New Jersey airports is at its "beginning stages," and action should be taken now to prevent it from spreading, members of the Waterfront Commission of New York said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- The Post Office Department announced plans today for a $97-million increase each year in rates for parcel post and catalogues.

YONKERS, April 4 -- A recent survey disclosed that more than 300 standardbreds from New Zealand and Australia are in training and/or racing at various harness tracks in the United States. Of that number, 46 are at Yonkers Raceway, where four will go postward in tomorrow night's featured one-mile event for Class A-1 pacers.
A DEFENDER who finds that a "certain" trump trick had disappeared should congratulate the declarer and resign himself to appearing in print in the role of victim.

ERIE, Pa., April 4 (UPI) -- A group of about 50 Negro students, apparently in retaliation for the expulsion of two classmates, touched off a garbage and chair throwing melee in Erie Academy High School today, then carried the fight onto nearby streets.

ALBANY, April 4 -- The Legislature's top Democrat, Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia, indicated today that he would agree to a restoration of Governor Rockefeller's proposed gasoline and liquor tax increases. His agreement would be a means of breaking the state budget impasse between the Legislature and the Governor.
The London Stock Exchange edged ahead yesterday in moderate trading.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- One classic definition of a true diplomat is a man who keeps on talking, even with a nation with which his own country is no longer on speaking terms.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Construction activity continued to rise in February, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $81.3-billion, the Commerce Department reported today. The increase in the annual-rate figure from the January level was $800-million.

KHESANH, South Vietnam, Friday, April 5 (AP) -- United States Marines beat off an attack by about 40 charging North Vietnamese troops on the crest of a hill less than two miles from Khesanh early today only hours after having taken it over from enemy forces.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 4 (AP) -- Some 225 students from Bowie State College, most of them Negro were arrested today when they refused to leave the Maryland State House, where they had been protesting conditions at the college.
ALBANY, April 4 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that all buildings open to the public at night must have lighted entrances.

BECAUSE Peter Sellers is an excellent actor who just happens to have great skill at comedy, rather than a comedian with a continuing, easily recognizable character, he is at a loss in something as flimsy as "The Party."

LAUNAY, France -- By their last elections and a continuing political crisis the Belgians seem intent on demonstrating to the world that there is no such country as Belgium. A Socialist Minister named Jules Destree told King Albert after World War I: "Sire, there are no Belgians -- only Flemings and Walloons."

CLEVELAND, April 4 -- Floyd B. McKissick, national director of the Congress of Racial Equality, said tonight that the death of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. meant the end of the nonviolent philosophy.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 4 -Gov. Richard J. Hughes was designated by the state Democratic party today as New Jersey's favorite-son candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

WITH U.S. FORCES, advancing on Khesanh, South Vietnam, April 4 -- American infanward combat base today in trymen marched out of a for-their drive toward the beleaguered Marine outpost at Khesanh, just three miles away.

SAN ANTONIO, April 4 -- There are only three things that are Texas-size about HemisFair, the international exposition that opens here Saturday: The theme, "The Confluence of Civilization in the Americas;" the handsome 622-foot Tower of the Americas built as the tallest observation tower in the Western Hemisphere; and the $10-million Texas Pavilion.

NEW ORLEANS, April 4 (AP) -- Clay L. Shaw must stand trial in New Orleans on charges of plotting to assassinate President Kennedy, a Criminal District Court judge ruled today in denying a change of venue.
SAN JUAN, P. R., April 4 (AP) -- The bow of the oil tanker Ocean Eagle, which broke apart in San Juan Harbor a month ago, was pulled out to sea today.
The fourth annual Andy Awards dinner of the Advertising Club of New York, held last night in the New York Hilton, was not without its moment of unexpected drama.

LONDON, April 4 -- Paris, Pnompenh and Warsaw were mentioned by a North Vietnamese journalist as places where preliminary talks between the United States and North Vietnam could be held. The journalist, Nguyen Van Sao, of Cuuquoc, a Hanoi weekly, was interviewed by a British Broadcasting Corporation commentator.

PLEASANT, often gently ingratiating, "The Education of H*Y*M*A*N K*A*PL*A*N," which arrived at the Alvin Theater last night, is a modest musical. Of course, as Winston Churchill once said of Clement Attlee, it has quite a lot to be modest about.
New York magazine, a slick-paper, 40-cent, weekly successor to the former Sunday supplement of the New York Herald Tribune, appeared on the newsstands yesterday.
PANAMA, Friday, April 5, (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled early today that the impeachment process against President Marco A. Robles was illegal.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 4 -- The Saturn 5 moon rocket ran into one engine problem after another on its unmanned flight today and apparently failed to qualify for manned missions without further testing.

With a team effort remarkable for its efficiency, pounding, skating and defense, the Rangers won the opening game of their Stanley Cup quarter-final playoffs with the Chicago Black Hawks last night, 3-1.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) -- The House passed today a travel tax measure that dropped all but the mildest of President Johnson's plans to keep American tourists home.

The board of governors of the West Side Tennis Club, site of the national tennis singles championships annually since 1923, voted unanimously last night to welcome an open tournament this year, pending negotiations with the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4 -- United States officials here are becoming increasingly concerned over the quiet but bitter reaction of South Vietnam's Government to Washington's new peace efforts.

WHITE PLAINS, April 4 -- More than 200 boycotting Negro students and their few white allies returned to classes at White Plains High School today after winning demands that Negro history and culture be made a regular part of the academic program.

The United States Steel Corporation disclosed yesterday the design of a 54-story office tower that it will erect on Lower Broadway, and the executive director of the City Planning Commission hailed the project as "a great planning achievement."

McCarthy for Presidential nomination said today he would file a Federal lawsuit here next week challenging the constitutionality of the allocation of voting strength to the state delegations at the Democratic National Convention in August.

PRAGUE, April 4 -- The Czechoslovak Communist party today recast its ruling body, the Presidium of the Central Committee, and named a new Premier, who will head a new Cabinet.

THERE were few, if any, fashion pace-setters among the 350 women at the Plaza Hotel attending the benefit show yesterday for the Thrift Shop of The New York Hospital. The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was killed as his organization, the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, was preparing its largest demonstration for Negro rights -- the Poor People's Campaign scheduled to begin in Washington on April 22.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 4 (AP) -- Howard Hughes, who is estimated to have spent $125-million in Las Vegas in one year, has expanded his empire to the historic gold and silver mining land in northern Nevada.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 4 -- All three Democratic candidates in Indiana's pivotal Presidential primary are wooing the Negro vote, but the forces of Senator Robert F. Kennedy have been most ardent about it.

OTTAWA, April 4 -- Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson, who came to power five years ago, bade farewell to his Liberal party colleagues tonight.

JOHN BARBIROLLI, always a welcome guest, directed the New York Philharmonic last night and, as usual, programed some music by British composers. There were Alan Rawsthorne's "Street Corner" Overture and the Vaughan Williams "London" Symphony to represent the British 20th - century school.

The First National City Bank, the most profitable in New York City, reported yesterday that its net operating earnings in the quarter to March 31 had risen by 16 per cent to $33,404,000, or $1.25 a share.
The Franklin National Bank announced yesterday that it had abandoned its plans to form a statewide bank holding company because of opposition from the Controller of the Currency.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 4 -- Two new techniques for automatic and rapid detection of bacterial contamination of water supplies were reported here today.

BOSTON, April 4 -- The incidence of malaria and deaths from the disease among American troops in South Vietnam are dropping, but the malady remains a serious medical problem in the war zone, a group of military surgeons said today.

BOSTON, April 4 (AP) -- The career of the Boston Red Sox slugger, Tony Conigliaro, appeared ended today with a medical report that the young outfielder's vision in his left eye is deteriorating.
The Propeller Club of the United States is urging that Congress continue the Army Corps of Engineers in its role as maintainer and improver of the nation's navigation channel and ports.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -Representative Melvin R. Laird predicted today that Senator Robert F. Kennedy would be harder for the Republican Presidential candidate to beat than President Johnson.
MEMPHIS, Friday, April 5 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who preached nonviolence and racial brotherhood, was fatally shot here last night by a distant gunman who then raced away and escaped.

WARSAW, April 4 -- The chief of the Polish atomic energy agency and another high Government official were dismissed today. The press, meanwhile, indirectly criticized members of the Communist party's ruling Politburo for the first time.

Pearson as Prime Minister.

" PAINTING IN FRANCE, 1900-1967," the new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum, opens with a bang and ends with just about the saddest little whimper imaginable. A quick trot through the galleries, which are filled with great big bright paintings, gives the impression that this is a great show.

ONE of the outstanding events of the New York theater season has been Michael Cacoyannis's staging of "Iphigenia in Aulis" for the Circle in the Square on Bleecker Street. The most human of all Euripides tragedies and also, with its themes of war, peace and justice, the most relevant to our own time, this "Iphigenia" seems to strike home to us today with the deadly, biting force of an arrow.

FORCES, Near Khesanh, South Vietnam, April 5 -- As relief troops moved within a few thousand yards of the Marine outpost of Khesanh, military spokesmen suggested that the North Vietnamese soldiers who had besieged the base were either drifting into nearby Laos or falling farther back into northern Quangtri Province.
Prices backed down slightly yesterday in reduced volume on the American Stock Exchange.

Hearing those two works side by side was asinstructive as it was entertaining.

OUT of the bewildering confusion of recent days there is an overdue development of more than passing significance in broadcasting. The radio medium, so often relegated to a secondary role behind the more vivid appeal of television, is showing renewed signs of vitality and importance.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Thursday, April 11 -- Five persons were killed here last night as violence exploded again on the Negro East Side. At least 10 were wounded as the police and National Guardsmen exchanged gunfire with snipers.
MINEOLA, L. I., April 10 -- A suit by Nassau County against the Metropolitan Transportation Authority over its recent fare increase for the Long Island Rail Road was dismissed today.
The 1968 model of the New York Yankees, unveiled at Yankee Stadium yesterday, proved to be a marvel of efficiency in a 1-0 victory over the California Angels with a little human warmth added.
ALBANY, April 10 -- Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson charged today that Republican Senator Jacob K. Javits "has been on all sides of every issue," and challenged the Senator to a debate.
The Shubert theater interests demanded yesterday that the city deny the applications of two competitors for permits to build theater-office structures on Broadway.

BALTIMORE, April 10 (AP) -- Don Buford, given a starting chance after Mark Belanger was called for National Guard duty, starred at bat and in the field as Baltimore defeated the Athletics, 3-1, in Oakland's American League baseball debut today.
Walter Ward, a Queens advertising executive, was elected by the City Council yesterday to fill the vacancy in the 17th Councilmanic District of Queens.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 -- Gil Hodges directed his first game from the front trenches today as manager of the New York Mets, and found out in one stunning inning what the legend was all about.

CAIRO, April 10 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser announced today that the United Arab Republic was "fully prepared to support and arm the Palestine resistance movement" in its guerrilla operations against Israel.
A record volume of 20.41 million shares deluged the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, causing the ticker tape to run as much as 41 minutes late and snarling communications in the Wall Street area.

I LOVED him when he was Cagney, I would obviously have loved him when he was Cohan, himself and, yes, at the Palace Theater last night I loved him when he was Joel Grey. I'm just a sucker for the style -- it involves all that nostalgia for bright lights and Broadway that only a Hollywood-nurtured European can really savo to the full.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey hurled the opening pitch today as the baseball season began two days late following national mourning for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

JACKSON, Miss., April 10 -- Ten white men, including a lawyer and a state official of the Ku Klux Klan, were indicted today by the Hinds County grand jury in a racially connected bombing here last year.

Since it is not possible to discuss a song recital by Nicolai Gedda without using the words "style" and "taste," let them be put down at once. He has style and taste. Ordinary tenors, and even some better than ordinary ones, let one know when they are expressing deep emotion by (1) suddenly taking two or three quick steps away from the piano, or (2) clenching a fist.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) -- Reacting to six days of street violence, the Senate refused today to accept House action that eliminated all funds sought by President Johnson for a summer job program in the nation's slums.

TO the duplicate player all part scores are worth just 50 points, but this is far from true at rubber bridge. The real value of a part score is closer to 100 points in most situations, and when both sides are vulnerable a value of 200 is suggested by some authorities.
Six thousand pupils were kept out of eight schools in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville section of Brooklyn by their parents yesterday to support demands for community control of the schools.

The first application of the new anti-spitball rule created a little heat at Yankee Stadium yesterday, but quickly cooled into a historical footnote as its potential effect on a close game evaporated.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Following is the transcript of President Johnson's news conference in his office today and of a statement the President read after the news conference in the Fish Room:

The Celanese Corporation showed a sharp gain in the first quarter of this year with a record net income of $16.5-million, equal to $1.16 a share, 14 per cent above the $14.7-million, or $1.02 a share, in the first three months of 1967.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies announced yesterday plans to build a $15-million home for the aged linked physically and professionally with a psychiatric institution and a general hospital.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Draft Rockefeller Committee being organized by Senator Thruston Morton of Kentucky, among others, is the logical development of the political strategy adopted by the Governor of New York when he announced on March 21 that he would not be an active Presidential candidate.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 10 -- North Vietnamese troops and equipment have continued to pour into South Vietnam in a maximum effort during the 10 days since President Johnson announced his curtailment of bombing, according to preliminary intelligence reports.

TRW, Inc., diversified electronics, automobile parts and aircraft components producer, agreed in principle yesterday to acquire the United-Greenfield Corporation, Northbrook, Ill., producer of metal-working tools, in exchange for stock worth $130-million.

A 71 per cent increase in accidents on the nation's railroads in the last six years may require additional regulatory authority, according to a report by Joseph J. O'Connell Jr., chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board.

A former businessman now in the National Administration said yesterday that if the country was serious about preventing riots and looting it must give up half the annual increase in the things that improved Americans' level of living and use the sums for schools, housing, day care centers and health.

ALBANY, April 10 -- Governor Rockefeller disclosed today that he had forced the passage of his $6-billion slum-rebuilding program in the Assembly last night by threatening to stop doing "personal favors" for the legislators, such as signing their pet bills and appointing their friends to jobs.

ATLANTA, April 10 -- The Rev. Ralph D. Abernathy, the man the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. wanted as his successor, took over officially today as president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 10 -- "In the Heat of the Night," a detective drama set against the background of racial conflict in the Deep South, was named the best film of 1967 tonight at the 40th annual awards presentations of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

The world's two largest electrical-equipment manufacturers -- the General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation -- got off to strong starts this year, according to first-quarter financial results disclosed yesterday.
Two major sets of journalistic prizes were announced yesterday by the Overseas Press Club and the Newspaper Guild of New York City.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Lawrence F. O'Brien resigned today as Postmaster General, and President Johnson named W. Marvin Watson, Presidential Appointments Secretary, to succeed him.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 -- "There are 20 players capable of winning the Masters," insisted Gay Brewer today. Brewer speculated that the rain-drenched course and slow greens would affect the play starting over the Augusta National Golf Club course tomorrow, favoring the long hitters.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 10 -- United States officials conferred with the North Vietnamese today and said later that a meeting place for preparatory talks for a conference to end the war in Vietnam would be decided upon in two or three days.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 10 -- A college professor urged Negro students tonight to "develop black community control over the long term" as their principal response to riots and rebellion.

JERSEY CITY, April 10 -- Consolidated sales and profits of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company in the first quarter are "expected to set records," A. H. Galloway, president and chief executive officer, told the annual meeting today.
Which crop report do wheat traders follow? Apparently they follow two -- a private one and another the Government issues.
CAIRO, April 10 -- An American computer will soon be helping to disseminate President Gamal Abdel Nasser's views throughout the Arab world in the pages of the authoritative Cairo newspaper Al Ahram.
Stock prices soared in an explosive opening rally yesterday morning, then lost a large part of their gains in a steady afternoon retreat.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Whatever his economic status, the white American remains a respecter of property. Indeed, the sanctity he ascribes to property partakes of the same reverence he grants his flag. To see it violated angers and hurts him at some point in his inner being.
OMAHA, April 10 (UPI) -Senator Eugene J. McCarthy called today for a better farm bargaining program so such pressure tactics as those used by the National Farmers Organization need not be employed.
BUFFALO, April 10 -- Standing next to the charred remnants of a children's clothing store display window, a Negro young man shook his head today and said: "Bums. They want something for nothing."

ALBANY, April 10 -- The Court of Appeals today laid down a new rule on the procedure that courts must follow in imposing indeterminate sentences of one day to life.

WASHINGTON, April 10--Cyrus R. Vance, former Deputy Secretary of Defense and Presidential troubleshooter on both foreign and domestic affairs, has been chosen by President Johnson to join the American delegation to preliminary talks with North Vietnam.
A MOST elegant setting was the smash windup of the Nimzo-Indian Defense, Y. Kraidman vs. Y. Bernstein in the 14th Israel championship. The game was awarded the brilliancy prize.

The Italian showcase for the actors, which opened yesterday at the 55th Sweet Playhouse, is anything but fine.

MEXICO CITY, Thursday, April 11 (UPI) -- A twin-engine plane carrying 20 persons, including some government officials, on the first flight of a new airline crashed in mountains 60 miles north of Mexico City yesterday, officials said today.
NEWARK, Thursday, April 11 -- Antipoverty workers, enforcing a curfew they had encouraged the police to impose, cleared South Ward streets last night after a limited outbreak of looting and fire.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A Presidential review committee will recommend the principle of binding arbitration as an alternative to the right to strike for Federal employes.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 11 -- Fifty-three per cent of the persons interviewed in a recent Gallup Poll say churches should avoid involvement in political and social issues while 43 per cent feel they should speak out on them.

THE United States entry will be the clear favorite in the World Women's Team Championship in Deauville, France, in June. Y., and Emma Jean Hawes of Fort Worth, together with Peggy Solomon of Philadelphia and Mary Jane Farell of Los Angeles.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 11 -- Hofstra University announced today the appointment of Malachy T. Mahon as dean of its law school, effective Aug. 1.

The jazz quartet Booker Ervin brought to the Donnell Library Center last night spent most of its hour and a half proving its capability, but it was unable to rise above routine.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The mysterious pulsars, sources of radio pulses of extreme regularity, may be stars of extraordinary density spinning at incredible speeds, according to an explanation made here today by two theorists.

As promised, Ketchum, MacLeod Grove today unveils its new creative director: Arthur H. Hawkins 3d, former creative director at West, Weir Bartel.

CAIRO, April 11 -- Highly placed Egyptian sources reported today that Israel had approved a formula worked out by Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring for acceptance of the United Nations resolution on the Middle East.

With the week-long observance of the Festival of Passover beginning tonight, Jewish religious leaders yesterday compared the tribulations of the ancient Israelites under Egyptian rule to the American Negro's struggle for full equality.

LONDON, April 11 -- Britain's trade gap in March was the worst since devaluation of the pound, Government figures showed today. Imports exceeded exports by u103-million, or about $247-million compared with a u73-million deficit in February.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11 -- First impressions are often lasting in golf. Marvin Vinny Giles, a 25-year-old University of Virginia law student, ran in a 30-foot birdie putt at the first hole in his first Masters tourney today.
Secret Service agents have seized $300,000 in counterfeit $5 and $10 bills and the photo-offset equipment used to produce them in a small Brooklyn printing shop.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

DURING pregame ceremonies at the Yankee Stadium opener the other day, a handsome bronze plaque was presented to Mickey Mantle by Steve Hamilton, the player representative. The Mick did not keep it long enough for more than a cursory glance. If he wants to study it carefully, he will have to climb into the right-field stands because that is where it will be placed.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Administration said today that peace in Vietnam would not substantially reduce military spending for some time and urged an immediate tax increase to head off an even greater budgetary deficit than estimated by the President last January.

The Poetry Society of America last night paid a 50th anniversary tribute to the Pulitzer Prizes in poetry, which the society inspired and financed for several years.
A nationwide review of the summer-job prospects in the Neighborhood Youth Corps indicates they will equal last summer's total, despite an earlier threat of a 25 per cent reduction.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The pattern of rising sales and shrinking profits continued among manufacturing corporations in the last quarter of 1967. And the rate of profit on stockholders' equity also declined in each of the four quarters last year.

WASHINGTON, April 11-Rail freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended April 6 was below the volume in the corresponding week of 1967. Intercity truck tonnage in the corresponding period registered a gain.
WARSAW, April 11 -- The political fortunes of Defense Minister Marian Spychalski, who was named Poland's Chief of State today, have ebbed and flowed.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 12 -- The Vietcong mounted a heavy assault early today against a unit of the United States 25th Infantry Division about 50 miles northwest of Saigon, but were thrown back by a ground, air and artillery counterattack.

Marine insurance underwriting groups in Britain, West Germany and in Scandinavian countries have agreed to pay claims by shipowners whose vessels have been trapped in the Suez Canal as a result of the six-day Arab-Israeli war last June.
The second day of a parent boycott kept 5,700 pupils out of school yesterday in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville section of Brooklyn. The parents are demanding community control of the schools.

PARIS, April 12 -- The French Government was reported today to have signed a contract to let Iraq have 54 French Mirage supersonic fighter bombers.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Army National Guard and Army Reserve enlisted men whose reserve obligation expires on or before Dec. 12, 1968, will be exempted from the limited mobilization announced yesterday, Defense Department officials said today.

A West German chemical executive whose company derives half its $1.6-billion annual business from international operations cautioned this week that trade restrictions were not the way to solve the United States balance-of-payments problem.

Mediation of a salary dispute involving the faculty of the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L. I., and the Maritime Adminstration and the Department of Commerce is scheduled to get under way next week.

NEW DELHI, April 12 -Prime Minister Indira Gandhi made a ceremonial occasion Wednesday of the presentation of the 15 awards to the prizewinning artists in India's first Triennale of Contemporary World Art, thereby accentuating the importance this country attaches to a venture in international exhibitions of painting and sculpture rivaling, it is hoped, the biennials in Venice and Sao Paulo.

CALCUTTA, India, April 10 -- If there is a limit to the misery of Calcutta's streets, it is set by Mother Teresa, an Albanian-born nun whose mission is dedicated to caring for those who have no other possibility of help.

PRINCETON, W. Va., April 12 -- Former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara has recorded for television a statement praising the conduct of Senator Robert F. Kennedy during the Cuban missile crisis in 1962, a spokesman for the Senator said tonight.

MOSCOW, April 12 -- The long-delayed passenger airline service between Moscow and New York is expected to begin before the end of May, a Deputy Minister of Civil Aviation, Nikolai P. Bykov, said today at a news conference.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 13 -- United States B-52 bombers are stepping up their attacks in the Central Highlands of South Vietnam because of intelligence reports that North Vietnamese units are building strength in the mountainous region.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- A rubbery bulb-like device that fits around a failing heart and massages it for minutes or even hours until normal rhythm can be restored has been patented this week by two researchers at the National Heart Institute, Bethesda. Md.

A PROBING, compassionate study of the alcoholic personality was televised last night on the National Broadcasting Company in "The American Alcoholic." Avoiding the usual documentary fascination with statistics and conflicting therapeutic claims, the program concentrated instead on the deeply wounded human being hidden behind the ugly face the alcoholic presents to the world.

SPECIALISTS in Chinese ceramics are generally horrified at the enthusiasm collectors of Americana have for 18th-century and 19thcentury Canton and Nanking wares. They feel there is more originality in the decoration and the porcelain is finer in the products of the 15th to 17th centuries that were also made for export.
The Polaroid Corporation reported yesterday that its net profits and sales fell in the first quarter from the yearearlier levels.

In the past, he had enlisted the aid of designers like the late Jacques Fath and Antonio del Castillo (1952) and Luis Estevez (1962).

Lou Butera of West Pittston, Pa., defeated Jack Colavita of West Caldwell, N. J., 150-86, and gained the lead yesterday afternoon in the world pocket billiard championship tournament in the Terrace Ballroom of the Statler Hilton Hotel.
Two more leading department store chains reported yesterday record sales and earnings for their latest fiscal years.
LONDON, April 15 -- The Government's bill to outlaw racial discrimination in jobs, housing and other areas has run into political controversy.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 15 -- The scene at the West Side Democratic and Civic Club for today's celebration of Dyngus Day, a traditional spring festival, told something of what a mixed up political year it is.

Joe DiMaggio, vice president and batting coach of the Oakland Athletics, has never looked happier and more at ease. When he arrived at Yankee Stadium yesterday, to re-enter for the first time as an "enemy" the home of the only major league baseball team he was ever associated with until now, he received an unexpected welcome and it only relaxed him further.
The chairman of the State Assembly's Judiciary Committee said yesterday that the Legislature would pass a bill this term providing for 125 new judgeships.
A huge microfilming project -- the filming of the Jewish Theological Seminary library's entire collection of 10,000 rare, early printed books and manuscripts, page by page -- has just been completed.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The International Monetary Fund approved today three stand-by drawing arrangements totaling $154.3-million for Argentina, Ceylon and Guatemala.

TOKYO, April 15 (AP) -- Japanese shipbuilders plan to ask their counterparts in Western Europe to join with them in exercising restraint in competing for orders. They also plan to ask for a halt in construction on mammoth ship docks.

AFTER the Masters tournament one year a generous Arnold Palmer decided to give his caddie a $1,000 tip. He asked his wife, Winnie, to write out the check and never gave it another thought. Neither did she apparently. She absent-mindedly wrote out a check for $10,000 and left it at the Augusta National where club officials discovered the obvious error.
TOKYO, April 15 -- A high security official here has warned that the Japanese Communist party has penetrated the communications industry and other key sectors of business and government.
NEWARK, April 15 -- Unionized telephone installers, linemen, repairmen and central office workers went on strike throughout New Jersey today and some customer services were affected.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -The Soviet Union probably will make a manned space flight within six weeks and certainly has accelerated its already "vigorous'' program to land men on the moon, official sources said today.

" The mode of appointment of the Chief Magistrate of the United States is almost the only part of the system of any consequence which has escaped without severe censure," Alexander Hamilton was able to write in The Federalist in 1788. Specifically as to the method worked out for selecting a President, he added with obvious confidence: "If the manner of it be not perfect, it is at least excellent."
Progress in establishing closer liaison with waterfront employers was reported here yesterday by Local 1814 of the International Longshoremen's Association, the union's 15,000-member Brooklyn local.

The May contract for world sugar was a late swinger yesterday, but it managed to catch some speculators by surprise at the end of the trading session. In fact, it turned in the liveliest last moments of an expiring contract that sugarmen can remember for a long time.

The retrial on conspiracy charges of two partners and an accountant of the accounting firm of Lybrand, Ross Bros. Montgomery has bogged down in a bitter legal battle involving the prosecutor, the judge and a defense lawyer. The first trial ended in a hung jury.
The New York City Housing Authority is searching for funds with which to add about 450 policemen to the special force that now patrols city housing projects.

Victor Muscat, former chairman and president of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., scheduled to take the stand for the first time today in a civil suit against the company and four individuals by the Securities and Exchange Commission in Federal Court here.
Twenty-thousand daffodils have been planted in Central Park as the gift of Mrs. Albert D. Lasker, the philanthropist.

Willie Mays, center fielder for the San Francisco Giants, was named yesterday national chairman of a $2.5-million fund-raising campaign to build a health and physical education center at Miles College, a Negro school in Birmingham, Ala.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 -- A leading Roman Catholic educator proposed here today new national guidelines for Catholic education that would give first priority to the needs of the urban slums.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department reported today that it had found hazardous Salmonella bacteria in 14 drain cleaners and had banned their use in meat and poultry plants operating under Federal inspection.

NOW that fashion is folding its tent dresses, the problem of finding suitable maternity clothes has been intensified. A year ago, a woman could go into any dress department and pick a style at random.
NAMHA PROVINCE, North Vietnam -- The children of Mytrung play with unusual toys.

After some initial difficulties, the experiment in taxicab group riding at the shuttle terminal at La Guardia Airport is now working so well that it may soon be expanded to other points. It provides a far more civilized method of getting a cab than the ruthless scramble that formerly prevailed.
Mayor Lindsay summed up the city's philosophy and strategy of dealing with racial violence yesterday in these words:
Stock prices continued to edge up yesterday as the market followed a churning, irregular pattern in heavy trading.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- The Vatican has stepped into the dispute between James Francis Cardinal McIntyre, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Los Angeles, and the Sisters of the Immaculate Heart, the United States Catholic Conference reported today.

While no copper reached the market from the struck Phelps Dodge Corporation mines during the first quarter, the company "just about broke even," shareholders were told yesterday at the annual meeting at the Essex House.
The Channing Financial Corporation has leased for three subsidiaries 33,000 square feet of floor space in the 40-story annex to the Bankers Trust Building, 280 Park Avenue.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The poor child who needs a free school lunch the most has the least chance of getting one, according to an extensive study of the national school lunch program.
Minoru Yamasaki, the world-famous architect who designed New York's World Trade Center, recently spent six months in a hospital recovering from a near-fatal ulcer attack.

IT becomes increasingly obvious that the New York Mets are sadly lacking in endurance. Once a ball game reaches the 23d inning they start to show signs of wilting. Four years ago the Giants beat them in the 23d inning. Yesterday morning at the not very witching hour of 2:37, New York time, they lost to the Houston Astros in the 24th inning.
A burglary suspect was shot dead yesterday by a policeman in East Harlem, and workers for one of the Mayor's task forces were sent into the area to head off possible disorders.
Trading volume expanded yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as prices moved up.

WARSAW, April 16 -- Warsaw University officials have postponed until the end of the month their ruling on readmission requests of about 1,300 students whose departments were closed last month, it was announced today.

ELWOOD, Ind., April 16 (AP) -- Three officers of Indiana Self-Help Housing Inc. submitted resignations last night from their posts in a project designed to settle Spanish-American migrant laborers in this city of 12,000 that has never had a nonwhite resident.
Neither the United States nor North Vietnam looks very well in the controversy over a site for preliminary peace talks.

DALLAS, April 16 (UPI) -- Curtis Cokes retained his welterweight title in his fourth defense tonight with a remarkably easy fifth-round technical knockout of his South African challenger, Willie Ludick.

Two leaders of the campaign to modernize the city's building code -- a move that seeks to liberate architects from old design requirements and make construction dollars go further -- said yesterday that they thought the proposal could be enacted by this summer.
Anna Freud, the daughter of Sigmund Freud, said in a speech here last night that the younger generation was losing confidence and interest in psychoanalysis.

ROME, April 16 -- One day and 3,300 miles away from the finish, the East Affrica safari rally and its course are still a vividly remembered adventure. After driving thousands of miles there a Yugoslav donkey path will seem like Inter-state 87 and West Virginia like Murray Hill.

If they can recover their strength, the Mets will make their New York debut at Shea Stadium this afternoon. But their minds may still be fastened on the 24-inning, six-hour marathon they lost in Houston's Astrodome in the early hours of yesterday morning.

Joseph Valachi, the informer who outlined the genealogies of Mafia families for a Senate committee in 1963, is to take the stand as a prosecution witness in a Brooklyn hijacking trial, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS -- It seems almost certain that the Czechoslovak people, gaining new strength from freedom's resurgence in their country, are about to discover that Jan Masaryk did not commit suicide on March 10, 1948, but was murdered by Stalinist secret police.
LONDON, April 16 -- The British Government has decided not to participate in the proposed project for an experimental European television relay satellite.
SIOUX FALLS, S. D., April 16 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy flew into South Dakota today and announced he would compete in the state's Presidential primary June 4.
A DAVID AND GOLIATH battle between Publicker Industries, Inc., and a dissident stockholder has been canceled by the man with the slingshot -- "at practically the last minute."

SOUTH SETAUKET, L. I., April 16 -- Suffolk County detectives today interviewed residents of this North Shore area who live near an isolated woodland where an explosion was set off Saturday at a hidden test site.
A Barnard College student-faculty committee met yesterday afternoon to recommend what action should be taken against a sophomore who has been living off-campus with her boyfriend.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A build-up of Soviet naval strength in the Mediterranean is adding to the concern felt by United States officials over conditions at both ends of the strategic waterway.
BONN, April 16 -- West Germany's radical student leaders, exhausted by five days of continual demonstrations, called today for a pause to reflect on the gains and losses of their violent protest.
MEMPHIS, April 16 -- The bitter sanitationmen's strike that had brought the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to Memphis and his death from a sniper's bullet ended today.
TRENTON, April 16 -- Governor Hughes said today that he was opposed to the outright shooting of looters and arsonists in a riot.

Special efforts by major trading nations to help the United States increase its exports was seen as "a possibility" yesterday by Jean Rey, president of the European Common Market's executive commission.
SAIGON, Wednesday, April 17 (AP) -- Five sharp battles broke out around Saigon late yesterday as allied forces probed jungles and rice paddies.
SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, April 17 -- President Park left this morning at 7:43 on a special plane sent by President Johnson.

ATHENS, April 16 -- Two former Greek Premiers who were put under house arrest last night were accused by the army-backed Greek regime today of "excessive political activity that might endanger public security and order."
HICKSVILLE, L. I., April 16 -- The bodies of three boys missing since April 7 were found today in a sump behind an industrial concern a block and a half from their home.

The scene began ominously enough with two clowns prancing about the Yankee Stadium infield yesterday. It ended as the Oakland Athletics beat the New York Yankees, 4-3, on Floyd Robinson's pinch-hit two-run homer in the ninth inning.

Merchants in areas of the city that suffered damage through the looting and arson that followed the slaying of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on April 4 are being urged by the police to clear out their window displays when they close for the day.

BALTIMORE, April 16 -- Four Vietnam war protesters were convicted in United States District Court here today of mutilating and destroying Government records and interfering with the Selective Service program.

When he was 4 years old, Jimmy Connors toddled out to his backyard tennis court, a sawed-off racquet in hand, ready for his first lesson. His instructors were his mother, Mrs. Gloria Connors, and his grandmother, Mrs. Bertha Thompson.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 16 -- President Johnson's popularity rating has taken a spectacular rise since his decision to halt the bombing of North Vietnam and his withdrawal from the 1968 Presidential race, according to the Gallup Poll.
Beginners learn to take finesses. With more experience, they learn to avoid them. It is often possible to make a contract without relying on a favorable location of the opposing cards.

HONG KONG, April 16 -- North Vietnam adhered to Pnompenh, Cambodia, or Warsaw, as a site for preliminary peace talks today, but, despite the impasse with the United States, may have chosen its chief representatives.

The Most Rev. Terence J. Cooke, Archbishop of New York, yesterday appointed a nonsectarian committee of leaders in education, finance, industry and civic affairs to conduct a comprehensive study of the archdiocese's 432 schools.
Ana Drittelle, a Russian cellist who gave her first New York recital in Town Hall just 30 years ago, appeared last night in Carnegie Hall, a rather more demanding atmosphere for any solo performer.
Representative James H. Scheuer of the Bronx came out yesterday for Senator Eugene J. McCarthy for President -- the first Congressman in the East to do so.

In the course of his opening night monologue at the Waldorf-Astoria's Empire Room Monday night, Jack Benny, 74 years old and seemingly ageless, recalled a conversation in which his doctor urged him to cut down on his work schedule.
SYRACUSE, April 16 -- Eugene H. Nickerson assailed Senator Jacob K. Javits for "indecisiveness'' today on the first upstate swing of his campaign for the Senate.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A record $20-billion increase in the gross national product in the first quarter and the setting of a new mark in industrial production last month were reported today by the Department of Commerce and the Federal Reserve System.
WHAT happens when a first-rate writer produces a biography of a second-rate writer? Well, in Sylvia Townsend Warner's "T. H. White." it makes an uncommonly interesting book.

The reckless temptation to create dances should not be acceded to without discrimination. In the case of Maja Lichtenfeld and Nannette Domingos, who offered their works at Judson Church last night, the urge should have been the subject of second and perhaps third thoughts.

The Presidential aspirants should make the National Aeronautics and Space Administration space program an issue in this campaign. Interest in the issue will have to be cultivated because the American public has not customarily been aroused by problems with a substantial technology and science content.
Interest rates on new bond issues marketed yesterday stayed close to the high levels reached earlier this spring, attracting investors in substantial but not overwhelming numbers.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 16 -- Two Michigan pharmacologists presented evidence today indicating that cigarette smoking depresses the reflexes.
Maria Irene Fornes, a dark-haired girl with lustrous eyes, sat in the theater of the New Dramatists Workshop Monday night laughing at a play. It was her own play.

ATLANTA, April 16 -- Two Atlanta cab drivers identified today a sketch of a man believed to be Eric Starvo Galt, an elusive 36-year-old white man sought by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for questioning in the murder April 4 of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
Mayor Lindsay called on the state's new Urban Renewal Corporation yesterday to cooperate with the city in rebuilding slums here.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 16 -- A Texas research physician has reported instilling fear in normal rats by giving them injections of material extracted from the brains of rats who were trained to be afraid.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 16 -- Victor Panzella, the 79-year-old bootblack who had been asked by Nassau County to pay $5 a month as a fee for a concession to shine shoes on county property, received an apology today from the County Executive.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- North Korean sources have made available photographic copies of documents that they say were taken from the seized United States intelligence ship Pueblo, purporting to prove she violated North Korea's territorial waters before her capture on Jan. 23.

MEMPHIS, April 16 -- In the unrest that swept Memphis following the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., stones were thrown through the windows of several Loeb laundries and Loeb barbecues.
