WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The United States would welcome suggestions from third parties to help break the current impasse with North Vietnam over the site for their preliminary talks, State Department officials said today.
CHICAGO, April 16 -- Many Negro leaders were sharply critical today of Mayor Richard J. Daley's orders to the police yesterday to shoot arsonists and looters in any future rioting.

DETROIT, April 16 -- The Chrysler Corporation reported today record sales and profits for the first quarter, with sales climbing 33 per cent from last year and profits nearly four times as large as the total last year.
BIRMINGHAM, England, April 16 -- Den kin member bad way person kin do long after de person kin don die.
The Transit Authority charged yesterday that the New York City police aggravated Sunday night's melee at Coney Island by herding thousands of people, including many rioters, onto subway trains.

CHARLES COLLINGWOOD, the first American television correspondent to visit Hanoi, gave a report from 10 to 11 o'clock last night on his eight days in North Vietnam. The experienced journalist for the Columbia Broadcasting System necessarily was limited to the use of authorized pictures and familiar propaganda interviews, but even within these strictures the hour had value in affirming the tenacity and resourcefulness of the enemy of United States forces.

The New York Giants made a trade yesterday with the Green Bay Packers, which on the face of it appears to be a great coup for New York. Francis Peay, the offensive right tackle in whom the Giants no longer had much interest, went to the Packers for Tommy Crutcher, a linebacker, and Steve Wright, an offensive tackle.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 16 (AP) -- Milan Marcetta poked in a point-blank shot at 9 minutes 11 seconds of an overtime period to give the Minnesota North Stars a -3 victory over the Los Angeles Kings tonight and deadlock their National Hockey League playoof series at three games apiece. The seventh and deciding game will be played in Los Angeles Thursday night.
JOE BURK, who has been crew coach at the University of Pennsylvania for 18 years, recently described American intercollegiate rowing as "a fascinating art rather than a calculated science.''

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission voiced strong opposition today to legislation that would grant special exemption from the antitrust laws to certain newspapers entering into mergers or joint operating arrangements.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 16 -- Significant gains in food production have advanced Asia's developing countries toward higher economic growth rates, a United Nations survey showed today.

Nine employes of the city's Human Resources Administration filed suit in State Supreme Court here yesterday, seeking to prevent the city from imposing Civil Service status on antipoverty agency employes who doubt they can pass qualifying tests.

SACRAMENTO, April 16 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan acknowledged today his interest in what he said was an "increased; grass roots movement across the country" in his behalf for the Republican Presidential nomination.
The Soviet Embassy in Washington said yesterday that three Soviet Jewish religious leaders would visit the United States next month for a series of meetings.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The executive assistant to the Democratic Governor of West Virginia said today that a campaign advance man for Senator Robert F. Kennedy had threatened him and other West Virginians with political vengeance during a dispute last Friday.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries registered a record net income of $26.5-million in the first quarter this year compared with $25.7-million earned in the first three months of 1967, it was reported yesterday.

It's juice and cookie time! The Four Roses Distillers Company has reassigned four brands that had been at Doyle Dane Bernbach. And the Keebler Company in Chicago has announced that it is switching its cookies, crackers and snacks from Young Rubicam to Leo Burnett on July 15.

HONOLULU, April 16 -- President Johnson spent more than three hours with his military commanders in the Pacific here today. He was told about the deployment of enemy and allied forces since the start of efforts to arrange negotiations between the United States and North Vietnam.
PROVIDENCE, April 16 (AP) -- A proposed new constitution for Rhode Island was rejected today by a four-to-one margin in a special referendum.

BOSTON, April 16 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers erupted for eight runs in the fourth inning and spoiled Boston's 1968 home debut, 9-2 today after the Red Sox had raised their first American League pennant in 21 years.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday his opposition to the proposed sale of Long Island University's Brooklyn Center to the City University.

THE always surprising, always engaging Netherlands Dance Theater opened the second and last week of its all-too-brief first New York season at the City Center last night. The program included two ballets by Hans Van Manen new to New York, "Metaphors" and "Essay in Silence," a repeat of another Van Manen ballet, "Dualis," first seen here last week, and another local premiere, the American choreographer Benjamin Harkarvy's "Septet."
Earnings of the Republic Steel Corporation spurted 38.6 per cent in the first quarter of this year from the comparable 1967 level, the company reported yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, April 16 -- Erwin N. Griswold, Solicitor General of the United States, upheld today the moral right of dissenters to disobey laws they believe in conscience to be unjust.

The city announced yesterday that an electronics manufacturer who moved away from New York in 1965 would build a plant here under the small-site industrial renewal program.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 16 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy advocated today that the United States indicate in advance of negotiations with Hanoi its willingness to accept a coalition for South Vietnam that included the National Liberation Front.

LINCOLN, Neb., April 16 (AP) -- Robert Johnson won the heavyweight title and Larry Lyden the 171.5-pound crown in Greco-Roman wrestling tonight, pacing the Minnesota Wrestling Association to the team championship in the National Amateur Athletic Union championships.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 16 -- The United States lost four jet fighter-bombers in North Vietnam yesterday as pilots twisted through the heaviest antiaircraft fire sent up since the start of President Johnson's bombing curtailment.

PRAGUE, April 16 -- The Czechoslovak Communist party newspaper, Rude Pravo, suggested today for the first time that Soviet agents might have been responsible for the death of Foreign Minister Jan Masaryk in 1948.

The Crucible Steel Company, whose operations had been hampered until last November by a two-year dispute with a dissident shareholder group, is planning to merge into the Whittaker Corporation, a Los Angeles producer of aerospace, aircraft and other industrial products.

MOSCOW, April 16 -- The Supreme Court of the Russian Republic today rejected appeals against the conviction and sentencing last January of four persons accused of anti-Soviet agitation and propaganda.

A monthly series of programs dealing with Negro affairs, will be started by National Educational Television in mid-June, the network announced yesterday.

Four men were quietly arrested yesterday in the heart of Manhattan's financial district, after one of them allegedly paid $15,000 cash to the three others in return for a stolen negotiable $100,000 United States Treasury bill.

TEL AVIV, April 16 -- Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations peace envoy, and Foreign Minister Abba Eban held a 90-minute discussion today that was said to have centered on efforts to arrange a meeting of Israel, the United Arab Republic and Jordan under Dr. Jarring's auspices.

Uniroyal, Inc., told shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday that earnings in the first quarter of this year rose by 26.3 per cent, to an estimated $12-million, or 87 cents a share, from $9.5-million, or 67 cents a share, a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A vast expansion of airline service to Hawaii, the South Pacific and the Orient was recommended today by a Civil Aeronautics Board examiner.

A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner's findings recommending new trans-Pacific routes to some airlines was warmly greeted and severely criticized by airlines yesterday, depending on whether or not the airline was recommended for new routes. On the New York Stock Exchange, the reaction was much the same. Those that were recommended for new routes rose, while those that were not showed declines.

Mayor Lindsay cut a red, white and blue ribbon yesterday to open a major part of the $8.5 million ramp complex on the Manhattan end of the Brooklyn Bridge. The ramp system was designed to take a large portion of traffic heavily used downtown streets.

More than 200 New York high school seniors took a day off from their spring recess yesterday to attend a financial forum at the Chase Manhattan Bank, where they listened patiently to bank officers explain their specialties while they waited for the chance to ask questions.

The man accused of having shot and killed the 13-year-old son of Roy Innis, the associate director of the Congress of Racial Equality, was turned over to the Department of Hospitals yesterday for psychiatric examination.
Edna Ferber, who celebrated American life in novels, short stories and plays, died yesterday after a long illness at her home, 730 Park Avenue. She was 82 years old.

PRAGUE, April 16 -- The Most Rev. Frantisek Tomasek, acting leader of Czechoslovakia's Roman Catholics, said today that a Vatican representative would come to Prague to discuss church questions with the new Government.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- President Joseph A. Beirne of the Communications Workers of America has warn 400,000 union members that they can expect no more than $25 each in union strike benefits in the nationwide telephone strike scheduled Thursday.

IN his years as a leader of telephone workers, Joseph Anthony Beirne (pronounced burn) has seen the development of automatic dialing on a worldwide scale, with the consequent decrease in the degree of pressure that a strike can place on the vast Bell System.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 17 -- An official North Vietnamese publication has said that the "new situation" in the war is an opportunity to "strengthen our forces" and shift "the balance of power more rapidly in our favor."

HONG KONG, April 17 -- A propaganda campaign against rightism and the "evil wind of reversing the correct verdicts" is apparently related to the recent dismissal of Yang Chengwu as acting chief of staff.

MRS. JOAN W. PAYSON, who owns the Mets, was sitting on the sunny side of the dugout under a blue hat. Robert F. Wagner, who let the Mets into town while he was mayor, was wearing a brown hat on the shady side. As usual, Mrs. Payson looked as if she were expecting a pleasant surprise, and Wagner as if he were waiting for a sour ball he had swallowed by accident to melt.

Eight bids have been received to hold open tennis tournaments this year, the United States Lawn Tennis Association said yesterday.

BANGKOK, Thailand, April 17 -- Premier Thanom Kittikachorn and a majority of the compact oligarchy that governs Thailand left tonight on a month-long tour of five capitals that will take them around the world.

HANNAH TROY won't be there when her fall collection is introduced Wednesday afternoon. She won't be anywhere near Seventh Avenue. THE recent Sturgis Memorial Chess Tournament in Boston, dominated by college students from the Bay City area, was captured by the Massachusetts state champion, Larry Kaufman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 17 -- Frank Beard, who begins defense of his title in the $150,000 Tournament of Champions tomorrow, was among the golf champions who criticized the present golf rule that penalizes errors in recording scores.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Informed sources said today that the North Vietnamese had built several new roads into South Vietnam from Laos and in South Vietnam itself, apparently to improve their ability to move troops, heavy weapons and supplies into combat areas.
First-quarter earnings of the Reynolds Metals Company rose 12 per cent from the 1967 level on record sales, R. S. Reynolds Jr., chairman, told the annual meeting yesterday in Richmond, Va.
LOS ANGELES, April 17 -- Governor Rockefeller would carry California against any of the leading Democratic Presidential possibilities, according to The Los Angeles Times's State Poll.

BOSTON, April 17 -- Bravely and emotionally, as if defending the fortress of their heritage, the Boston Celtics forced the Philadelphia 76ers into a seventh-game showdown in the Eastern Division final of the National Basketball Association playoffs with a 114-106 victory tonight.

The Borden Company, which changed its name to Borden, Inc., yesterday, expects to report record sales but a decline in profits for the first quarter.

A Barnard College committee recommended yesterday that Linda LeClair, the 20-year-old sophomore who broke housing regulations to live off campus with her boyfriend, lose several of her campus privileges, but did not recommend her expulsion.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation's telephone revenues, manufacturing sales and consolidated net income reached record levels in the first quarter, Leslie H. Warner, president, told shareholders today.

OAKLAND, Calif., April 17 -- Major league baseball came to Oakland with the full flourish of Charles O. Finley tonight.

Milton Berle's accountant was arrested yesterday on charges of giving a $1,000 bribe to an Internal Revenue Service agent to allow deductions of more than $60,000 in unsubstantiated entertainment and travel expenses on the comedian's 1960 income tax return.

United Press International increased its number of subscribers worldwide by 103 in the last year, Mims Thomason, president and general manager, said yesterday. The news service now has 6,583 subscribers.
The Government took strong action yesterday to restrain "intensifying inflationary pressures" in the economy and thus protect the international position of the dollar.

Roy M. Cohn, one of four persons associated with Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., accused of misappropriating $4.8-million from the company, was called as a hostile witness yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
FOR an auto analyst who is bullish on car sales for 1968, David Healy has some surprisingly bearish things to say about the auto stocks.

The scramble for delegates to the Democratic National Convention will be accelerated here in the next few days with appearances by Vice President Humphrey, Senator Eugene J. McCarthy and Theodore C. Sorensen, adviser to Senator Robert F. Kennedy.
CORVALLIS, Ore., April 18 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy objected tonight to the White House action earlier in the day laying down new terms for opening Vietnam talks.
Stock prices scored an irregular advance yesterday as another wave of heavy trading swept over the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, April 18 -- In the wake of new attacks in the demilitarized zone, the United Nations Command charged today that North Korea had adopted a pattern of intensified violence against South Korea. North Korea, on its part, accused the United States of further attempting to provoke a new war in Korea.

Your editorial comment of April 5 on the transfer tax shows that the snake has merely been scotched. The New York Stock Exchange is still trying to get the public to swallow the fiction that this tax is an imposition on the small investor, instead of on the members of the Exchange.

BOSTON -- A bright-faced youth in dungarees zipped down the stairs that led from the bedroom, past the small bare living room on the ground floor where his mother was talking with a visitor and out the door into early spring sunshine.

DETROIT, April 18 -- The new Detroit committee, formed to combat problems that led to last summer's rioting, listed today the achievements of its first five months but conceded that they were "woefully inadequate" compared with the city's needs.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The United States proposed today 10 new sites for preliminary talks with North Vietnam and asserted that "it is time for a serious and responsive answer from Hanoi."

THERE is so much that is wrong about "Mike Downstairs," which opened at the Hudson Theater last night, that it becomes difficult to specify precisely what is right. The author, George Panetta, is clearly a likable chap and has created a few likable characters, but the play moves so slowly at first that now and again you find yourself wondering whether it is still breathing.
ATHENS, April 18 -- The Greek Government said tonight that former Premier George Papandreou was only "trying to get back into power" by appealing for help to topple the army-backed regime.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 18 -- John W. Gardner, former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, will become a visiting professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology next fall.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI) -- The Senate rejected today a move to slop construction of a $5-billion antimissile system to protect the United States against Communist Chinese nuclear attack.

YONKERS, April 18 -- Going from one extreme to the other, the longest-priced horse captured the Dan Patch I, and the heaviest-backed pacer took the Dan Patch II before 21,114 harness racing fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Maritime Administration said today that nearly $1.5-million would be saved because of engineering changes in building 11 large and highly productive barge-carrying vessels.
THE roster of county fish and game associations belonging to New York State's influential Conservation Council is growing.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Analysts of Chinese affairs say that the efforts of moderates in the Peking leadership to rebuild Communist China's local governments have brought new provincial administrations to more than two-thirds of the country's population.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 18 -- Eric Starvo Galt, the suspected assassin of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., apparently eluded the Federal Bureau of Investigation in California last night, a source said today.

THAT famous Lindsay grin is going to be showing up more and more around Fun City. But this time the face will be feminine. The Mayor's 15-year-old daughter, Margaret, has decided she wants to be a model.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Telephone workers left their jobs throughout the country today in the first national strike against the Bell System in 21 years. At issue were wages and wage-related problems.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Presidential election and the Vietnam peace talks are going on at the same time, and this accidental conflict of national and world politics creates for both the President and the candidates a serious problem, which can and should be faced at once.
The United Negro College Fund opened its 1968 campaign yesterday with an appeal to three dozen corporations at a luncheon atop the Chase Manhattan Bank's headquarters.

HONG KONG, April 18 -- A group of Chinese Communist "ultraleftists" who were close to the inner circle around Mao Tse-tung until last fall has been accused of plotting against Chairman Mao's wife and Premier Chou Enl-lai.
The expected sale of the London Bridge to the McCulloch Oil Corporation was announced here yesterday at a lavish news conference at the Four Seasons Restaurant. The purchase price was $2,460,000.

With hundreds of millions of dollars being spent to elect candidates and with more and more advertising agencies getting involved in political campaigns, the American Association of Advertising Agencies has issued a code of ethics and a manual on the subject for its members.

Another casualty in a Mafia factional conflict came to light yesterday as the police and prosecutors in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx redoubled efforts to compel testimony from members of rival factions seeking control over a far-flung racket empire.

The Hartwell Campbell Fund, Inc., expects to resume selling shares to investors today. Because of a large influx of orders on April 1, its 600,000-share supply of unsold authorized shares was exhausted. So the growth-type mutual fund had to stop accepting orders.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the kind of massive urban construction programs proposed by Governor Rockefeller would not solve the problems of American cities.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 18 -- Two advances in the treatmen of severe burns were reported today at a scientific meeting
City Finance Administrator Roy M. Goodman resigned yesterday to devote all his time to his campaign for the Repubican nomination for the State Senate in the 26th District of Manhattan.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 18 -- President Johnson returned to his ranch near here this evening after a three-day journey to Hawaii to reassure his Pacific allies that their interests and counsel would be respected during any negotiations with North Vietnam.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 -- Commissioner of Education Harold Howe 2d challenged today the necessity for a dual system of Roman Catholic and public schools in the suburbs and asked that church funds from these areas be channeled into large cities.

TEL AVIV, April 18 -- Israel requisitioned an area of about 29 acres today near the Wailing Wall to restore the ancient Jewish Quarter of the Old City in Jerusalem. Jordan destroyed much of the quarter after its seizure during the 1948 war.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 18 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy made his first direct appeal today for Indiana's substantial Negro vote in the May 7 Democratic Presidential primary, but the response was apathetic.

TRENTON, April 18 -- The Hughes administration and the chief Republican sponsor of a bipartisan plan to develop the Hackensack River meadowland agreed today on a final series of amendments. They would enlarge the plan's governing body, reduce the area of the development tract and guarantee alternative methods of disposing of a large share of northern New Jersey's garbage.
AUSTIN, Tex., April 18 -- Another slight cut in Texas oil production, under the nipping of gradual restoration of imports, was ordered today by the Texas Railroad Commission.

Many of the civil trial parts of Manhattan Supreme Court may be closed soon to clear up "the worst jail-case backlog in our memory," Presiding Justice Bernard Botein of the Appellate Division, First Department, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee is investigating a report that the Central Intelligence Agency once removed Nguyen Cao Ky, now the Vice President of South Vietnam, as the commanding officer of a secret sabotage operation because he had used it as a front for opium smuggling.

Mrs. Martin Luther King Jr. has agreed to speak in her husband's place at the anti-Vietnam War rally to be held in Central Park on April 27. Before he was slain in Memphis on April 4, Dr. King had been listed as the rally's keynote speaker.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee is investigating a report that the Central Intelligence Agency once removed Nguyen Cao Ky, now the Vice President of South Vietnam, as the commanding officer of a secret sabotage operation because he had used it as a front for opium smuggling.

Mrs. Martin Luther King Jr. has agreed to speak in her husband's place at the anti-Vietnam War rally to be held in Central Park on April 27. Before he was slain in Memphis on April 4, Dr. King had been listed as the rally's keynote speaker.

The field for the $100,000 added Wood Memorial at Aqueduct tomorrow will be a large one, with probably 13 participating. The mile-and-an-eighth race for 3-year-olds will be run for the 44th time, but even with the "baker's dozen" anticipated, the betting will most likely settle on five horses.

LONDON, April 18 -- The leader of the Conservative party, Edward Heath, said today that the Labor Government's bill to outlaw racial discrimination would "create priviieges" for the colored minority in Britain.
Development of a new dispersant that disintegrates oil slicks and cleans oil-fouled beaches without harming marine life has been announced by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

In his address to the American Society of Newspaper Editors, Governor Rockefeller offered a strong and convincing restatement of the basic beliefs that have animated his public career. Although he addressed himself to the claims of justice, his deepest theme was responsibility.
City antipoverty officials say they feel the Federal Government's failure to provide more money to hire unemployed teen-agers this summer is an "invitation to disaster."

PITTSBURGH, April 18 -- The Aluminum Company of America today reported record first-quarter earnings of $30,734,152. This is $3,485,998, or 12.8 per cent, above the previous first-quarter record achieved last year, John D. Harper, president, told the annual shareholders meeting here today.

The last union leader in the country anyone would accuse of being strike-happy is Joseph A. Beirne of the Communications Workers of America -- the man who yesterday called the year's biggest strike so far, which directly involves at least 178,000 Bell System employees in hundreds of cities.

The Federal Reserve's double-barrelled decision to raise the discount rate and change an important regulation affecting bonds caught the credit markets by surprise yesterday afternoon. New issues were thrown into turmoil and dealers predicted a sharp decline in most prices today.

A horde of Young Rubicam folk trooped to a second-floor screening room yesterday for a look at the new Eastern Air Lines commercials that were rushed to completion for Sunday night's Tony Awards show.
Following is the text of a letter sent by Miss Martha Peterson, president of Barnard College, to Linda LeClair:
"The reason I do it is because I heard of Martin Luther King, and he, well, I know he wanted to do something for the poor," 8-year-old Eric Jacobs explained.
A new station wagon with 70 cubic feet of carpeted cargo area was introduced here yesterday by Volvo of Sweden. The vehicle, called the 145 S, lists at $3,395, East Coast port of entry.
STORRS, Conn., April 18 -- The University of Connecticut will grant paid leaves of absence next year to faculty members who participate in full-time civil rights work.

SUMMIT, N. J., April 18 -- The foursome of Mrs. James Blair, Mrs. Nancy Waters, Mrs. Allan Bildner and Mrs. Sidney Dornfield won the Garden State Women's Golf Association's opening tournament of the season today with a handicap score of minus 9, after shooting a gross 76 over the 6,080-yard, par-75 North Course of the Canoe Brook Country Club.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., April 18 -- Employment by the police of student informers to combat the use of drugs on the Vassar College campus has been denounced here by a member of the college faculty.

BERLIN, April 18 -- Mayor Klaus Schutz of West Berlin called today for an immediate end to violence and reaffirmed his administration's determination "to defend democracy against the enemies from within and without."
"LE TARTUFFE," that 300-year-old expose of zealous hypocrisy, opened in New York last night, not a moment too soon for whatever such pleas for sincerity may be worth in an election year.

Their 63,000 season ticket-holders will see the New York Giants next season play home games at Yankee Stadium against the Washington Redskins, the New Orleans Saints, the San Francisco '49ers, the Baltimore Colts, the Philadelphia Eagles, the St. Louis Cardinals and the Dallas Cowboys. The Sunday dates run from Sept. 29 to Dec. 15.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- A group of pro-Rockefeller and other Republican leaders agreed generally today that the New York Governor should declare his active candidacy for the Presidential nomination soon.

MONTREAL, April 18 (AP) -- John Ferguson and Yvan Cournoyer scored two goals each to night and the Montreal Canadiens routed the Chicago Black Hawks, 9-2, in the first game of their four-of-seven-game semi-final series for the Stanley Cup.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today that an escaped convict named James Earl Ray was the man being sought under the alias of Eric Starvo Galt for the murder of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

The link between business and the theater has long been strong in the apparel industry. Designers move between both worlds and a dramatic presentation can often make the difference between a hit and a flop.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Telephone service throughout the country remained virtually normal today despite a strike that the Communications Workers of America pronounced 90 per cent effective. The union reported nearly 200,000 workers had left their jobs.

Dr. Linus Pauling has concluded that many mental disorders may stem from a chemical imbalance in the brain. He suggested yesterday that therapy to restore the balance was "the best method of treatment for many patients."

YONKERS, April 19 -- An obviously sharp First Lee, forced to go all out through the first half of the one-mile race, wound up a comfortable winner tonight at Yonkers Raceway in the Australian pacing ace's first start in this country.
James Earl Ray, the man suspected of killing the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was described yesterday as a drunken drifter, prone to thievery and violence, a failure at everything.
AUSTIN, Tex. April 19 (AP) -- The White House said today that tighter money was inevitable because, in the absence of higher taxes, it is "our only present defense against inflation."

Interest rates climbed sharply yesterday throughout the bond and money markets in a pronounced but orderly response to the Federal Reserve's moves Thursday to choke off the inflationary pressures in the economy.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- New divisions have emerged within the Johnson Administration as a result of maneuvering over the selection of a site for preliminary negotiations with North Vietnam.

GEORGE ORWELL'S chilling look into the future, "1984," was presented last night in a generally faithful British Broadcasting Corporation production on the National Educational Television network, including Channel 13 here. However, the adaptation by Nigel Kneale, originally presented in England in 1953 and in an updated version in 1965, was curiously lacking in suspense until the final portionmwhen Winston Smith, the rebellious clerk in the Ministry of Truth, _ comes to love his tormentor.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., April 19 (UPI) -- Gov. Roger D. Branigin, campaigning as a native and favorite son, urged Indianians today to treat Senator Robert F. Kennedy and Eugene J. McCarthy "like all tourists."

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 19 -- The descriptions given the police and the F.B.I. of the assassin of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. have varied so widely it appears that as many as four men may have been under suspicion.

Ask any Latin American woman with pretensions to chic where fashion comes from and she will inevitably answer "Paris." That's where she goes for her clothes if she can. If she can't, it's where she gets the ideas for the styles her local dressmaker whips up.
The Crucible Steel Company of America has decided to postpone a decision on the merger offer of the Whittaker Corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy suggested today that the Administration consider paying ransom for the release of the American intelligence ship Pueblo and her crew, seized by North Korea Jan. 23.

A team headed by a well-to-do insurance man from Minnesota and financed by a manufacturer of motorized sledges reached the North Pole yesterday afternoon after a 44-day trek over the frozen Arctic Ocean.
HOUSTON, April 19 (AP) -- Mike Belkin of Canada and Boro Jovanovic of Yugoslavia scored upsets today to join Cliff Richey and Rafael Osuna in the semi-finals of the 34th River Oaks tennis tournament.
What have the mutual funds been doing with their billions of dollars in cash during the stock-market surge of April?

GENEVA, April 19 -- A "newly discovered Russian pianist" playing works by famous composers that local music experts had somehow never heard before has pulled off the biggest hoax in the history of the Tonhalle, Zurich's famous concert hall.

GENEVA, April 19 -- A compromise plan to avoid a deadlock between the world's leading trading nations over aid to be granted the United States in meeting its balance-of-payments deficit is being given a final polishing by the head of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

Ceremonies aboard the nuclear merchant ship Savannah yesterday, designating the week of May 18-26 as Nuclear Week in New York, served as the backdrop for a plea for building a nuclear American merchant marine.
A Cuban Night concert at Town Hall was disrupted several times last night by a tear-gas-like substance that forced members of the audience to sneeze, cough and leave the auditorium.

FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, April 19 -- Sierra Leone was calm and more than a little confused tonight as two exiled army officers returned to the country, apparently to take charge of the 36-hour-old military government.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, April 19 -- The nine powerful elders of the Olympic movement converged on this Victorian lakeside resort today for a weekend meeting to decide the fate of the Olympic Games.
SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, April 20 (UPI) -- A band of North Koreans attacked a United States Army patrol south of the truce line today and wounded an American soldier, Army spokesman reported.

BAYPORT, L. I., April 19 -- An Air Force jet fighter on a training flight crashed and burst into flame in a residential neighborhood of this Suffolk County today after its two crewmen parachuted to sefety.
Interest rates moved upward across the nation yesterday as the financial markets reacted to the Government's latest moves to restrain inflation.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The Army today chose two additional contractors to produce the lightweight, rapid-firing M-16 rifle. It awarded the concerns contracts leading to the production of up to 480,000 weapons for $98-million.
WHAT'S in a name? A whole lot, especially if it belongs to someone else and it's highly visible.

LOS ANGELES, April 19 -Senator Robert F. Kennedy, campaigning in the heart of the aerospace industry, called today for a fusion of technology and government "to build up an America where the citizen is not enslaved by technical achievement but freed by it."
ATHENS, April 19 -- The army-backed regime has decided that Greeks should stop listening to records of one of the regime's most vocal critics abroad, Melina Mercouri, the actress and singer.

The Wood Memorial, a race that has produced a half-dozen winners of the Kentucky Derby, will be run at Aqueduct today, and a crowd of 55,000 fine-weather friends of the thoroughbred is expected to be out to see it.

Fred Samara, the latest movie star to emerge from Brooklyn, and strong foursomes from Power Memorial and Mount Vernon were the major victors yesterday as the Queens-Iona Relays opened a two-day stand at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.
The stock market broke sharply yesterday in the wake of the Federal Reserve System's announcement on Thursday of an increase in the discount rate, the nation's key lending rate.

A tiny head of a man or woman carved on a limestone pebble has been identified as one of the most ancient pieces of sculpture known. The piece, which is 2 1/2 inches high and 1 1/4 inches wide, dates from around 20,000 B.C. and may be the earliest carved head ever discovered.

After 16 years' residence at 42 West 58th Street, the Chateau Madrid, the home away from home for nightclubbing Hispanophiles, has moved to new and larger quarters in the Lexington Hotel, Lexington Avenue at 48th Street.

Adam Lischewski of Poland, competing in the United States for the first time, became the foil victor in the eighth annual Martini and Rosi international fencing tournament when he defeated Jeff Checkes of the United States in the final.

McLEAN, VA., April 19 -- Hickory Hill is quite obviously Ethel country. Senator Robert F. Kennedy's wife has decorated it in large bursts of color -- yellows blues, greens and particularly pink. She probably is one of the few people to have a pink and white dining room.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- In a move that could make financial history, an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner ordered officials of five financial institutions today to identify the hidden owners of some of the nation's largest railroads.

The statement issued by Presidents Johnson and Park after their Honolulu conference shows signs of hard bargaining in bridging, verbally at least, the differences between the United States and South Korea over Vietnam policy and over American commitments to Seoul's defense.
Two of the best kept secrets of the Lindsay administration can be found in a dingy garage on 65th Street between Amsterdam and West End Avenues.

HANOI, North Vietnam, April 19 -- North Vietnam today rejected all sites suggested by the United States for talks looking toward a settlement in Vietnam. It insisted on its suggestion of Warsaw as a site.

A Federal Grand Jury in Manhattan returned yesterday a 71-count indictment against the former chairman and president of VTR. Inc., and three of his business associates for allegedly filing false and misleading financial statements in annual VTR reports.
In your March 27 editorial "Poison Gas Boomerangs" you wonder "what benefits the nation receives from poison gases."
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- "The nation is in the midst of the worst financial crisis since 1931," William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, asserted today.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- A new electronic device is being used in Los Angeles, London and Tokyo to ascertain the subconscious response of audiences to en tainment and advertising presentations. The spectators are not required to press buttons or mark cards. Electrodes taped to two fingers and held in place by a wristband register the subject's reactions by detecting the amount of current passing through his skin.

Vincent P. DiNapoli, chairman of the board of Tully DiNapoli, one of the city's largest construction companies, has been ordered to appear before the Manhattan grand jury that is investigating the affairs of James L. Marcus.
FOR antiques collectors, the exhibition of chess sets at the Brooklyn Museum should serve as a quick course in recognizing authentic styles.

BIMINI, THE BAHAMAS, April 19 (UPI) -- Adam Clayton Powell said today that he would open an active campaign next month for re-election to the House of Representatives as a candidate against "white racism."

IF the current season of the Netherlands Dance Theater at the City Center had proved nothing else, it proved that the Dutch do not consistently dance in clogs. But much more, it has proved that in the Netherlands Dance Theater the Dutch have one of the most interesting and explorative dance companies in Europe, or, for that matter, in the world.

As Jews in the United States and elswhere yesterday observed the 25th anniversary of the Warsaw ghetto uprising, fears were mounting in this country that a new wave of anti-Semitism once more endangered Polish Jews.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 20 -- The United States reported yesterday that it had carried out the year's heaviest air raids on North Vietnam as monsoon clouds thinned.

THE HAGUE, April 19 -- Construction of a European antiballistic missile defense is not justified in the present circumstances, the Nuclear Planning Group of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization reported today.
MULUNGUSHI, Zambia, April 19 (Reuters) -- President Kenneth D. Kaunda announced today that the state would take control of 25 major companies, including subsidiaries of foreign-owned groups.

NEW HAVEN, April 19 (AP) -- A two-month jail sentence for Yale student, Walter Cummings 3d, the 20-year-old son of a Federal judge in Chicago, was revoked today by the Superior Court judge who had imposed it.
The reputed elder of a Brooklyn Mafia family was shot and killed yesterday morning as he sipped a strawberry malted in a corner luncheonette in Brooklyn.
LONDON, Saturday, April 20 -- The Times of London announced today that it would be sold in the Soviet Union.

Studies of laboratory animals have shown that a diet deficient in protein during pregnancy can result in offspring with a subnormal number of brain nerve cells.

WARSAW, April 19 -- His curly hair has thinned a bit and his waistline has thickened considerably in the quarter of a century since Maj. Gen. Mieczyslaw Moczar (pronounced MYEH-chee-slav MOHT-char) was a Resistance fighter, but to most Poles he is still a partisan.

Roy M. Cohn completed his testimony yesterday in a civil action against him, three business associates and Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc. by denying that he knew early last year about the removal of $152,500 from a company bank account.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- The National League decided today to expand to 12 teams in 1969 but left open the question of which two of five applicants -- San Diego, Milwaukee, Buffalo, Montreal and Dallas-Fort Worth -- would be added to the present 10 members.
The Proposition, a satirical revue from Boston, opened last night at the Bitter End in Greenwich Village.

Two top city officials charged yesterday that more than $250,000 was lost is improperly issued checks last summer in connection with expenditures of the Neighborhood Youth Corps. The charges were contained in a report to Mayor Lindsay by Arnold G. Fraiman, Commissioner of Investigation, and Mitchell I. Ginsberg, Human Resources Administrator.

DAVIS, Calif., April 19 -- The Regents of the University of California, embroiled for 15 months in a battle over tuition or enlarging student fees, voted today to increase student charges by $27 a quarter, or $81 for the normal three-quarter academic year.
The brown pelican seems to be disappearing for unknown reasons along much of the coast of the Gulf of Mexico.
BOSTON, April 19 -- Mayor Lindsay told 3,500 Massachusetts Republicans tonight that the party could improve its chances of winning the 1968 elections by recruiting Negro youths.
Time Inc. has won the approval of the Justice Department for its proposed purchase of Little, Brown Co., the Boston publishing house.

Jagged glass protruded from the frames of broken windows, and litter filled empty apartments yesterday as city officials toured an owner-abandoned Bronx tenement that was still inhabited by several families.

The Harvard crew, of which so much is expected this season, opens a campaign today that it hopes will extend all the way to the Olympics at Mexico City next fall.

The saga of Nolan Ryan added a new chapter yesterday in the New York Mets' 3-2 loss to Los Angeles: The Rookie Outfielder Who Overslept.

WARSAW, April 19 -- Polityka, a weekly newspaper closely associated with Wladyslaw Gomulka, Communist party leader, defended itself today against critics who have included Maj. Gen. Mieczyslaw Moczar, the Interior Minister.

PITTSBURGH, April 19 (UPI) -- Debbie Meyer, a slender 15-year-old, and 18-year-old Claudia Kolb bettered national records tonight to match the ones they set last night in the Amateur Athletic Union women's short-course swimming competition.
OTTAWA, April 19 -- The 100-year-old gray stone mansion on a bluff overlooking the Ottawa River is about to enter a new age.

UTICA, N.Y., April 19 (AP) -- Robert E. Peach, president of Mohawk Airlines since 1954, today was elected chairman of the board of directors and chief executive officer in a major reorganization of the Utica-based airline.
BERLIN, April 19 -- The East German regime offered today to give more influence to the official youth organization at universities and colleges.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -Richard M. Nixon told a responsive audience of editors today that he would continue to remain silent on Vietnam "as long as there is hope for successful negotiation."

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 19 -- For the second straight day there was a tie for the lead in the $150,000 Tournament of Champions golf event. Don January, the Professional Golfer's Association champion, and Dan Sikes finished with 36-hole scores of 138 today as warm weather and light breezes replaced the gales and cold of yesterday's opening round.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The Senate approved today a $21.3-billion authorization for military hardware, research and development in the 1968-69 fiscal year. The action followed approval of a 3 per cent, $660-million cutback in the proposal submitted to the floor.
Millions of homeowners on the East Coast may soon be paying more to heat their homes as a result of price increases on fuel oil being announced by the nation's major suppliers.

CAMRANH BAY, South Vietnam, April 19 -- The newest airman at the 412th maintenance Squadron stood in a T-shirt and assisted the older men lifting 750-pound bombs, tightening bolts and inserting fuses.

A federal judge who, the Government charged, showed bias and prejudice for the defense in a long trial that ended in a hung jury agreed reluctantly yesterday to let another judge retry three accountants on conspiracy and fraud charges.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- Surrounded by bedsheet banners that insulted them as "old men," the Boston Celtics dethroned the Philadelphia 76ers as champions of the National Basketball Association tonight with a 100-96 victory in the seventh-game showdown of the Eastern Division final playoffs.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission cleared the way today for the merger of the Great Northern, Northern Pacific and the Chicago, Burlington Quincy railroads in 15 days.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 19 -- The newest thing in religion is fun and comedy, Dr. Harvey G. Cox, author and professor of Christian thought at Harvard Divinity School, declared today.
LOSER-ON-LOSER is a technique that can often turn a possibility into a certainty. On the diagrammed deal South's appeared to depend on a spade finesse, but he found a way to avoid that hazard.

Precious metals moved up in price yesterday, while the stock market moved down. In the case of stocks, the downward impact on prices could be traced to the Federal Reserve's increase in the discount rate to help put a brake on inflation.

Five trim warships in five different shades of gray slipped into the Narrows yesterday morning, sailed beneath the Verrazano Bridge and past the soaring jets of city fireboats up the Hudson River, and tied up, tight as sardines, at Pier 86 off West 46th Street.

Most of the galleries are holding either their last or their next to last shows just now. The season has provided a great deal of variety, and these last weeks you can see just about anything. PITTSBURGH, April 21 -Orders for steel were steady at high levels.
As the Metropolitan Opera's 83d season came to a close, its often acidulous general manager. Rudolf Bing, summed up the state of the Met in a contented phrase: "We have overcome."

The London Symphony Orchestra ended a brief visit to New York on Saturday night with their fourth concert at Carnegie Hall.

Newspaper publishers drew a dismal picture of their industry's labor relations yesterday, accusing unions of "rushing pell-mell" for "illusory" shortterm gains without increases in productivity. There were 35 newspaper strikes across the nation last year, the most since 1958.

Sales of single-family houses in February were nearly 27 per cent higher than in the same month of 1967, the National Association of Real Estate Boards has reported.

The Penn Central Company yesterday reported consolidated earnings of $13,388,000 for the first quarter. This was up from the combined net income of $11,481,000 of the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads in the corresponding three months of 1967.

WILMINGTON, N. C., April 21 (AP) -- Steve Reid, a 31-year-old golfer from St. Louis, whose name isn't even included in the 1968 Professional Golfers' Association player catalogue, dropped a birdie putt on the second hole of a sudden-death playoff today to defeat Gary Player of South Africa and win the Azalea open tournament.
Details of the proposed merger of Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc., the Canada Dry Corporation and the McCall Corporation into a new billiondollar conglomerate were announced over the weekend.

The Greek, Russian and other Eastern Orthodox churches, which have more than four million communicants in the United States, celebrated Easter yesterday with colorful processions and ceremonies.

Under pressure from about forty nations which had threatened to boycott this year's Olympic Games if South Africa were allowed to compete, the executive board of the International Olympic Committee voted yesterday to recommend South Africa's exclusion. Testing for chromosomal defects to detect latent physical and mental abnormalities is being hampered by high costs and a lack of personnel, two scientists said yesterday.
The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) announced yesterday that the highest quarterly earnings in its history were attained in the three months ended March 31.
MIAMI, April 22 (AP) -Craig Perret, an apprentice jockey who is bidding for a Gulfstream Park record, rode four winners today to bring his total for the meeting to 53 with three racing days to go.
Plans for a campaign to make "black schools in the ghetto the equal of any school attended by whites" were announced yesterday by a newly formed group known as the Ad Hoc Committee for Education.

PRAGUE, April 21 -- "This may be a dead year as far as the economic reform goes," a Czech economist said the other day. "Some people talk of the dangers of going too fast; I think the danger is that we shall not go fast enough."
PINEHURST, N. C., April 22 (AP) -- Bill Campbell, bidding for a fifth North and South amateur golf championship, led the field through today's first round. There were no major upsets.

THE other day, the Rev. George Harold Dunne, the only Roman Catholic among the 350 Protestant and Orthodox officials at the Geneva headquarters of the World Council of Churches, turned up at his office wearing a black priestly suit that contrasted sharply with the sports jackets and flannel slacks favored by most of his colleagues.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A 1964 Mississippi antipicketing law was declared constitutional today by the Supreme Court over the assertions of Negro demonstrators that it had been enacted to crush desegregation protests.
CAN a West Virginia mountaineer who plays his hunches bring new life to an old shoe?
Julius Monk and the Plaza Hotel will part company at the end of June, after six years of revues in the hotel's Plaza 9 room.

Wearing the uniform of a lieutenant in the Biafran army and preoccupied with the secessionist battle of his native region against Nigeria, Dick Tiger yesterday signed a contract for the third defense of his light-heavyweight boxing championship.

Fundamental and deeply disturbing questions relating to the place of the veteran in American society have been raised in a report recently released by the U.S. Veterans Advisory Commission. Established in 1967 by the Administrator of Veterans Affairs at the request of the President, the commission was asked to study how tax dollars are being spent for the veteran and how Government responsibilities to the veteran are being met.
BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 22 (AP) -- Professional tennis stars had a series of shocks today at the start of the British hard-court championship, the world's first open tournament.

United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau announced yesterday that his office had taken preliminary action to get five dissident members of the National Maritime Union reinstated as full "book" members.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The average interest rate on a conventional new-home mortgage rose to a record of 6.5 per cent in March. Passing the previous high of 6.47 per cent the month before, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Supreme Court declined today to consider the charge by New York City and other governments that the Justice Department is letting 18 major publishers off too lightly in an antitrust settlement.

TRENTON, April 22 -- The Republican leadership in the Legislature announced today that it would attempt to establish a new state Department of Criminal Justice, taking from the State Attorney General his jurisdiction in criminal matters.
"An exchange on the artistic front adds a new dimension of understanding which is tremendously important in terms of working and living together," said John D. Rockefeller 3d.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -The Treasury bill rate rose at today's auction from last week's levels, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
They gave away daisies at the Martinique Theater last evening.

DETROIT, April 22 -- John S. Bugas will retire from Ford Motor Company at the end of this month, giving up his post as vice president and his seat on the Ford board of directors. Mr. Bugas, who was an early ally of Henry Ford 2d in young Ford's efforts to win control of the company, will be 60 years old Friday.

A group of about 30 parents and spokesmen for predominatly Negro organizations besieged the principal's office of a Bronx school yesterday and said they would sleep there in protest against a newly assigned principal.

Following the axiom of the track (if you have it, you spend it), another remarkably large crowd, 31,518, turned up at Aqueduct yesterday and continued to defy pessimistic predictions that the increased "take" would frighten bettors away.

The National Broadcasting Company has won five and the Columbia Broadcasting System four of the 10 George Foster Peabody Awards presented to networks for "distinguished achievement by television and radio" during 1967.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., April 22 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy taunted Richard M. Nixon today for advocating Federal budget cuts while allegedly failing to propose alternate solutions to the nation's pressing difficulties.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Pierre-Paul Schweitzer, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said today that it was "anybody's guess" whether there would be another international financial crisis if the United States failed to raise taxes, cut government spending, or both.
BUFFALO, April 22 -- A young Negro mother who was held captive by Winston Moseley, an escaped murderer, was subpoenaed today to testify about the incident to a grand jury.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he might ask that the city's armories be opened to accommodate the thousands of persons who are expected to stop here May 10 or May 11 en route to Washington on the projected Poor People's Campaign.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that The Los Angeles Times must give up three San Bernardino newspapers it bought in 1964 for $15-million.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -There are so many Presidential candidates in the display case that it's hard to decide which one to choose. This is probably because everybody is concentrating on what they are all saying they will do, instead of thinking about how they will actually behave after they get into the White House.
Mayor Lindsay and City University officials informally agreed yesterday on a permanent site for York College in Jamaica, Queens, but disagreed over an interim site for the new senior college.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 22 -- Favorable weather conditions over the panhandle, the region just north of the demilitarized zone, enabled United States pilots to strike North Vietnamese targets in force again yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, gave assurances today that the underground nuclear test scheduled for Friday in Nevada had been planned only after it was found safe by a "careful" review.
Steamship operators are planning to appeal a decision the Maritime Administration ruling out the pay and subsistence of certain crew members in the Government's complicated operating subsidy system.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The United States, the Soviet Union and 42 other nations signed a treaty today to assure international cooperation in the rescue of any astronaut who has to return to earth outside his own national territory.

BILL McCARTHY, who retired in 1964 after coaching the New York University baseball team for 40 years, goes out to see the Violets play now and then and is particularly pleased with what he has seen this season.

WARSAW, April 22 -- Warsaw University students failed to stage their threatened demonstration today apparently because of official warnings that any further unrest would cause the closing of the university until October.

OAKLAND, Calif., April 22 -- Fritz Peterson's dream did not quite come true tonight and, boy, was he glad. Although be did have to be taken out of the game in the eighth inning, just as in the dream he had last night, the New York Yankees held on for a 2-1 decision over the Oakland Athletics and Peterson received credit for his first victory.

The April 16 letter of Joseph A. Califano Jr., Special Assistant to the President, attacks both me and The Times for alleged misstatements of facts about the level of Federal funding for summer antipoverty programs in New York City.
ATHENS, April 22 -- Five members of the British Parliament ended a week's visit to Greece today with a generally favorable report on the country.
DALLAS, April 22 -- Two Protestant denominations legally closed out their books here today and prepared to join tomorrow in forming the United States' newest church body.
The American economy has never produced more than it is producing right now. The rate of unemployment has been below 4 per cent for more than two years. Business profits are higher than ever before.
HELENA, Mont., April 22 -- Richard M. Nixon and his aides appear to believe that they have not yet secured the Republican Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The nine Justices of the Supreme Court asked many questions today, but they gave few clues on how they felt about the constitutionality of a New York law requiring public schools to lend textbooks to parochial and other private schools.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 22 -- The lawyer for two American pilots on trial for manslaughter through negligence today blamed faulty transmission of navigational data from the ground for the crash of a jetliner near Taipei that killed 32 people.

PATERSON, N.J., April 22 -- A two-year-old investigation into a North Jersey counterfeiting ring and the murders of a bookmaker and a housewife took a strange turn today when the state's principal witness recanted a sworn statement in which he said he had seen one of the murders.

Two small explosions shattered glass and pitted the facades of the Mexican consulate and the Spanish national tourist office in mid-Manhattan early yesterday morning. The offices were closed at the time, and there were no injuries.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., April 22 -- The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors today approved a mile-by-mile survey of the county in the hope of collecting millions of dollars in taxes on properties that are either untaxed or undertaxed.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner prescribed today the quality of service that the railroads should provide for passengers.
Minority groups are "systematically excluded or stereotyped" in the theater, the chairman of the State Commission for Human Rights charged yesterday.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I. -- The serene atmosphere of this sedate South Shore village is shattered by the obtrusive sound of a small helicopter several days a week as it settles gently on the spacious lawn of an expensive white home.

LONDON, April 22 -- Seven orchestras and eight theatrical companies will perform this summer at the 22d Edinburgh International Festival.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Some effects of narcotic drugs persist much longer than previously supposed, it was reported here today.

MONROVIA, Liberia, April 22 -- A meeting of West African countries got off to a faltering start today with only half the 14 invited leaders present to discuss proposals for a regional economic grouping.

The American Bankers Association called yesterday for an overhauling of the policies that govern lending by the Federal Reserve System to its member banks.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Charging that the Johnson Administration had "failed to take the necessary and proper action to prevent and control crime," a key Republican group recommended today 31 steps to combat lawlessness in America.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- President Johnson returned to the White House today after a 10-day absence in Texas and Hawaii. In his first official act he signed a bill providing for an elected school board for the District of Columbia.

INDIANAPOLIS -- The official motto of the Hoosier state is "The Crossroads of America," which is appropriate because simple Hoosiers are hard to find in Indiana, while nearly anything else American is not.

A New Jersey pharmaceutical laboratory announced yesterday that its vaccine to prevent Rh blood disease in infants had been approved for marketing and would be generally available in June.

ST. LOUIS, April 23 (AP) -Texaco, Inc., had the best first quarter in its history, J. Howard Rambin Jr., chairman, told the company's annual stockholders meeting here today.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Agriculture Department said today that it had money and food for hungry people but that bureaucratic conflicts with county officials often blocked the distribution machinery.

James L. Buckley, Conservative party candidate for the Senate, called last night for constitutional amendments doing away with what he termed the "overmeticulousness" of recent Supreme Court decisions that have "thrown our whole system of justice out of killer."

Interest rates, paced by a record 6 3/4 per cent yield on Bell System debentures, were increased again yesterday on a wide range of new fixed-income securities. Already outstanding issues, however, moved up in price for the first time in more than a week.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 23 -The Arabs and their allies today challenged Israel's participation in the International Conference on Human Rights because of their charges that she has violated those rights in occupied Arab territories.
Pierre Elliott Trudeau has called a general election in Canada June 25 for the reason Prime Ministers usually make such decisions in a parliamentary system: He believes his Liberal party can win it.
The city and the nonprofit organization that is planning to develop the Brooklyn Navy Yard have tentatively agreed on building a combined incinerator and sewage disposal plant at the yard.

LONDON, April 23 (UPI) -- Britain officially began circulating decimal coins today, amid sighs of relief from visitors and confusion among the British.

Working with a group of student editors, Wesleyan University Press in Middletown, Conn., will publish tomorrow the first installment of a periodical devoted to American undergraduate college poetry. WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The United States has reached no agreement with North Vietnam on a site for their preliminary talks, the State Department said today.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas belittled today the danger of an international financial crisis such as that described last week by William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
A program to "help schoolchildren confront the issues causing tension in American society" will be televised in the nation's schools this spring, it was announced yesterday.
DALLAS, April 23 -- The new United Methodist Church was born here today in a ceremony of solemn dignity and reverence.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 25 (UPI) -- The Chicago White Sox, who have yet to win a game, suffered their 10th straight defeat today when they were beaten, 3-2, by the Minnesota Twins.

ZANZIBAR, Tanzania, April 25 -- Zanzibar's ruler, Sheik Abeid Amani Karume, who is also Tanzania's First Vice President, has said he wants no further integration of the island and its subsidiary isles with the mainland.
The corporate bond market continued to inch its way upward yesterday, more and more convinced that Vietnam peace talks could get under way relatively soon.
Grain traders took the Government's stocks-on-hand report in stride yesterday, indicating that it held few surprises for them. As a result, futures prices showed little change yesterday.

In the face of warnings that its actions could cause racial unrest, the Board of Estimate yesterday cleared the way for construction of a $165-million sewage-disposal system on Manhattan's Upper West Side.
DALLAS, April 25 -- Gary Player of South Africa took a one-stroke lead with a 66 today in a tournament that was renamed to honor a Texan.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Federal officials disclosed today plans to publish information on the comparative safety of automobiles by make and model.
The Federal Reserve pressed its policy of tight money during the week following an increase in the discount rate, banking data published yesterday showed.
ST. LOUIS, April 25 -- The American bishops of the Roman Catholic Church inaugurated a massive program today to expand and make professional the social action programs of local dioceses.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 25 -- Following is a statement by Ambassador Arthur J. Goldberg, United States representative at the United Nations.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 25 -- King Hussein of Jordan removed from office today two security officials who had been opposed to Arab guerrillas operating from Jordan against Israeli, it was reported from Amman.

TRENTON, April 25 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes proposed a special $126-million urban-aid program today, based primarily on a state income tax and a "moral recommitment" to meet a "New Jersey crisis of massive proportions."

The New York Yankees returned, pleasantly surprised, from their first major road trip of the baseball season yesterday while their National League counterparts -- the Mets -- prepared to invade Cincinnati's Crosley Field tonight in the opener of a three-game series.

FRANCESCO CAVALLI'S "Ormindo" was composed in 1644, and that is about as far back as one can go for an opera, considering that the form was invented by a group of Florentines about 1600. The Juilliard Opera Theater gave the work its American premiere last night, and it turned out to be a real surprise.

DETROIT, April 25 -- The General Motors Corporation today reported that its first-quarter profits were up 17 per cent from last year but complained that strikes and higher labor and material costs hurt the total.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, said today that he would call for the censure or expulsion of any member of Congress who advocated "bending the knee" to demands of Negro leaders planning a massive demonstration -- the Poor People's Campaign -- here next month.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Prospects for early agreement on a Federal tax increase and spending reduction appear to be improving, but the outcome is still far from certain.

Just before bringing home Baird Brittingham's favored Coffee Please in the first race at Aqueduct yesterday, Angel Cordero Jr., the meeting's leading rider, was making light talk in Spanish with Braulio Baeza in the jockeys' room.
Investment for expansion and modernization of productive capacity will show a substantial rise this year, McGraw-Hill, Inc., business publishers, predicted yesterday.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
WITH a new version of Rostand's "Cyrano de Bergerac," the Lincoln Center Repertory Company last night completed its roster of plays at the Vivian Beaumont Theater for the current season.

"LESCARABINIERS," which opened yesterday at the New Yorker Theater and Bleecker Street Cinema, is a film of such extraordinary and understated brilliance that it advances the possibilities of film a step.

The program will be seen here on Channel 13.
A day-long protest by 10 to 20 Negro students at Long Island University ended early today after R. Gordon Hoxie, the chancellor, had agreed to six of seven demands sought by the students.

THE world team olympiad championship that begins in Deauville, France, in six weeks will be the biggest such contest ever played. Thirty-four teams have entered and there will be about half that number in the women's series.
BOATING'S oldest trade organization has decided to hoist anchor and transfer its headquarters from Manhattan's bustling Lexington Avenue to suburban Steamboat Road in Greenwich, Conn.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Federation of American Scientists urged today that the United States suspend indefinitely all nuclear testing as a gesture aimed at halting the spread of nuclear weapons.

The Shell Oil Company turned in the best earnings for any quarter in its history in the first three months of this year, with sales and operating revenues setting a new high for the March quarter, Richard C. McCurdy, president, reported yesterday.

Under the heading "'Reward' for Violence," you published a letter [April 18] advocating that the costs of the "siege" of an area disturbed by rioting should be deducted from "welfare expenditures originally intended for the area." One is both astonished and saddened that such a view should reach print in our outstanding newspaper.

CHICAGO, April 25 (UPI) -- The American League went on record today favoring separation into two six-team divisions beginning with the 1969 season, but took no final action pending future conferences with the National League.

OAKLAND, Calif., April 25 -- Jerry Quarry takes a pill each morning to alleviate an underactive thyroid condition. He had a duodenal ulcer six months ago, but he said it no longer bothered him. As a boy, he suffered from nephritis.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Arthur Joseph Goldberg's seven-year public career has been as spectacular as any in recent times, and the 13 preceding years were not spent in obscurity, either.
THE Hilton Hotel's Trianon Suite was the setting last night for the Bal Rouge et Noir, the handsome little dinner dance that Mrs. Robert W. Sarnoff organizes on behalf of Irvington House.
DES MOINES, Iowa, April 25 -- A chartered orange jet skipped from city to city in the Midwest today, and everywhere it stopped two men hopped out and started acting like candidates.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Senate Committee on Banking and Currency approved day a housing bill authorizing the expenditure of $5.2-billion over the next three years combat urban decay.

Demonstrators ended a four-day sit-in at a Bronx intermediate school yesterday after a Negro was named acting principal and they were promised a greater voice in the appointment of a permanent principal.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Drafters of Congressional maritime policy were told by a leading steamship industry official today that more needed to be done to revitalize the American merchant marine than to appropriate and spend money.

SALEM, Ore., April 25 -- Richard M. Nixon advocated tonight "a new approach" to the nation's racial problems that he said "ought to he oriented towards more black ownership, black pride, black jobs, black opportunity and, yes, black power, in the best, the constructive sense of that often misapplied term."

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 25 -- The Calumet Farm hurled its Forward Pass into a commanding position among the 3-year-olds today. The homebred son of On-and-On won the $32,300 Blue Grass Stakes by five lengths from T. V. Commercial, with Francie's Hat third.

Loew's Theatres, Inc., the hotel and theater complex, made a move yesterday to diversify into the finance, insurance and manufacturing fields with a proposed tender offer for the Commercial Credit Company of Baltimore.

NEWARK, April 25 -- A peaceful antidraft demonstration in downtown Newark was carried out with few incidents today but produced a complaint of police "inaction" by the New Jersey Chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- American and North Vietnamese diplomats met again today in Laos without reaching agreement on a site for preliminary talks between the two nations.
MONZA, Italy, April 25 (AP) -- Paul Hawkins and David Hobbs of Britain drove a Ford GT-40 to victory today in the 1,010-kilometer Monza race for prototypes, sport and grand tourism cars.

"THE best hitters," said Grady Hatton, "are usually the inquisitive ones. They are forever studying the pitchers in a constant search for information. They are always asking questions of other hitters, trying to pick up scraps of information."

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Johnson accepted today "with regret," but without a word of praise, the resignation of Arthur J. Goldberg as the chief United States representative at the United Nations.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- The first Federal Government suit seeking to force desegregation of a school system in a Northern state was filed today in Federal District Court by Attorney General Ramsey Clark.

George M. Bunker, president of the Martin Marietta Corporation, and the top officials of each of the company's four major divisions told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday that this year should be a much better one than 1967.
The market bounded ahead yesterday, with buyers encouraged by the renewed activity of institutions the day before and the daily crop of Vietnam peace rumors.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The nation's traditional surplus of exports over imports disappeared altogether in March, after diminishing since late last year, the Commerce Department reported today. The effect of the 11-day New York dock strike in reducing exports was an important factor in the further deterioration of the trade figures.

ROME, April 25 -- Pope Paul VI re-called Roman Catholics to disciplined orthodoxy today and warned against perils of of "the whilrwind of ideas and events" that arose from the Ecumenical Council Vatican II.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Johnson promised a group of young Democrats today that his withdrawal from candidacy in this election year "does not mean that I am just going to be an uninterested or passive bystander."

Edgar H. Smith Jr., the nation's longest-term death-house inmate, has written about his life and his murder case in a book that will be a Literary Guild alternate selection.
The National Maritime Union yesterday called upon the Department of Labor to act "immediately'' in setting up a new union election in accordance with a Federal Court ruling last week.

DALLAS, Tex., April 25 -- An investigation of alleged racial discrimination in the huge Methodist Publishing House at Nashville, Tenn., was called for today as the new 11-million-member United Methodist Church began its second day of legislative deliberation.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- A senior Marine general whose career was advanced under former Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara has put in for retirement.

LONDON, April 25 (AP) -- Women who take contraceptive pills run nearly 10 times as great a risk to contracting a blood clotting disease as those who do not, the British Government's Medical Research Council said today.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

MILWAUKEE, April 24 -- In the office of Mayor Henry W. Maier, stands a six-foot map of Milwaukee County with the wealthiest suburbs painted the color of money and marked with black dollar signs.

ATHENS -- George Papadopoulos, the colonel who took over the Greek Government a year ago, has taken to playing with a string of worry beads. Not that he's worried about any immediate threat to his power. He toys with the beads because he is a chain smoker and is trying to cut down.

DETROIT, April 27 -- The Rockefeller-for-President Committee's first scouting trip through the hinterlands ended today, and the delegate hunters described themselves as "well pleased" with the results.

ALONG the southern shore of Long Island is a dune wonderland called Fire Island. Recently made into a National Seashore, it is summer residence to hundreds of city dwellers who go out to it by ferry and hire a "jeep taxi," or hike or boat to their cottages. The island has no roads, no private cars, just dunes, lush vegetation and brisk sea breezes.

The lives of yachtsmen who will engage in distance races during the Long Island Sound season that will begin in mid-May will be somewhat more involved this year. They must pay special heed to the sailing instructions issued by sponsoring clubs because of a new rating rule introduced by the Storm Trysail Club.

The University of Notre Dame is nearing completion of a five-year development program and getting ready for the start of another effort of similar length. The present program has involved the expenditure of $20-million for capital improvements, with the major share going to a convocation center, now 80 per cent completed.

More than 30,000 ocean-going vessels called last year at Rotterdam and its subsidiary port development known as Europoort, a Netherlands port official reported here last week. He said the port handled 141.4 million tons of cargo in 1967.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- In his years as a confidential adviser to President Johnson, Clark M. Clifford took a hard, militant line on the war in Vietnam. But since he became Secretary of Defense two months ago, Mr. Clifford, to the surprise of Washington, has spoken of Vietnam in terms of disengagement, accommodation and a negotiated peace.

The Detroit Tigers, who had not scored a run in 20 innings, scored plenty of them in Yankee Stadium yesterday as they overpowered the New York Yankees, 7-0. The Tigers scored early and often, and clung to their American League lead, behind the five-hit pitching of Denny McLain. The 24year-old right-hander stopped the Yankees on five singles scattered across five innings, struck out six batters and was never remotely in trouble.
