WALNUT, Calif., April 27 (AP) -- An Army all-star team from Fort MacArthur turned in the fastest distance-medley face ever run with a time of 9 minutes 33.4 seconds today at the Mount San Antonio Relays. The time is recognized as an American record.

PILAR, N. M. -- Although the Rio Grande becomes a sleepy, muddy stream ("too thin to plow, too thick to drink") farther down, here in northern New Mexico it well deserves its old Spanish name, Rio Bravo del Norte, the fierce river of the north.

Less than 5 per cent of the 104,000 registered motorboats in Massachusetts were inspected in 1967 under the state's compulsory boat inspection plan, Thomas Legere, the state director of motorboats, reported before the joint Legislative Committee on Public Safety.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 27 -Harvard's varsity crew goes on and on. The Crimson eight overwhelmed Princeton and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the Compton Cup race here today. The margin at the finish of the 2,000-meter race was almost four lengths -13.3 seconds for Harvard over Princeton which, in turn, was almost three lengths ahead of M.I.T.

NEW SMYRNA BEACH, Fla. -- This Atlantic Coast resort city will celebrate its 200th anniversary next Saturday. WASHINGTON -- Congress came back to town last week, presumably refreshed from the Easter recess, but hardly anxious to face the months ahead in the final half of this election year session. It was caught between two massive and conflicting pressures.

VALLETTA, Malta -- The traveler who visits this Mediterranean archipelago will be rewarded by getting to know a place where time has stood still in many ways, where people are genuinely courteous and friendly to strangers, where prices are amazingly low and where there are the escapist pleasures of sun and sea, as well as an array of archeological, architectural and artistic treasures.

TODAY'S enthusiasm for "new and improved" strains of flowering plants has almost relegated old-fashioned flowers to the compost pile. Many of these oldtime favorites, however, have a charm that modern flowers lack.

In the four weeks since President Johnson's announcement that he would not run, Vice President Humphrey's strength as a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination has steadily grown. His announcement yesterday of his entry into the race comes after what must be a gratifying show of support from a broad spectrum of his party.

CHURCHTOWN, Pa. -- The ancient pageantry of Rogation, or prayer for the harvest, will be held at historic Bangor Episcopal Church here on Rogation Sunday, May 19. A highlight of the event is a procession to bless "new seed, young flocks and the husbandmen of the vineyards."

THE phrase "by nature" implies an assessment of national character, the imputation of qualities assumed to be innate, deep-rooted, historic, fatefully ineluctable. Anyone who attempts such an exercise might ponder the success of attempts to capture the distinctiveness of English character in such phrases as Elizabethan, Puritan, Restorationist, Georgian, Victorian, Edwardian -- and on to Swinging London.

A PROGRAM of unusual interest has been arranged for the Metropolitan New York Numismatic convention, which begins a four-day run on Thursday at the Park Sheraton Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 56th Street.

WASHINGTON -Weary of crowds and lines at Washington's most popular tourist attractions? There's an "oasis" close at hand. Just two blocks from the Capitol, at 201 East Capitol Street, is the Folger Shakespeare Library, a library-museum that has yet to be discovered by most of the millions of annual visitors to the nation's capital.

MONIQUE VAN VOOREN, the Belgian actress, international sex symbol and theatrical investor, has declared her intention of wearing her new, transparent chiffon blouse by Yves Saint Laurent to the Broadway opening of "Hair" tomorrow evening.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., April 27 -- Stroking over the same type of rough water that contributed to the swamping of five shells in the 1960 edition of the same fixture, a New York Athletic Club eight won the grueling 4 1/4-mile race across Long Island Sound today for the third straight time.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 27 (AP) -Booming drives, sharp irons and 16 one-putt greens carried Jack Lewis to a 7 and 6 victory over Bill Hyndman in the 36-hole finals of the North and South Amateur golf tournament today.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 27 -- The suspension of China Airlines flights to Malaysia and Singapore will be ended next week, it was announced yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, April 27 -- A group of anxious residents here is battling to save the old Hudson County Courthouse before the wrecking ball is ordered to swing against the big granite edifice next month.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Hubert Horatio Humphrey, who rose from South Dakota pharmacist to the Vice-Presidency of the United States, announced today his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for President.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Rumania's Communist leader, Nicolae Ceausescu, appears to Western analysts to have suddenly decided to give a more liberal tinge to his regime, to forestall any internal challenges, such as those that have occurred in Czechoslovakia.

MATTOON, Ill., April 28 (UPI) -- A stocky 18-year-old high school senior captured after a 12-hour manhunt was charged today with shooting to death five farm children, the younger brothers and sisters of the girl he had been dating.

MIAMI, April 28 -- The idea of an inter-American air fleet, first conceived by Colombia eight years ago, has been advocated again by the director of civil aviation of Colombia.

POWNAL, Vt., April 28 -- Strolling and betting leisurely on a day of rest, 5,659 fans wagered their way into history at Green Mountain Race Track today as Vermont became the first state east of the Mississippi to stage Sunday parimutuel thoroughbred racing.
ATHENS, April 28 -- A celebration today at Olympic Stadium provided the climax to the week of festivities marking the Greek revolutionary regime's first year in power.
LONDON, April 28 -- Leaders of 20 immigrant organizations met today in Leamington Spa, Warwickshire, to discuss means of fighting discrimination against Britain's immigrant population.

This question is being posed by opponents of the decentralization plan. It is usually followed by predictions of a mass exodus of qualified and certified teachers and principals from community-controlled schools in Negro neighborhoods.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., April 28 -- A young Santa Barbara couple say they are being "wiped out" as the result of the levying of a Federal tax claim for $1,622,000 against them on the basis of a little known Federal marijuana tax law of 1937.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Vice President Humphrey said today that he could make no promise that United States troops would not be sent to world trouble spots if he was elected President.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Representatives of 56 consumer groups from across the country formed today the Consumer Federation of America, which they hope will speak for all the nation's consumer groups.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) -- Leaders of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference announced today plans for meetings during the next three days with members of President Johnson's Cabinet and key Congressional leaders to present demands for "justice for the poor of America."

The "American Alps" -- Washington State's North Cascades region -- are indeed threatened, but not by the logging and mineral extraction, as was suggested by your April 21 editorial. The threat is that of overconservation, a cause often preached by those who have seen photos of the destruction wrought on America's natural beauty 75 years ago.
Fighting back from the lion pit at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., Robert H. O'Brien, president of the movie company, questioned yesterday the shareholding strength of his latest adversary.

GREENWOOD, Miss., April 28 -- A Negro boycott organized by clerics and run like a military campaign has crippled business in this Mississippi Delta town, forcing one group of white merchants to seek out the boycott leaders and make peace.
Plans for the merger of Horace Mann School and the New York School for Nursery Years, two of the city's leading private schools, were announced yesterday.

A Federal law that would authorize limited wiretapping and eavesdropping by governmental authorities is recommended by two committees of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York in a report released for publication today.

The New York Civil Liberties Union called yesterday for a departmental trial of two high police officers on charges involving allegedly brutal conduct by plainclothes men Saturday in dealing with antiwar demonstrators in Washington Square.
DALLAS, April 28 -- Miller Barber won the Byron Nelson golf classic today by a stroke after Kermit Zarley's spectacular 29 over the last nine holes had barely failed to earn him a tie.

NEW YORK MILLS, April 28 -- Ch. Celou's Michael Macrory, a 4-year-old male Irish setter from Providence, R. I., was named best in show today in a field of 785 dogs at the Central New York Kennel Club show.

ATLANTA, April 28 (UPI) -- Calvin Craig, Grand Dragon of the Georgia United Klans of America, Inc., announced today his resignation from the Klan to help build a nation where "black men and white men can stand shoulder to shoulder in a united America."

BONN, April 28 -- West Germany's extreme right-wing National Democratic party won 9.8 per cent of the total vote today in the state election in Baden Wurttemberg. It was the party's most impressive display of strength to date.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 28 -- Ken Rosewall, the Australian professional, won the world's first open tennis tournament today. The acrobatic little 33-year-old simply smothered his arch rival, Rod Laver, 3-6, 6-2, 6-0, 6-3, for the British hard-court championship.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- A special Senate committee called tonight for creation of a Federal institute on retirement income to re-examine programs and policies relating to the growing numbers of aged Americans.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 28 -- A four-engined DC-8 jetliner on a training flight with a crew of four swerved off the runway at the National Aviation Facilities Experimental Center early today, crashed and burned. The four were hurt, one seriously.

BORIS SPASSKY of the Soviet Union routed his compatriot Evfim Geller, 5 1/2-2 1/2, during their recent candidates' elimination match at the Black Sea port city of Sukhumi. Spassky defeated his fellow grandmaster three times, each time as White in a Sicilian Defense.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- President Johnson's private exchanges with Arthur J. Goldberg about his resignation Tuesday as chief representative at the United Nations are reported to have been almost as chilly as the public announcement.

MONTREAL, April 28 (AP) -- Jacques Lemaire scored his second goal of the game after 2 minutes 24 seconds of an overtime period today to give the Montreal Canadiens a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks and the National Hockey League's East Division playoff title.

MARANELLO, Italy, April 30 -- A prototype Ferrari racing car with a white Pininfarina body is standing idly in the Pininfarina factory at Turin. From time to time it will be exhibited in international auto shows, but the chances are it will never race.

MARCH AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., April 30 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower has suffered what was described today as a "mild" heart attack. He is under intensive care in the cardiac unit of this base's hospital.
Five New York City high school seniors have been selected for the finals of the third annual "WQXR Young Artists Competition" for pianists.

Premier Daniel Johnson of Quebec, here for a two-day visit, said yesterday that independence for Quebec would be "a solution of despair."
For the first time in many years, the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches with more than 800 golfers got under way yesterday with only one bit of trouble.

An initial public offering of the Gleason Works reached the market yesterday at $30 a share and was quickly sold. The offering was made by selling holders, who disposed of 500,374 shares of the producer of gears and gear machinery.

The nation's savings institutions, which provide most of the financing for home construction, sustained a net loss of funds of about $500-million during April, economists estimated yesterday.

LONDON, May 1 -- Bertolt Brecht is a great breaker of British directorial reputations, but Frank Dunlop -- the National Theater's new staff director -- has at least hedged his bet by picking "Edward II," a work that couples the safety of English literature with the hazards of epical theater.

STONY BROOK, L.I., May 1 -- A group of 40 students broke into an office at the State University Center here early today and staged a sit-in to sympathize with protestors at Columbia University and to make demands on their own administrators.

SQUEEZE-PLAY is normally a means by which a declarer embarrasses one or both defenders, but on rare occasions the defending side gets its revenge. It did so on the diagramed deal, played last Friday in the Mixed Pair Championship at the sectional tournament played at Long Beach, L. I.
GENEVA, May 1 -- Sixteen industrialized nations offered today to speed up tariff cuts on American exports to help ease United States balance of payments problems.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 1 -- Analysts of events in Communist China believe the left wing of the Maoist Cultural Revolution there has reasserted itself in the last two months. They think this accounts for the recent purging of the acting army chief of staff, Yang Cheng-wu, and two subordinates.

Attorney General Ramsey Clark has once again expressed optimism that the assassin of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. will soon be captured. Certainly, the nation hopes this optimism is well founded. But, if there is doubt, it is understandable.

J.
PATCHOGUE, L. I., May 1 -- Evidence of possible crimes involving land deals will be presented to a special Suffolk County grand jury Monday, District Attorney George Aspland said today.

ALBANY, May 2 -- The touchy question of decentralizing the New York City school system, one of the most unpopular of all matters before the 1968 Legislature, is mired in confusion, and most Albany officials do not expect any sweeping plan to be enacted this year.
Fifty years ago a group of 100 sweater manufacturers got together to form an association to insure that they could obtain yarn and fiber to keep their small mills going.

YONKERS, May 2 -- Cardinal King's blistering final quarter of 0:28 4-5 beat First Lee of Australia and Cardinal King's stablemate, Cardigan Bay, convincingly in the $50,000 Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

CAIRO, May 2 -- While Egyptians balloted today to give President Nasser a "new mandate," it was announced that he had sent letters yesterday to President Johnson and other chiefs of state of Security Council members expressing "deep appreciation" for the resolution of April 27 urging Israel not to stage her military parade in Jerusalem today.

Earlier this week the president of the Student AfroAmerican Society said that there must be no "further encroachment and expansion of Columbia into the black community." Almost simultaneously the university trustees announced Columbia's readiness "to be associated in mutually constructive undertakings with its immediate neighbors."
MARKS, Miss., May 2 -- A contingent of the Poor People's Campaign organized a protest march tonight in one of the nation's poorest counties.
In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 2 -- The Suffolk County District Attorney's Office obtained a court order today allowing it to examine business and real-estate records belonging to a Councilman in Brookhaven Town. A special grand jury is to begin an investigation Monday into allegations of corruption there.

LONDON, May 2 -- A Jewish organization said here today that it had evidence that Adolf von Thadden, leader of the extreme right-wing National Democratic party in West Germany, had been a member of the Nazi party.

Before another minicrowd at Yankee Stadium, which was swept by squall-like winds, the New York Generals moved into first place in the North American Soccer League's Atlantic Division last night by tying the Boston Beacons, 3-3.
JERUSALEM, May 3 -- Israeli officials reported today that 17 Arabs and one Israeli had been killed in three skirmishes over the last three days.
BRUSSELS, May 3 -- The ris-the costs of the European Economic Community's program to support the income of its 30 million farmers is threatening to touch off a new internal crisis.

WARSAW, May 3 -- The Communist regime has demanded a major shake-up in the film industry that could purge many internationally recognized Polish filmmakers, the official Polish press agency disclosed today.

CORSICANA, Tex., May 3 -- A Braniff International Electra flying through blinding rain and lightning crashed in a ball of flame tonight in a pasture in central Texas. All 84 persons aboard were killed.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 13 (AP) -- Rear Adm. James F. Calvert, who commanded the first production model of the nuclear submarine has been selected as new superintendent of the United States Naval Academy.

A first-rate rock group from San Francisco -- Jefferson Airplane -- and an experimental quartet from Britain, which calls itself The Crazy World of Arthur Brown, were the attractions at two concerts at Fillmore East last night.

ALBANY, May 3 -- New York City could gain as much as $10.1-million in Federal aid for child care if the city and state revised certain administrative procedures, according to a report made public today by the office of State Controller Arthur Levitt.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith charged yesterday that the Government of Japan had failed to adopt a policy that would protect its industry from Arab boycott pressure against trade with Israel.
Acting Sanitation Commissioner Maurice Feldman picked up a pail of litter yesterday, looked around to see if anyone was watching, and dumped it on Duffy Square.
The Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation disclosed a top management change yesterday.
HOUSTON, May 3 -- The heart of a 15-year-old girl who died of a gunshot wound was transferred today to a 47-year-old accountant whose heart was faltering.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Senator Carl Hayden, the dean of the Senate and chairman of the Appropriations Committee, will announce on Monday that he is retiring from the Senate after 56 years of Congressional service.

SYRACUSE, May 3 -- Seven Syracuse University graduate students charged with taking part in a protest that barred access to the administration building on March 12 were given suspended sentences by the Graduate Student Welfare Committee today.
THE employes of Wellco Enterprises, Inc., are about to get an unexpected bonus because the chairman of the boot-making company, Heinz Rollman, has decided to give up leather for peace.

ELLENVILLE, N. Y., May 3 -- Higher interest rates and urban renewal were the focus of discussion here today at the closing session of the 75th annual meeting of the Savings Banks Association of New York State.

Mayor Lindsay urged prominent members of show business yesterday to participate in "Broadway in the Streets," a project that would bring one-hour entertainment shows to low-income areas of New York City this summer.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The United States and Mexico agreed today to create a joint committee for mutual assistance in such civil disasters as earthquakes.
THE North Vietnamese who will serve as his country's chief representative in the forthcoming preliminary peace talks in Paris is regarded by those who know him as a tough and wily negotiator.
BAASTAD, Sweden, May 3 (UPI) -- Several hundred anti-Rhodesian demonstrators forced officials to call off the first-round Davis Cup matches between Rhodesia and Sweden today.

GEORGE BALANCHINE produced a strange and unexpected double-header at the New York State Theater on Thursday night, when New York City Ballet gave the first performance of his new version of "Slaughter on 10th Avenue" and also the premiere of his latest collaboration with Stravinsky.
A model training and education program will be developed by the Police Department under a grant of $77,485 made by the Office of Law Enforcement Assistance of the Department of Justice.

COMPLAINTS about the scarcity of available drawings of high quality grow more and more pitiful these days, but a few dealers still manage to locate them. The Shickman Gallery, 929 Park Avenue at 81st Street, is exhibiting its latest finds, 103 pieces of paper covered with beautiful lines, washes and scribbles.

The first company to move into the projected industrial park at the Brooklyn Navy Yard announced yesterday that it had signed a lease and taken over a building although the park deal itself has not been completed.
LONDON, May 3 -- Britain's first heart transplant was carried out tonight at the National Heart Hospital.
The troubles at Columbia University seem to have had no effect on the number of students who want to study there next year or on the number of employers who want to hire Columbia graduates.

SUSPEND for a time your belief that a floor is simply something to walk on, to support furniture, and to cover up with a rug. At the Architectural League, 41 East 65th Street, Lila Katzen has made it into an art object.

EVANSTON, Ill., Saturday, May 4 -- Negro students continued to occupy Northwestern University's Finance Building here early today, several hours after university officials handed them a "position paper" that reportedly met some of the students' demands.
THE gimmicks are gone. As Seventh Avenue swings into the first part of its fall fashion cycle, the spring's romantic revival has receded and the hemline controversy has subsided.
The threat of loss of accreditation facing St. John's University since 1966 was removed yesterday by the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools, the regional accrediting agency.
A new ship that will run between Miami and Freeport, on Grand Bahama Island, has been launched in Germany and is expected to enter the luxury resort trade next November.

Jefferson Market Courthouse at the southeast corner of West Tenth Street and Sixth Avenue -- now the main Greenwich Village branch of the New York Public Library -- stood for two years with the hands of the clock at twenty minutes after 2. Then devoted and persistent citizens saved the building from threatened demolition, transforming a particularly awkward architectural elephant into the mascot of Greenwich Village.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 3 -- Rouhi el-Khatib, who was driven from office as the mayor of the Jordanian part of Jerusalem by the fighting last June, accused Israel in the Security Council today of trying to change the character of Jerusalem by colonizing former Arab areas with largescale Jewish housing projects.

The impulsive and irresponsible actions of the police in the recent Columbia disturbances have once again made them unwitting allies in the efforts of radicals to cultivate the hatred necessary for their fantasies of revolution.

Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld refused yesterday to grant a change of venue or a long trial delay in the James L. Marcus bribery conspiracy case after hearing charges of prejudicial publicity by defense lawyers.

MOSCOW, May 3 -- A group of Crimean Tatars was reported today to have protested to the Soviet Communist party's ty's Politburo and the Government that 300 Tatars, members of a minority that was exiled during World War II, were arrested April 21 in a town near Tashkent after an all-day battle with soldiers and policemen.

PALO ALTO, Calif., May 3 -- Joseph Rizor, a 40-year-old carpenter who received a transplanted heart in an operation at Palo Alto-Stanford Hospital, was having difficulty 24 hours later in keeping his blood oxy genated as it passed through his lungs.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- A bathtub with a side door, which was patented this week by Mrs. Ron Hanson of North Miami, Fla., has become a family project. When Mrs. Hanson invented the tub she had her mother, Mrs. Michael Ragen, in mind.

President Johnson has evidently decided to stop shadowboxing in private over the tax bill and start fighting in public. His assertion at his news conference that opponents of a tax increase are trying to "blackmail" him is the toughest language he has ever used about Congress during his five years in the White House.

MARKS, Miss., May 3 -- Howard C. Langford, a soft-spoken white man who has served for 18 years as Mayor of this quiet town in the Delta region of northwestern Mississippi, endorsed "the goals but not the methods" of the Poor Peoples' Campaign today.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Some officials believe that a major military push will be timed by the enemy to coincide with the early phases of the preliminary peace talks in Paris, to which Hanoi agreed today, and with the intensive political campaign in the United States.
Following is a transcript of President Johnson's news conference in the East Room of the White House, yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
PATERSON, N. J., May 3 -F. Lee Bailey, the criminal lawyer, was barred by a State Superior Court judge today from serving as a defense counsel in the DeFranco-Kavanaugh murder cases.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., May 3 (UPI) -- President Johnson gave former President Harry S. Truman a personal report on developments in the proposed Vietnam peace talks today.

STRATFORD, Ontario -- Shakespeare no longer provides the bulk of the dramatic presentation at the Stratford Festival. Of the six productions now in preparation for the season opening June 10, only two are Shakespeare works, "A Midsummer Night's Dream" and "Romeo and Juliet."
PARIS, May 3 -- More than 500 students were arrested and scores injured today when armed riot policemen charged the quadrangle of the Sorbonne and evicted left-wing demonstrators.
WASHINGTON May 3 (AP) -- Top officials of a leading drug manufacturing company defended today its advertising practices and the efficiency of a drug widely used in treating arthritic disorders.

One gets the impression from the recent disturbances at Columbia University that it is an institution adrift. The indecisive attitude adopted by Columbia's administration toward a minority of undergraduate students may not resolve the present impasse and may indeed imperil the institution's survival.

It appears to me that a very important issue facing Columbia and every major university today has been neglected while concern centers about the status of Grayson Kirk's office and alleged police brutality.
HONG KONG, May 3 -- A new revolutionary committee to rule Shensi Province, in northwest China, was established Wednesday.

A contingent of Republicans for McCarthy will barnstorm in Indiana for the next few days, urging fellow Republicans to cast cross-over votes for Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, a Democrat, in the Presidential primary next Tuesday.

Whatever faint hope the Administration may have had for the success of its hold-the-line pleas on the wage-price front evaporate with the tentative settlement of the two-week-old strike of Bell System employes. The accord freezes into the 1968 pattern a settlement rate of roughly 6.5 per cent a year, double the long-term growth in national productivity.

BERLIN, May 3 -- Official sources said today it was "virtually certain" that Adolf von Thadden, chairman of West Germany's extreme right-wing National Democratic party, voluntarily applied for membership in the Nazi party in 1939.

Mayor Lindsay's indictment of the Public Service Commission for its failure to protect consumers is thoroughly justified. But we do not agree with his suggestion that the best remedy would be for the city to establish its own regulatory agency to supplant the P.S.C.

Carnegie Hall's International Festival of Visiting Orchestras for this season came to a close last night with a concert by the Philadelphia Orchestra. The program ended in a way that seemed appropriate, to the occasion, for the final work was Bruckner's Fourth, or "Romantic," Symphony.

MOSCOW, May 3 -- A dozen writers in the Ukraine have come under a threat of disciplinary action for a strong protest to the Soviet leadership over closed trials of intellectuals in the Ukraine and elsewhere in the Soviet Union.
Peace talk in the morning and tax talk in the afternoon gave silver, platinum and palladium a fast-moving trading day.

A newly formed organization at Columbia University that says it represents 4,000 striking students refused yesterday to call for the resignation of the university's president and vice president in submitting its first list of demands for settling the dispute.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- President Johnson, showing unmistakable signs of emancipation from political stress, needled the Presidential candidates and roughed up Congress in a free-swinging White House news conference today.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- The Federal Communication Commission announced today that it was permitting Western Union to increase its rates Sunday.

LONDON, May 3 -- The free-market gold price, which had been rising steadily, dropped 50 cents an ounce this afternoon in a favorable European reaction to news that Vietnam peace talks would begin in Paris about May 10. Stock market prices rose.

The Police Civilian Complaint Review Board has received 48 complaints of alleged police brutality on the Columbia campus. Two hundred more have been received by a student group acting with the cooperation of the National Lawyers Guild and the New York Civil Liberties Union.
EVANSVILLE, Ind., May 3 -- Gov. Roger D. Branigin acknowledged for the first time today that his favorite-son Presidential campaign had trouble spots.
KENT, Ohio, May 3 -- Vice President Humphrey turned a student protest into a triumph today during a one-day tour of Ohio.
City property owners were told yesterday by Controller Mario A. Procaccino that their 1968-69 real estate tax rate would probably be lower than had been predicted.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- Bill Monbouquette pitched another fine game tonight and added luster to his unexpected role as the only man standing between the New York Yankees and oblivion. He defeated the Chicago White Sox, 3-2, to end a four-game Yankee losing streak and to bring his personal won-lost record to 4-1.
The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday it was setting up a new procedure for use in the near future to speed the reporting of its ticker in periods of heavy volume.
Governor Rockefeller welcomed yesterday President Johnson's announcement that preliminary talks with North Vietnam would begin in Paris next week.
Investors were active again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market with volume and prices advancing.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- President Johnson said today that the Government was concerned about the "many inherent dangers" in the planned camp-in here in the Poor People's Campaign.

Central Park, the scene of happenings, open-air concerts and peace marches, was the green setting for a different aspect of New York last night when nearly 1,000 guests gathered at the Bethesda Fountain for New York Junior League's Medallion Ball.

The historic first open tennis tournament in the United States, with $100,000 in prize money for the professionals, will be played at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, from Aug. 29 through Sept. 8.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) -- The Navy is willing to make a submarine rescue service available to any country that asks for it, including Communist nations, officials said today.
SAIGON, May 4 -- South Vietnamese troops and American helicopter crews killed 194 Vietcong soldiers yesterday in a daylong battle 28 miles southwest of Saigon.

LOUISVILLE, May 3 -- Forward Pass, the star of the Calumet Stable, took the expected lead in the betting for the 94th running of the Kentucky Derby tomorrow. A field of 14 has been named to answer the starter's call for the famous race for 3-year-olds at a mile and a quarter at Churchill Downs.

LLOYD HARBOR, L. I. -- A band of horticultural enthusiasts -- about 400 women and a scattering of men -- went on a busman's holiday this week. They were participants in the New York Botanical Garden's annual spring tour of five houses.
In the julep-less security of Aqueduct's Man O'War Room, Clocker Lawton predicted yesterday that Forward Pass would win today's Kentucky Derby.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Despite pressure to trim domestic spending, the House Appropriations Committee voted today to increase the flow of Federal funds into city programs.

America's domestic scheduled airlines have reported a 16.3 per cent increase in passenger traffic over the first quarter of 1967, but not nearly enough to fill their planes. The passenger load factor -- the proportion of available seats sold -- was down from 55.9 per cent to 51.5.
Dr. Fager will be the big horse at the Big A today.

DETROIT, May 3 -- Three Detroit policemen and a private guard were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on a charge of conspiring to violate the civil rights of 10 persons during the Detroit riot last July.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Ten years ago, the two square blocks of solid sandstone, granite, brick and marble built and rebuilt as the Patent Office by Robert Mills, William Elliot, Edward Clark and others from 1836 through the 1880's, a monument in the noblest of Washington's classical styles, was scheduled to be pulverized and replaced by blacktop.

PARIS, May 3 -- The choice of Paris as the site for preliminary peace talks led informed French observers to predict today that President de Gaulle would eventually play a major active role in the search for a settlement in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The United States and North Vietnam agreed today to begin formal talks in Paris next Friday or soon thereafter.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The National Collection of Fine Arts, which has been without a home it could call its own since it was created by Congress in 1846, finally made it tonight.
THIRD-HAND-HIGH is far from being the unbreakable rule that some beginners are led to believe, but the third player will hardly ever be willing to concede a cheap trick to the declarer.
A recent offer by 16 nations to accelerate tariff cuts on American exports was sharply criticized yesterday as not being the right way to remove "inequities" of the Kennedy round agreement.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., May 3 -- Richard M. Nixon said today that any Presidential candidate who indicated in advance the concessions he would give the North Vietnamese would be jeopardizing the chances for peace in Southeast Asia.

Major realty interests here, which have long been critical of the way the state Public Service Commission regulates electric utilities, yesterday opposed Mayor Lindsay's call for a city regulatory agency to supplant the commission.

Yesterday's agreement on Paris as the site for Vietnam preliminary peace talks marks a major diplomatic breakthrough. Washington's patient search for a setting suitable for substantive negotiations has been gratifyingly rewarded. Concern about the genuineness of Hanoi's interest in talking at all has been greatly eased. Paris represents a logical choice for both sides.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- President Johnson, using unusually strong language about Congress, demanded at a news conference today that the members "stand up like men" and pass a tax increase "even in an election year."

STRATFORD - ON - AVON, England, May 3 -- Thanks to the old tale that "The Merry Wives of Windsor" was a pot-boiler written by Shakespeare in a fortnight to amuse the Queen, directors have habitually treated it as an entertainment play with no purpose beyond raising laughter -- which it often failed to do.
President Johnson's mood of despair over a tax increase spread to the money and capital markets yesterday, dispersing almost all hope that interest rates will not climb higher.

PARIS, May 3 -- The chestnut blossoms are out all along the banks of the Seine. Children are riding donkeys and sailing little boats in the Tuileries Gardens, and elderly couples are sunning themselves on the benches of the small park behind Notre-Dame.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Following is the text of the statement of the North Vietnamese Foreign Ministry regarding the level, place and time of formal talks with the United States, broadcast by the Hanoi radio's English-language service today and monitored here:
Freddie Hubbard's Quartet completed this season's series of four "Jazz: The Personal Dimension" concerts at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
Students broke up a faculty meeting at the Brooklyn Center of Long Island University yesterday and prevented Chancellor R. Gordon Hoxie from delivering an appeal for unity within the university.
The lecturers were graduates of the Harlem Assassins and the Lower East Side Untouchables, and they had a tough message for their class of 45 public school teachers.
The Police Department has decided to sharply limit the use of detectives and plainclothes men to control crowds at demonstrations and disturbances here.

A handsome Pacific - type steam locomotive will be up front when a 15-car train pulls out of Camden, N. J., tomorrow morning with a full load of 850 passengers -- and with some 400 to 500 others disappointed at not being able to get aboard.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 3 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota said today that the agreement on preliminary negotiations would not have much effect on his campaign for the Democratic nomination for President.
DAIDO, South Vietnam, May 3 -- It was not much of a village, even when the buildings were standing. Now there is nothing but rubble and the smell of death and destruction.
PAINTED furniture made in 19-century America has so far attracted only the fairly small group of collectors interested in folk art, except for the distinctive work of Pennsylvania Germans.

OTTAWA, May 3 (AP) -- The Finance Minister, Edgar Benson, has announced guidelines Canadian chartered banks will follow to prevent "pass-throughs" of United States dollars to other countries. Without special action, the banks could have been used as a loophole to permit the investment of United States funds abroad, thus frustrating the United States attempt to stop its dollar drain.

The Symetrics Engineering Corporation marketed 100,000 shares of common stock in a first public offering yesterday and by the end of trading the shares had been bid up to $13.50-$14.50 from the original price of $10.
DALLAS, May 3 (AP) -- The United Methodist Church asserted today that when citizens cannot get justice by legal means, they have a right to disobey the law and take the consequences.

LOUISVILLE, May 3 -- Two stout women from St. Louis, their sparse blue hair damp and limp from the heat of the noon, peered into the darkened stall. One of them said, "Hi, boy, how are you feeling today?," and when the horse didn't answer, the other woman turned to the groom, Dan Barnette, and asked: "What do you call him?"
RICHMOND, May 3 -- Playing on courts in his hometown, Lieut. Arthur Ashe gave the United States Davis Cup team a 2-0 lead over the British Caribbean team today.
PRAGUE, May 3 -- A student rally today in Prague's Old Town Square supporting the democratization of Czechoslovakia swiftly assumed a markedly anti-Communist character.

OAKLAND, Calif., May 3 (UPI) -- Alex Hannum, who resigned as coach of the Philadelphia 76ers of the National Basketball Association last Monday, signed a long-term contract today with the Oakland Oaks of the American Basketball Association.
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had taken strong disciplinary action against one of its member organizations, two of the concern's officers and one former officer.
THE growing phenomenon of resistance to the draft by American youth was explored rather superficially last night on the National Broadcasting Company's "We Won't Go."

QUANTICO, Va., May 3 -Two sub-four-minute-mile legs in the collegiate distance medley, a winning late spurt in the four-mile relay by New York University and a superb showing by Rick Urbina in the special 880-yard run spiced the opening today of the Quantico Relays.
News of the selection of Paris as a site for negotiations between the United States and North Vietnam sent stock prices soaring in an explosive opening rally yesterday.
Of 455 persons executed for rape since 1930, 405, or 90 per cent, were Negroes, an official of the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., said yesterday.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 3 -- County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson released plans today for a projected mass transportation system to serve central Nassau County and ease "intolerable" traffic congestion in the area.

Testifying in a civil action in which he is a defendant, Edward Krock said yesterday that Victor Muscat, a co-defendant, agreed to pay excessive law fees from Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc. in 1966 to Roy M. Cohn, another co-defendant.
MADISON, Ind., May 3 -- In this Ohio River town of 10,000, perhaps one-fourth of the adult population turned out today to hear Senator Robert F. Kennedy speak from the court-house steps.

A 16-year-old boy who the police said was carrying a blood-stained stiletto was arrested at 2:30 A.M. yesterday in Tompkins Square Park after allegedly stabbing one person, robbing two others and attempting to rob a fourth.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 3 -- The drastic diet used to prevent brain damage in babies afflicted with the genetic disorder phenylketonuria may itself cause mental retardation, a scientist said here today.

Net earnings of the Outboard Marine Corporation for the second fiscal quarter ended March 31 rose to $4,054,060, equal to 51 cents a share, compared with $3,908,003, or 49 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter of the preceding fiscal year, it was reported yesterday from Waukegan, Ill. Sales rose to $72,872,166 in the 1968 period from $61,654,233 in 1967.

BATON ROUGE, La., May 3 (AP) -- A United States District Court judge accused the Justice Department today of a "payoff" because of its refusal to prosecute criminal charges against a local union leader who gave key testimony at the trial of James R. Hoffa, teamsters union president.

A long controversy at the theological school of Drew University in Madison, N. J., has moved toward settlement by a decision to revise the school's charter and reshuffle the university's board of trustees.

As graduate students at Columbia University, we the undersigned wish to dispute the validity of a widespread interpretation of the recent events on the Columbia campus in which police were called in to remove student demonstrators from campus buildings. This interpretation places the major blame for the violence that occurred on the students.

The financially troubled Saturday Evening Post, once the country's magazine with the greatest circulation, is going to drop about half its subscription list and put the emphasis on "quality of circulation, editorial content and appearance."
CAIRO, May 3 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser received nearly unanimous approval of his policies and program in a plebiscite yesterday that brought 98.2 per cent of registered voters to the polls.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 3 -- Brazil urged the General Assembly today to withhold endorsement of the United States-Soviet draft treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.
The American Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a gain of 10 per cent in operating revenues for the 12 months ended March 31.

The Avco Corporation is planning to add a film-producing company to its extensive diversified activities through the proposed acquisition of the Embassy Pictures Corporation for stock worth $40-million.

THESE fifteen learned essays take a critical look at various aspects of the ancient world (Greece, Rome, the Middle East). They recapitulate some history, glance at old controversies, call attention to new discoveries. M.I. Finley, an American scholar, now a Fellow of Jesus College and a teacher at the University of Cambridge, author of "The World of Odysseus" and other books, writes in a plain style without flourishes or adornments.
The 22d anniversary spring dinner dance of the Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center will be held this year on May 15 in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom.
An attempt will be made this summer to determine if a drug can improve the learning abilities of mentally retarded children, a California psychobiologist reported yesterday.
MOSCOW, May 3 (Reuters) -- The ideological crackdown on Soviet intellectuals by the Communist party chief, Leonid I. Brezhnev, is having its effect on Moscow's foreign community.
MOSCOW, May 4 -- Alexander Dubcek and three other leaders of the reformist regime in Czechoslovakia conferred today in the Kremlin with the Soviet leadership.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- The New York Yankees flirted with the indignity of being held hitless today, then lost a game-end argument and a decision to the Chicago White Sox, 4-1, before only 3,878 paying customers at Comiskey Park. Youth groups swelled the actual attendance to 8,000.
BOTH the old and the new in Russian literature -much of its first rate -- is offered in this season's list of books available to young readers of all ages.

THE MIRACLE OF FLIGHT. By Richard Cromer and the staff of Don Meier Productions. Illustrated by Joseph Cellini. 159 pp. New York: Doubleday Co. $4.95.
WEST POINT, N. Y., May 4 -- The University of Maryland lacrosse team eliminated Army from the race for the national championship by beating the Cadets, 13-8, today before 3,500 persons.

THE American Air Mail Society will celebrate its 45th anniversary at Washington's Willard Hotel, beginning Saturday and continuing through next Wednesday, May 15. It will share in observance of the Golden Air Mail Anniversary, and the issuance of a 10-cent multicolored United States airpost stamp commemorating the inauguration, on May 15, 1918, of airmail service between Washington, Philadelphia and New York.

THE BOY WHO MADE A MILLION. By Sidney Offit. Illustrated by Mercer Mayer. 148 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $3.95.

AFTER all these years of Hollywood and TV melodramatics (the images alternating wildly between treacherous savage and improbably noble red man) publishers are making a commendable effort this spring to give the real Indians back to America.

LONDON, May 4 -- London's traffic authorities want Parliament to give them power to keep commuter drivers out of Central London by regulating all-day parking in private as well as public lots.

BURNSVILLE, N. C. -- This Appalachian town is probably as tucked away and as noncommercial a place as can be found in this country today. Yet, it is well appointed for entertainment of a certain kind, and for caring for one's physical needs in a more or less standard tourist way.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 4 -- New power projects costing more than a billion dollars are under construction or scheduled by the Tennessee Valley Authority.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, May 5 -- Vietcong and North Vietnamese troops opened a series of mortar and rocket attacks in Saigon and in cities and military bases throughout South Vietnam this morning.

This week's auctions at the Parke-Bernet Galleries are divided about equally between rare books and manscripts as fine antique furniture and art, with rarities in both categories.

That is the striking picture in Britain today.

THE New Jersey dog clubs have followed the lead of Kentucky and banded together in a new organization called the New Jersey Dog Federation to foster canine interests in the state.

Destroying the Electoral College, whether by abolishing it outright or by proportionalizing each state's electoral vote, will not result in greater democratization but in less, by reducing the influence of the populous states on the nominating process.
The capital-appreciation fund continued to corner the market last week in the proliferation of new mutual funds.

At Port Latta on the northern coast of Tasmania iron ore is moving in from a mine 53 miles inland through a pipe-line. The ore is pumped in over a mountain, is formed into pellets and started on a mile-long conveyor system to a ship in deep water in an unusual kind of terminal operation.

American Eagle, twice unsuccessful as an America's Cup defense candidate, re-entered the water last week at Fair Haven, Mass., with new owners a new name and under a new flag. She no longer is a 12-Meter yacht.

SAIGON, South Vietnam -- "I know one thing," said an American official yesterday at one of the numerous conferences at the United States Embassy, "I don't particularly want to be around here when the first pictures appear showing the North Vietnamese and the Americans sitting down at the conference table.

Julia Rajauskas, a pianist who graduated from the Conservatory of Lithuania, made her New York recital debut at Town Hall in 1958. She returned there late yesterday afternoon for her second appearance.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M. -- This burgeoning city of more than 250,000 people has become one of the important tourism centers in the nation. It is on U.S. 66, the Santa Fe Railroad and the routes of several airlines, and it is bisected by the Rio Grande.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy of New York captured tonight the District of Columbia's 23 delegate votes to the Democratic National Convention.
Gerald Tsai Jr., the man who made big money mutual funds a glamour business, is moving his fund group into partnership with an old-line insurance holding giant based in Chicago.

The Federal Reserve Board, under heavy pressure from the New York Stock Exchange as well as from some of the nation's largest banks, withdrew yesterday three controversial provisions of its new margin rules.

BOSTON, May 7 (AP) -- Pete Fuller, stunned by the disqualification of his Kentucky Derby winner, Dancer's Image, charged tonight that his horse had been tampered with and promised a full investigation of the matter.

The value of commercial land in the Watts district of Los Angeles has fallen about 20 per cent since rioting swept the Negro ghetto there in August of 1965, according to a real estate appraisal concern.
PRAGUE, May 7 -- New disclosures were made today implicating the Soviet secret police in the purges of Czechoslovak Communist leaders in the early nineteen-fifties.
The House of Representatives is scheduled today to consider the bill to provide money for several agencies, including the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 7 -- Mark down the Indiana primary as the one in which Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota proved that he was a serious contender for President of the United States. Score it also as one that confirmed that Senator Robert F. Kennedy of New York is both a big voteone more demonstration that Richard M. Nixon has a powerful voting appeal among Republicans.
Investors apparently digested the prospects of a tax increase without difficulty yesterday as the American Stock Exchange moved ahead in active trading.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation distributed today two more photographs of the accused killer of the Rev. Dr Martin Luther King Jr. One of the photos was described as "an extremely good likeness."

Anshel Brusilow and his Chamber Symphony of Philadelphia played a concert at Carnegie Hall last night that was no laughing matter. That's unfortunate, because it was planned as an entire evening of musical jokes.

Gil Evans, the arranger and conductor who has been part of the jazz underground for most of the last 20 years, surfaced last night at the Whitney Museum of American Art to give his first concert in New York since 1961.
Refined musicianship and professional expertise marked the sonata program given last night at Carnegie Recital Hall by Rachmael Weinstock and Joseph Seiger.

An entry placed one, two in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. Hail the Queen and Silver True, two of C. V. Whitney's older fillies without any special distinction, thus took down 85 per cent of the $15,000 purse -- $12,750 -- on a sunny, but brisk afternoon with 27,115 in attendance.

A cardboard guitar with rubber bands for strings and a pencil for a bridge illustrates principles of sound; an anemometer constructed from cardboard and corks measures the wind speed; a miniature generator, which looks like a pencil sharpener, activates a light bulb.
The latest Harris Survey indicates that Governor Rockefeller of New York would be a stronger Republican candidate for President than former Vice President Richard M. Nixon.

STANFORD, Calif., May 7 (UPI) -- Arsonists burned down the Navy Reserve Officer Training Corps headquarters at Stanford University today while a quiet student sit-in closed an administration building for the second day.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 7 -- The Radio Corporation of America's 49th annual meeting in Clowes Memorial Hall on the Butler University campus here today went relatively unnoticed as the state held its Presidential primary.
City officials have developed preliminary plans to handle 10,000 or more arrests a day if there is racial violence here this summer.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Department of the Interior wiped out today 5,200 mining claims on the oil-rich federally owned shale lands in Colorado and Utah.

AS a novelty, the last concert of the New Image of Sound series at Hunter College devoted the first half of its program last night to films. The idea was to take three important contemporary composers -- Harry Partch, John Cage and Edgard Varese -- and show how they accommodated their art to a different medium. Anyway, mixed media are all the rage these days.

Woe continued to pile upon woe for the New York Yankees last night as they lost to the Cleveland Indians, 8-0, before 6,630 fans at Yankee Stadium. It was their eighth loss in the last 10 games and their worst defeat of the season.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 8 -- Flames swept along the southern and western edges of Saigon this morning as enemy forces renewed their rocket and mortar attacks on the capital.

Horsemen at Aqueduct reacted yesterday with a mixture of pride and dismay to the disqualification of Dancer's Image as the winner of the Kentucky Derby.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- A joint Senate-House conference committee reported some progress today, though no definite decisions, in its effort to work out a tax increase, coupled with mandatory curbs on Government spending.
LOS ANGELES, May 7 (AP) LOS -- A three-year study of 400 persons shows many improved their mood and their heart performance by changing their diet.

ALBANY, May 7 -- A bill that would crack down on fraudulent use of credit cards won final legislative approval in the Assembly today after sharp debate over whether it might put too much of a burden on the honest credit-card holder.
WOODMERE, L. I., May 7 -- Jerry Pittman, who teaches golf and competes in tournaments, won the Long Island open today by three strokes.

The departmental trial of a policeman was stopped yesterday after he had obtained a court order directing the Police Department and the Kings County District Attorney's office to show that he was not the victim of a conspiracy between them.
NEW YORK has a new Zoo, complete with green grass, trees, park benches, cages and exotic attractions. The attractions, however, are not live animals. They're see- through vinyl clothes -- for men.
LISBON, May 7 -- There is a move on in Portugal to make peace with Christopher Columbus.

Vietnam's Communists are mounting new attacks on South Vietnamese cities while simultaneously moving toward peace talks in Paris. This is the old Maoist "talk-talk, fight-fight" strategy followed by the Vietminh in 1954 and openly espoused by Hanoi in recent weeks.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Administration formally named today the six-man delegation headed by Ambassador at Large W. Averell Harriman that will represent the United States in Paris.

ALBANY, May 7 -- Governor Rockefeller urged the Legislature today to expand and strengthen the state's civil rights laws and to make their enforcement more effective.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -Five New York Congressmen urged state leaders today to withhold action on any new taxing power for New York City until a Federal investigation was made of the city's welfare program.

Frank R. Milliken, president of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, told the annual meeting yesterday that the lengthy copper strike caused the company to suffer a loss of $7.8-million, or 23 cents a share, in the first quarter of this year.

The Ford Foundation has established an independent fund for the city's use, and pledged $1-million annually to the fund over the next five years, to help improve the municipal government's effectiveness.
PEKING, May 7 (Agence France-Presse) -- Jean Vincent, head of the Agence France-Presse bureau in Peking, was ordered to leave China today.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Wednesday, May 8 -- Senator Frank J. Lausche, Ohio's vote-getter extraordinary for 46 years, met defeat yesterday in the Democratic primary.

Dancer's Image, the colt who thrilled the racing world with a last-to-first rally in Saturday's Kentucky Derby, was dropped from first to last yesterday after chemical tests disclosed he had run with a pain-killing drug in his system.
Thousands of parents, teachers and children demonstrated outside hundreds of schools here yesterday to protest a proposed reduction in the Board of Education's expense budget for 1968-69.
A former funeral parlor at 455 West 43d Street, between 9th and 10th Avenues, has been converted into the Gotham Art Theater.

Thailand sees little hope for a real and lasting peace in Southeast Asia regardless of the outcome of talks between the United States and North Vietnam scheduled to begin in Paris this week, Premier Thanom Kittikachorn declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Representative William L. Dawson, apparently abandoning plans to abolish the Subcommittee on Foreign Operations and Government Information, has asked more money to let it continue.

Alexander B. Trowbridge, who resigned Feb. 16 as Secretary of Commerce for reasons of health, was named president of the American Management Association yesterday.
The Rockefeller for President Committee yesterday did the expected and named Jack Tinker Partners as the agency to handle Gov. Nelson Rockefeller's campaign for the Republican nomination.

Interest rates continued to reach record highs yesterday as a large number of new fixed-income security issues were marketed. Investors, spurred by Congressional action on the tax increase, quickly bought most of them.

PARIS, Wednesday, May 8 -- President de Gaulle warned yesterday that further violence in the streets would not be tolerated. His warning came as thousands of policemen cor doned off the Latin Quarter to avert a third round of student rioting.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 7 -- In this storybook cliffside town where old gentlemen still wear spats and white vests while walking the most elegant dogs in Europe, they are getting ready for one of the most picturesque races of all -- the Grand Prix de Monaco on Sunday, May 26.

PARIS, May 7 -- The second-ranking member of the North Vietnamese delegation arrived from Hanoi today for the preliminary United States-North Vietnamese talks.
WASHINGTON. May 7 -- The free market signaled to the Government today for the first time the going yield on Government-backed mortgages. It was 7 per cent.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) -- The House voted today for a two-year, $2-million study of the nation's auto insurance.
