A Columbia University disciplinary committee recommended yesterday that student rebels be placed on probation for a year, and that those guilty of vandalism and theft be suspended or expelled but that criminal trespass charges against them be dropped.
THE United States team will have its last serious practice match here tonight before its departure for Europe at the end of the month.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The chairman of a House subcommittee charged today that staff investigators had received evidence that a Chicago television station staged a marijuana party, it depicted as having been held on the Northwestern University campus.
The defense began a barbed cross-examination of Barry Goldwater in Federal Court yesterday on the fourth day of his $2-million libel action against Ralph Ginzberg, the publisher.

COMMACK, L.I., May 9 -- Suffolk County taxpayers rejected 10 of 33 school budgets yesterday. In two days of voting this week, 11 of 49 budgets were disapproved. This was fewer than last year's taxpayer revolt in which 18 of 53 budgets were rejected.

BOONTON MANOR, N. J., May 9 -- Dom Ferrone of Brooklyn College, an ex-ball retriever at a Flatbush driving range, became today the first City University student to win individual honors at the Metropolitan Golf Association intercollegiate championships.
PARIS, May 9 -- The negotiators seeking an end to the war in Vietnam will work against a background of hawks and doves -- and pelicans, peacocks and parrots.

HONG KONG, May 9 -- A Canton newspaper has reported that Mao Tse-tung was in Wuhan last July when the local military commander attempted a "counterrevolutionary coup d'etat." Mr. Mao, according to the paper, escaped only 20 minutes before the building in which he was staying was encircled by rebellious soldiers and civilians.

MONTPELLIER, France, May 9 (UPI) -- A 65-year-old Frenchman was reported to be in "satisfactory" condition today after receiving a new heart at the world's oldest medical school. It was the 13th human heart transplant in history.

CAIRO, May 9 -- The United Arab Republic accepted today the proposal of Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations envoy, to transfer the work of his peace mission from the Middle East to the United Nations headquarters in New York.

The American National Opera Company, in deep financial trouble after its first season of touring, has called off its fall trip. The company filed a petition in Federal Court here on Wednesday under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act, listing its liabilities as $840,000 and its assets as $150,000.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Both President Johnson and Congress appeared undecided today whether to accept a $6-billion budget cut linked to a tax increase.
WHENEVER there's a block trade in Columbia Pictures the handicappers in Wall Street perk up.
Carmine (Junior) Persico was Carmine convicted with three other defendants in Federal Court, Brooklyn, last night on charges of hijacking. The jury of 10 men and two women deliberated five hours.
The most ambitious school building program in the city's history was proposed yesterday by Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan in his tentative capital budget request for 1969-70

A doubling of New York City's $5-million Federal allocation for summer programs was asked by the city's antipoverty leaders last night. At the same time ,it became known that a Federal deadline for submitting city programs had already passed.
Carmine (Junior) Persico was Carmine convicted with three other defendants in Federal Court, Brooklyn, last night on charges of hijacking. The jury of 10 men and two women deliberated five hours.
The most ambitious school building program in the city's history was proposed yesterday by Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan in his tentative capital budget request for 1969-70

A doubling of New York City's $5-million Federal allocation for summer programs was asked by the city's antipoverty leaders last night. At the same time ,it became known that a Federal deadline for submitting city programs had already passed.

Prices in the money and capital markets rose slightly early yesterday in response to news that House and Senate conferees had cleared a 10 per cent Federal income-tax surcharge coupled with a $6-billion reduction in spending in the fiscal year ahead.

WASHINGTON, May 10, (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration announced today new labeling requirements for birth control pills because of new evidence it says indicates the pills may be hazardous to health.

A long-range "Israeli-Arab situation" in Vietnam -- tense frontiers between North Vietnam and South Vietnam, protracted guerilla activity and occasional major reprisal actions -- was projected yesterday by members of a research group that has analyzed the war effort in Vietnam under contract for various United States Government agencies.

Genuine decentralization of the city's school system is in imminent danger of sabotage by a combination of political cowardice in Albany and political maneuvering in New York. False allegations and unreasonable fears, fed by a variety of vested interests, contribute to the confusion and are paving the way to disaster.
The Treasury announced yesterday that it raised about $2-billion of new cash in its big offering of 6 per cent notes earlier this week.
BEATRICE, Neb., May 10 -Senator Robert F. Kennedy campaigned for the Presidency in low key today through six small towns in predominantly Republican Nebraska.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 -Marietta college of Ohio, seeking its third straight victory in the colorful varsity crew event, was among the 18 qualifiers today in the 30th annual Dad Vail regatta on the Schuylkill River.

First National Stores, Inc., which operates a chain of about 485 food stores, mainly in New England, but also here and in New Jersey, is planning to expand its Long Island operation by acquiring the King Kullen Grocery Company.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 10 -Classes returned to normal today in Camden High School although the school's 425 white students, fearful of violence, stayed away for the fourth successive day.

Leopold Stokowski was named Senior Musician of the Year yesterday and given a gold lifetime membership card by the Senior Musicians Association of Local 802, the American Federation of Musicians. The presentation to the 86-year-old conductor was made by Max L. Arons, president of the organization, at a luncheon Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) -- Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, said today he regretted that leaders of his own party had not joined Richard M. Nixon in focusing on crime as the major issue of the election.
Stock prices edged upward yesterday as trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange dipped to the lowest level in six weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- A sleek, gray Polaris submarine slipped out of her pen at Holy Loch, Scotland, one day recently and nosed out toward the North Atlantic to take up a secret patrol station from which her 16 missiles could reach targets deep inside the Soviet Union in the event of war.

NEW ORLEANS, May 10 (AP) -- George Archer, a former California cow puncher, shot a 6-under-par 65 today and took a one-stroke lead with a total of 134 in the $100,000 Greater New Orleans open golf tourney.
HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 10 -- Mike Mattwell retained a place at the top of the field in the William D. Richardson Memorial golf tournament today as he shared the 36-hole lead with a total of 148.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 10 -- Regarded as a sophisticated student of government who is not afraid to face up to the humdrum duties of political office, Albert Preston Brewer has spent the last five years as the legislative spark for two Wallace administrations -- first that of George C. Wallace and, more recently, Mrs. Lurleen B. Wallace.

Premier Thanom Kittikachorn of Thailand, worried over the consequences for his country of a peace settlement in Vietnam, received assurances in Washington this week that the United States will not abandon its military and economic commitments in Southeast Asia. But a White House communique issued at the end of his visit rightly stressed that defeat of Communist insurgents inside Thailand is a "Thai responsibility to be carried out" by Thai forces.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner approved today Pan American World Airways's agreement with the Port of New York Authority to operate the Teterboro, N. J., airport.

Your April 12 issue reports passage of a bill by the House of Representatives authorizing an increase of $112 million in the President's budgetary request for maritime subsidies, thus raising the total for such purposes to $460.9 million.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 10 -- When the proclaimed period of mourning for the late Gov. Lurleen B. Wallace ends at sunrise on Monday, Gov. Albert P. Brewer will begin to exercise the duties of Governor and George C. Wallace will be free to resume his Presidential campaign, probably in 30 days.

Radio Prague may have been correct in its assertion yesterday that the Czechoslovak Government knew in advance about planned Soviet troop maneuvers in southern Poland. But that assurance would have been more credible had it come ten or twenty hours earlier -- at the height of worldwide alarm about reports that Soviet troops in Poland were moving toward Czechoslovakia.
Trading was active and prices moved ahead yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 10 -Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson proposed today to use $89,0000 in county funds to make up for Congressional cuts in the budget for summer youth programs in 10 poverty areas.
A royal wish was the United States Coast Guard's command yesterday. As a result, King Olav V of Norway got an opportunity to inspect the world's largest ocean rescue center.

The Four Seasons Nursing Centers of America, Inc., sold shares publicly for the first time yesterday and investors bid so aggressively for them that the price quickly doubled -- to $22 a share from an original price of $11.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -Does a reporter for a television station licensed by the Federal Government have a right to break a law so that the station can broadcast a program it considers to be in the public interest?

Former Senator Barry Goldwater, undergoing cross-examination yesterday in his $2million libel suit, was called on by the defense to explain matters ranging from rightwing political backing to how he treated his pet bulldog.

PARIS, May 10 -- American and North Vietnamese delegates met in formal conference today, after years of fencing and unofficial contacts, in what could be the start of negotiations toward peace in Vietnam.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 10 (UPI) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, said today that if his union's final break with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. should come in December, he would attempt to form a new union federation.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, the president of Columbia University, backed down last night from the strong opposition he had taken the previous day to recommendations made by the school's Joint Committee on Disciplinary Affairs regarding students arrested in campus disorders.

JAEGER, a company that started as a health faddist's dream and grew into a pillar of British propriety, hopes to conquer America. Its weapons are maxiskirts, capes and long culottes as well as tweed suits, skirts and coats that last forever.

A threatened strike of 12,000 New York Telephone Company employes was averted yesterday when agreement was reached on grievance and arbitration procedures concerning the company's plan to transfer switchmen from a Bronx office that was sabotaged last month.
Costumes expressing the name or scent of a favorite perfume were worn by many women among the nearly 800 guests at the Fragrance Fantasy Ball last evening at the New York Hilton.
Mayor Lindsay called on 800 businessmen yesterday not only to give jobs to the hard-core unemployed but also to "adopt" the poor employe's family or block.
Localizing airy nothingness, such as a passing night shadow, is the proper business of genius and no choreographer does it better than George Balanchine.
OMAHA, May 10 -- Vice President Humphrey moved into the uncertain Nebraska political picture in person tonight, just four days before the state's Presidential primary.

Roswell Rudd, a jazz composer and trombonist, last night gave the third in a series of concerts that he describes as "Survival Music 1968." Like the second in the series, it was presented at the Washington Square Church, 133 West Fourth Street.
Preliminary results of a survey disclosed this week that the number of Roman Catholic nuns leaving their religious orders to return to secular life had tripled last year over 1966.

The Newport (R. I.) Casino, the site of the first United States grass court singles championships in 1881, will abandon its annual amateur invitation tournament in favor of a professional round-robin that will be held Aug. 12 through 18.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 10 -- The responsibility for stopping inflation will rest primarily on business and unions once the pending tax increase is in effect, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers said today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 10 -- About 40 kinds of "ordeal bean" and other plant-derived poisons were used by primitive societies to test accused offenders. If they survived, they were considered innocent.

The Manhattan School of Music's Opera Theater, continuing its stress on the French repertory, revived Thomas's "Mignon" last night. For a work that was once enormously popular, it has fallen into neglect, at least as far as New York is concerned.

A declarer who is trying to snatch nine tricks in three no-trump before opponents can make five may have to resort to unusual plays. In the diagramed deal, reported by G. C. H. Fox, a leading English writer, South had to abandon the normal play of the heart suit in order to win the race against time.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The chairman of the National Labor Relations Board defended that agency today against charges that it ignored Congressional intent in applying labor law and deciding labormanagement disputes.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- United States participation in the new international reserve currency system of paper gold was approved today by the to use 15.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Defense Department today listed the names of tile following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Secretary of Welfare Wilbur J. Cohen says that estimates of the cost of Medicaid, the Federal program of medical care for the poor, may have to be raised sharply above projections made last December.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) -- A lawyer in Washington was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of defrauding an order of Roman Catholic nuns of $1.5-million.
" TRUMPETS OF THE LORD," the musical adaptation of James Weldon Johnson's book, "God's Trombones," was seen last night in a powerful, evocative and deeply moving production on Channel 13.
THE supply of 19th-century Staffordshire figures seems endless.

MIDLAND, Tex., May 10 (AP) -- Mickey Wright, chipping and putting well, clipped three strokes from par for a 66 today to gain the first-round lead in the $15,000 Tall City women's open golf tournament.
In 1946, James J. Ling, a high school dropout with Navy and correspondence school training in electricity, invested $3,000 in an electrical contracting shop in Dallas.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -Representative Edward A. Garmatz, chairman of the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries, expressed concern today over published reports that all ship construction under subsidy would be scrapped as a result of the proposed $6-billion Federal budget cut.
Chief Justice Earl Warren, in a dramatic 11th-hour move yesterday, halted the merger of three big Northwestern rail-roads.

PARIS, Saturday, May 11 -- Thousands of students fought pitched battles with the police this morning after occupying much of the Latin Quarter and erecting more than 60 barricades. It was dawn before most of the fighting subsided. At one barricade, students fought with a sandblasting machine from a construction site.
ATHENS, May 10 -- The Government ended its censorship of the Athens daily newspaper Eleftheros Kosmos tonight as an inducement to the capital's other 10 newspapers to be more cooperative.

TORONTO, May 10 -- A tumultuous five - day convention of the Canadian Labor Congress ended today with the election to the executive vice presidency of a Quebec labor leader who had run against another French Canadian backed by the Congress' executive board.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 10 -- A United States military spokesman disclosed tonight that North Vietnamese MIG fighter planes were operating below the 19th Parallel in North Vietnam -- farther south than ever before.
WASHINGTON, MAY 10 -Two events within the last 10 days have illustrated why Hugo Lafayette Black, the Supreme Court's peppery senior Justice, has become its most controversial and enigmatic member.

ROME, May 10 (UPI) -- Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., fought off a determined bid by Jim Moore in the third round of the men's single at the 25th Italian tennis champions today and defeated the South African, 6-4, 5-7, 6-4, 6-3.
BERLIN, May 10 -- East Germany today released a United States citizen sentenced to a 15-year prison term for alleged espionage last September, returning him to American custody in West Berlin.

More than 20,000 people have been doused with the incapacitating spray Chemical Mace, and as the number rises with each new riot and protest demonstration so do questions about the drug's safety and the ethics of its use by the police.

ALBANY, May 10 -- Paul O'Dwyer, former New York City Councilman, said today that his name would be on the June 18 primary election ballot as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., May 10 -- City Manager Theodore W. Maurer announced today that a commitment had been received from William Zeckendorf Sr. to redevelop several hundred acres of a Negro slum along the blighted riverfront here.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, May 11 -- Allied jets, helicopters and artillery crews pounded a section of the Saigon slums through the night and early this morning in an effort to drive the enemy from his last remaining stronghold in the city.

Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Plucky Pan came through for the favorite players yesterday in the feature race at Aqueduct, after an earlier odds-on choice had been deprived of victory and placed last. The penalized colt was Ogden Phipp's King of the Castle, a 2-year-old son of Bold Ruler, making his first start.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department today estimated this year's winter-wheat crop at 1,193,553,000 bushels, down two per cent from last year's record production.

While Army's muscular cadets keep a wary eye on Harvard's depth-laden squad, Yale's late blooming athletes just might steal the 34th annual Heptagonal Games track and field championships on their own DeWitt Cuyler Field in New Haven today.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Navy opened to the public today its file on Lieut. Comdr. Marcus Aurelius Arnheiter, the day after the ousted destroyer skipper complained at an unofficial Congressional inquiry that he had been treated unfairly by the naval authorities.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -The Government issued today a permit to leaders of the Poor People's Campaign allowing them to erect a plywood "city" for 3,000 demonstrators near the Lincoln Memorial and a public exhibit of Mississippi sharecropper shacks at the Smithsonian Institution.
WARSAW, May 10 -- Poland lifted a 24-hour travel ban on Western diplomats today.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, said today that the Army had told him it had ignored an apparent low bid to build M-16 rifles from a Maine company because it did not think the concern could make them fast enough to meet the needs of the South Vietnamese Army.

ALTHOUGH Rudolf Nureyev has produced a great deal of choreography all over the world -- including original versions of all three of the Tchaikovsky ballets -- it was not until last night at the Metropolitan Opera House that America got a chance to see a complete ballet by the Royal Ballet's favorite Russian.

PRAGUE, May 10 -- The official Czechoslovak press agency, C.T.K., said today that the Prague Government had been informed in advance of the Sovietbloc troop maneuvers that had taken place in southern Poland.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 10 (AP) -- A charge against a Detroit trucking company of conspiring with James R. Hoffa, Teamsters union president, was dismissed yesterday by United States District Judge William E. Miller.

PATERSON, N. J., May 10 -- Two hundred Negroes demonstrated in front of police headquarters here late last night to protest the arrest of a 16-year-old Negro boy who had allegedly been sprayed with Chemical Mace and arrested on a charge of loitering in front of a supermarket.
The New England Conservatory of Music, which is celebrating its 100th anniversary this season, opened a four-day Centennial Festival of concerts in New York last night.

OUTSIDE of listing the 114 paintings, drawings and sculptures and commenting on the quality of each one, there is no way to indicate the variety and the charm of "The Artist and the Animal," a loan exhibition at M. Knoedler Co., 14 East 57th Street, for the benefit of the Animal Medical Center.

Another 2-1 victory, their fourth this year, moved the New York Yankees ahead of the Boston Red Sox in the American League standings last night as the two teams met for the first time this season before a crowd of 19,620 at Yankee Stadium.
LONDON, May 10 -- The Labor party surveyed today the disaster it suffered in last night's local elections in England and Wales as jubilant Conservatives proclaimed once again that "Wilson must go."
FRESNO, Calif., May 10 (AP) -- Heulon Hewitt, a 17-year-old high school junior, leaped the best double for the long jump and high jump in track history tonight at the 43d annual West Coast Relays.
Eleven teachers reported for work yesterday despite their "dismissal" on Thursday by the community governing board of an experimental school district in Brooklyn.
Students at Barnard College, the sister school of Columbia College, had their own demonstration yesterday.
In a noisy but orderly finish, the May potato futures contract expired yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Governor Rockefeller has assembled a staff of public relations experts to help in his uphill compaign for the Republican Presidential nomination.

CAIRO, May 10 -- The transfer of Middle Eastern peace efforts to the United Nations in New York reportedly will coincide with an Egyptian effort to obtain a timetable for the application of a Security Council resolution that called for Israeli withdrawal from occupied Arab territory.

It was with great chagrin that I read The Times's May 5 news account reporting the result of protests by Negro students at Northwestern University. The article indicated the university met almost every demand, including that of working to provide segregated living quarters for Negro students.

LONDON, May 10 -- Ministers of the European Free Trade Association, stymied in. their desire for closer ties with the European Economic Community, decided today to study the removal of nontariff barriers among themselves in the interests of free trade.

MOSCOW, May 10 -- A leading Soviet ideologist, in a polemical attack today on Czechoslovakia and Rumania, assailed "democratization and liberalization'' as subversive doctrines promoted by the United States to weaken the Communist movement.
Talk about type-casting: Real policemen are playing stage policemen in a revival of "Detective Story," Sidney Kingsley's 1949 study of precinct life.

A program devoted to music by the Japanese composer Yaji Takahashi was presented last night at Steinway Hall. Mr. Takahashi is a former pupil of Yannis Xenakis and he appears to be seriously influenced by Xenakis's stochastic methods.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Commerce Department eased today more of its restrictions on trade with Eastern Europe in line with the Johnson Administration's program to foster East-West trade.
CARRICK-ON-SHANNON, Ireland -- In a tiny pub, really just one room in a shabby cottage, the television was tuned to a British Broadcasting Corporation interview with American black-power advocates.

MADRID, May 10 -- On the street called Desengano, which means disillusion, 300 Spaniards filed out of the Church of San Martin this morning, raised their right hands in a Fascist salute and broke into the "Horst Wessel Lied," a Nazi marching song.
BALTIMORE, May 10 -- Mary land's 49 delegates to the Democratic National Convention have been committed to support Vice President Humphrey for the Presidential nomination.
ALBANY, May 10 -- Governor Rockefeller sent to the Legislature today measures to permit the state to give direct financial aid to private and religiously affiliated universities and colleges.

The Park Association of New York City has arranged a dinner dance for May 22 at Jager House on Lexington Avenue at 85th Street. The evening, proceeds of which will benefit the association, will be a preview of the Harlem Cultural Festival.
PIMLICO, Md., May 10 (AP) -- Dancer's Image, the disqualified winner of the Kentucky Derby, galloped twice around the Pimlico track today while his owner and trainer watched.

OSTRAVA, Czechoslovakia, May 10 -- This grimy mining capital on the Polish border sleepily basked in holiday sunshine today, unconcerned over reports from the outside that Soviet troops were moving across Poland in this direction.

WESTERN UNION is smiling at the high cost of borrowing Eurodollars with an eye on University Computing. These dollars, on deposit with foreign branches of United States banks, are being tapped by University Computing in making its bid for Western Union shares.

FROM 9 to 5 each weekday, William and Margaret Primavera toil at their separate public-relations jobs in Manhattan. Weekends, however, are a whole new ball game. That's when the Primaveras stop writing press releases and start selling antiques.
PARIS, May 10 -- Parisians reacted with a mild curiosity today to the spectacle of Americans and North Vietnamese moving toward the conference table.

TIME rushes on, and it is hard to believe that the Istomin-Stern-Rose Trio is about seven years old. It is even harder to believe that the group has remained together. When Isaac Stern, Leonard Rose and Eugene Istomin pooled forces, back in 1961, some of the professionals around town smiled knowing smiles.

CHICAGO, May 10 (UPI) -Roosevelt University expelled 16 students today for their part in protest demonstrations. The expulsions triggered a new sitin in which the police hauled 11 protesters out of the university president's office.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- A delegation of members of Congress from New York and New Jersey confronted two Navy officials this week with a demand that the New York port area receive more ship repair business from the Navy.

Finding educated and dedicated social workers to fulfill today's rising health and welfare needs is a difficult problem. The Social Work Recruiting Center, an affiliate of the Greater New York Fund, which is conducting its 30th annual appeal, is making promising strides in the effort to combat this shortage of qualified manpower.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., May 10 -- From the third tier of hills above the Hudson River, many of the white families of this troubled community can gaze down on the Negroes who live on the tier below, and then beyond to a spectacle of dilapidation.
ALBANY, May 10 -- Governor Rockefeller today proposed to the Legislature measures designed to help local officials prevent and control riots.
SINGAPORE, May 10 (Reuters) -- The South Vietnamese National Liberation Front, the political arm of the Vietcong, today denied that its forces killed four journalists in Saigon last Sunday.

FARMINGTON, Conn., May 10 -- Danny Lopez accomplished an unusual fear today when he rode the first three finishers in a green jumper class at the opening session of the Children's Services horse show.
The Fillmore East, Second Avenue and Sixth Street, was sold out twice last night for concerts by the Jimi Hendrix Experience and by a septet called Sly and The Family Stone.

The 93d running of the Withers Stakes will occupy the feature spot at Aqueduct today. A $50,000-added test for 3year-olds, this year's edition of the stakes, to be run at a mile, has attracted a field of 10, making for a gross purse of $59,300 and a winner's share of $38,545.

Six men, including three reputed Mafia figures, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to violate antiracketeering laws by allegedly getting a kickback for arranging a $1.9million loan to a builder from a teamsters union pension fund.

The British pound was hit by selling pressure on London foreign-exchange markets yesterday and dropped to its lowest level since the gold crisis in March.

CHEYNEY, Pa., May 10 (AP) -- Dr. Leroy Banks Allen, president of Cheyney State College which was the scene of a student takeover of the campus administration building earlier this week, has submitted his resignation, it was announced today.

AMES, Iowa, May 10 (AP) -One National Collegiate champion was eliminated, but the rest of the favorites moved on today as the United States Olympic wrestling trials moved through their second day at Iowa State University.

HOMINY FALLS, W. Va., May 10 (UPI) -- Rescue workers inched within 250 feet tonight of 15 coal miners trapped deep inside a flooded mine shaft.

Biggin Hill's Alarich, a 2 1/2-year-old black and rust Doberman pinscher, bred and owned by Norman D. and Phyllis Biggin of West Kingston, R.I., won his first best-in-show award today at the 24th annual Windham County Kennel Club dog show and obedience trial at Recreation Park. UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 13 -- Diplomatic sources said today that Israel would insist, along with Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations special peace envoy, on the need for direct Israeli-Arab negotiations to reach a settlement, in the Middle East.
BOSTON, May 13 -- Mayor Kevin H. White announced today that a major new urban program would be started to expand home and business ownership among the city's poor.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 10 -- A middle-aged woman in a well - tailored wool suit walked into the crowded United States Consulate here to ask about the requirements for immigrating into the United States.
PITMAN, N. J., May 13 -- The Army agreed today to change part of its Armed Forces Day program here after some local residents complained that it might teach "the joys of war" to children.
The nation's program for peaceful use of atomic energy moved ahead yesterday on several fronts.
TORONTO, May 13 -- The medieval profession of fool is being revived in Canada by an immigrant from Europe with two university degrees who quotes Shakespeare and Mother Goose.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 13 -- Secretary General Thant said today that unconditional cessation of bombing of North Vietnam by the United States was an essential condition for fruitful peace negotiations.
A Department of Agriculture report Friday -- that the 1968 wheat crop might be a little below last year's record levels -- failed yesterday to cause significant price movement in wheat futures.
NEW MILFORD, Conn. -- Peter Fink was photographing in Morocco last year when he got a cable announcing he'd just bought himself a barn.
In 1914 the flower of the British universities went to war and were destroyed. As a result Britain's development of scientific research was delayed at least ten years and possibly a generation.
President Johnson has "tragically failed to deliver" a new national maritime policy, the Navy League of the United States says.

The tax swindle convictions of two former Internal Revenue Service employes were upheld here yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals in a 2-to-1 decision, but the court ordered new trials for four taxpayers who were co-defendants.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 13 (UPI) -- President Johnson said today that the nation's auto makers issued 200 orders recalling cars for safety inspections since the National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act went into effect Sept. 9, 1966.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 13 (UPI) -- Bob Harrison, a former pro player, was named today as the head basketball coach at Harvard. He has been the coach at Kenyon College in Ohio for 10 years.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 13 (AP) -- The United States command said today that the latest Vietcong offensive had had almost no effect on the pacification program.

ROME, May 13 (AP) -- Alexander Metreveli of the Soviet Union and Juan Gisbert of Spain upset Cliff Richey and Marty Riessen, seeded American players, today and advanced to the quarter-finals of the Italian tennis championships.

LONDON, May 13 -- King Hussein of Jordan warned today that "time is running out" for a settlement between the Arabs and Israel under the auspices of Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring's mission for the United Nations in the Middle East.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 13 (UPI) -- Phoui Sananikone was re-elected President of the National Assembly today defeating the candidate of opposition southern politicians who are dissatisfied with Premier Souvanna Phouma's efforts to end the Communist threat in Laos.
The money market tightened yesterday, pushing short-term interest rates higher.

The Tyrone Guthrie Theater of Minneapolis is planning to visit New York in December or January for an engagement of three or four weeks at the Billy Rose Theater. The Billy Rose Foundation has agreed to advance $50,000 to the nonprofit repertory troupe to defray costs.
With every day's delay in action by the Legislature on decentralization of New York City's schools, the tragic and totally unnecessary divisiveness of this issue deepens.
The letter in The Times of April 27 concerning the civil liberties of the ousted principal of I.S. 148 in the Bronx does not go far enough.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal panel was named today to consider a Justice Department request for an injunction to block the merger of the Great Northern, Northern Pacific and Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroads.

IT sometimes happens that one's friends do not always put their best foot forward at the right times. Their inner personalities may be charming, their intellectual resources considerable, their manner, on the right occasion, sublime -- but the very moment you introduce them to someone and trust that they will shine, they emerge as stale, flat and unprofitable. That is life.

MOSCOW, May 13 -- Aleksandr Yesenin-Volpin, an active member of an intellectual protest movement here, has been released from a mental hospital after three months of confinement, informed sources reported today.

LONDON, May 13 -- A British Government study of air transport safety found today that American and Australian airlines were safer than those in Britain. It also reported that the two British Government corporations, British-European Airways and British Overseas Airways were safer than independents and that large air transport companies were safer than smaller ones.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- President Johnson met with his Cabinet today to review the Paris talks with North Vietnam and to discuss the nation's economic problems.

Stock prices continued to trace an irregular pattern in more active trading yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -The Federal Trade Commission made public today a set of guidelines for mergers between grocery product manufacturers.
MEDFORD, Ore., May 14 -- Richard M. Nixon expressed "compassion" tonight for the Poor People's Campaign but said that the billions of dollars in Federal aid it sought was "unattainable" now.
Green-thumbed New Yorkers are adding vast quantities of prunings, cuttings and other garden debris to their usual refuse on Mondays and Tuesdays, and the Sanitation Department says please don't.

GROTON, Conn., May 14 -Rear Adm. Husband E. Kimmel, commander of the Pacific Fleet at the time of the Japanese bombing of Pearl Harbor, died tonight, apparently of a heart attack, at his home here. The retired officer was 86 years old.
ISLIP, L. I., May 14 -- In a move believed to be the first of its kind in a New York suburb, the Town Council here outlawed discrimination in housing today under penalty of jail or fine.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 11 -When night falls beside the Tigris River, Abu Nawas Street awakes.

HONOLULU, May 14 -- Gov. John A. Love of Colorado told fellow Governors today that it would be "traitorous" to bow to an edict of the Secretary of the Interior setting water quality control requirements for the states.

BOSTON, May 14 -- Evidence gathered in three laboratories indicates that a substance found in excess amounts in the blood of a majority of schizophrenic patients may be responsible for the bizarre symptoms of this chronic mental disease.
The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) proposed yesterday in Washington that the Government's program for oil import control be completely overhauled.
WARSAW, May 14 -- Poland revealed draft plans today to increase Communist party control of Universities.

NO one thought it the least bit unusual when Mrs. John Sullivan of Belmont, Mass., started designing tennis clothes. Two years ago, the Sullivans were named the First Family of Tennis by the United States Lawn Tennis Association.
Nolan Ryan, the wonderchild of the New York Mets, struck out 14 Cincinnati Reds last night as he pitched the Mets to a 3-2 victory with turnof-the-century flourishes.

In the Senate vote to increase taxes and cut Government spending, only one out of five of the Senators voting yea is up for re-election this year. But of those voting nay, fully half will face the voters in November.

ATLANTA, May 14 -- Pro football's next Super Bowl game between the champions of the National and American Leagues will be played in Miami's Orange Bow1 on Jan. 12, 1969. That announcement was made here today by Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of both leagues, at the spring meeting of the owners and General managers.

BOSTON, May 14 -- Ballerinas are a notoriously strong-willed and capricious breed, but so far only Marcia Haydee of the Stuttgart Opera Ballet has ch6sen to make her brilliant American debut in the midst of a psychiatric convention.
BALTIMORE, May 14 -- Maryland voters turned out in surprisingly large numbers today to reject a proposed new state Constitution and retain the current document, which was drafted in 1867.
PARIS, May 14 -- The North Vietnamese and American delegates sparred at a distance today, through the medium of the press, as they took a day off from their "official conversations" on the war.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 14 -- H. B. Zachry, a builder here, became chief executive officer today of HemisFair.

The battle for control of the Westinghouse Air Brake Company escalated another notch yesterday, when one of its suitors, the Crane Company, extended until May 24 its offer for shares of the railroad equipment maker.

At 10:58 A.M. yesterday, Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, leaned toward a red microphone at bus division headquarters in the East New York section of Brooklyn and broadcast a radio message to Frank Lowey, a bus driver in Flatbush.

OMAHA, May 14 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy, the winner in the Nebraska Democratic Presidential primary, appealed tonight for Senator Eugene J. McCarthy's supporters to join him in a drive against Vice President Humphrey.
Devotees of the turf who concentrate on post numbers rather than on form in their speculations at the daily double windows found themselves in a bull market at Aqueduct yesterday.

BONN, May 14 -- The psychological warfare section of the Defense Ministry has conducted a quiet study of the impact of right-wing radicalism on West German soldiers and has concluded that there is no cause for alarm.
The London stock market rallied from recent declines yesterday on news of an improving trend in British trade.
